(b) The initial terms of office of two members, as designated by their appointment, shall begin on the first day of the month following the month in which this Act is approved by the governor or in which it becomes law without such approval and shall expire on December 31, 2014, and upon the appointment and qualification of their respective successors. The initial term of office of the remaining member of the board shall begin on the first day of the month following the month in which this Act is approved by the governor or in which it becomes law without such approval and shall expire on December 31, 2012, and upon the appointment and qualification of his or her successor. Successors to the members of the board whose terms are to expire shall be appointed to take office on January [1], immediately following the expiration of such terms of office and shall serve for terms of four years each and until their successors are duly appointed and qualified. The board shall take no official action until all members have been certified to the clerk of the Superior Court of Charlton County. Section 4. - [Supervisor of elections.] The Charlton County Board of Commissioners shall appoint a person to serve as the supervisor of elections of Charlton County. Such position shall be full-time or part-time at the discretion of the Charlton County Board of Commissioners and such person shall be paid a salary to be set by the Charlton County Board of Commissioners and payable from county funds. The supervisor of elections shall generally direct and control the administration of elections and voter registration in Charlton County. The supervisor of elections shall be supervised by the board and shall be subject to removal from office by the board with cause. The supervisor of elections shall not be a member of the board nor an elected official. Section 5. - [Tenure.] Each member of the board shall: (1) Serve for a term of four years and until a successor is appointed and qualified, except that initial terms of office shall be as provided in subsection (b) of section 3 of this Act; (2) Be eligible to be reappointed to succeed such member and shall have the right to resign at any time by giving written notice of such resignation to the commissioners and to the clerk of the Superior Court of Charlton County; and (3) Be subject to removal from the board at any time for cause, after notice and hearing, by the judge of the Superior Court of Charlton County. Section 6. - [Evidence of appointment.] (a) The appointment of each member, except the initial members, shall be evidenced by the appointing authority filing an affidavit with the clerk of the Superior Court of Charlton County no later than 30 days preceding the date upon which such member is to take office, stating the name and residence address of the person appointed and certifying that such member has been duly appointed as provided in this Act. The appointment of the initial members of the board shall be evidenced by the appointing authority filing an affidavit with the clerk of the Superior Court of Charlton County immediately following that appointment, stating the name and residence address of the person appointed and certifying that such member has been duly appointed as provided in this Act. The clerk of the superior court shall be notified of interim appointments and shall record and certify such appointments in the same manner as the regular appointment of members. (b) The clerk of the Superior Court of Charlton County shall record each certification on the minutes of the Superior Court of Charlton County and shall certify the name of each member to the Secretary of State and provide for the issuance of appropriate commissions to the members as provided by law for county registrars. Section 7. - [Vacancy.] In the event a vacancy occurs in the office of any member before the expiration of a term, by reason of removal, death, resignation, or otherwise, the appointing authority which is required under section 3 of this Act to make the appointment to the office upon the expiration of the term shall appoint a successor to serve the remainder of the unexpired term as provided for in section 3 of this Act. Section 8. - [Oath.] Before entering upon the duties of office, each member shall take substantially the same oath as required by law for county registrars and shall have the same privileges from arrest. Section 9. - [Powers and duties.] (a) The Charlton County Board of Elections and Registration shall be empowered with all of the powers and duties relating to the conduct of primaries and elections as election superintendents pursuant to the provisions of chapter 2 of title 21 of the O.C.G.A., the "Georgia Election Code." (b) The board shall be empowered with all of the powers and duties relating to the registration of electors and absentee balloting procedures as boards of registrars pursuant to the provisions of chapter 2 of title 21 of the O.C.G.A., the "Georgia Election Code." (c) This Act is intended to implement the provisions of subsection (b) of code section 21-2-40 of the O.C.G.A. and shall be construed liberally so as to effectuate that purpose. Section 10. - [Elected public office.] No person who holds elective public office shall be eligible to serve as a member of the board during the term of such elective public office, and the position of membership of any member shall be deemed vacant upon such member qualifying as a candidate for an elective public office. Section 11. - [Rule or regulation promulgated by political party executive committee.] Any rule or regulation promulgated by a county executive committee of a political party under the provisions of subsection (c) of code section 21-2-111 of the O.C.G.A. with regard to the conduct of primaries shall be null and void if in conflict with a valid rule or regulation of the board. Section 12. - [Primaries; municipal registrar.] (a) Nothing in this Act shall be construed to require or prohibit joint primaries or to require or prohibit the commissioners or any other public agency to bear any expense of conducting primaries not otherwise required by law. (b) The board shall have the authority to serve as municipal registrar and to conduct municipal elections and primaries for any municipal corporation located within Charlton County if such municipal corporation has entered into a contract for that purpose with the board of commissioners of Charlton County. Section 13. - [Distributing material solely to inform and instruct electors.] With the approval of the commissioners, the board shall be authorized to expend public funds for the purpose of preparing and distributing material solely to inform and instruct electors of the county adequately with regard to elections. No material distributed by the board shall contain or express, in any manner or form, any commentary or expression of opinion or request for support with respect to any political issue or matter of political concern. Section 14. - [Vice chairperson.] (a) The board may elect from among its membership a vice chairperson and shall be authorized to organize itself, determine its procedural rules and regulations, adopt bylaws, specify the functions and duties of its employees, and otherwise take such action as is appropriate to the management of the affairs committed to its supervision; provided, however, that no such action shall conflict with general law. (b) Action and decision by the board shall be by majority vote of the members of the board. Section 15. - [Meetings.] (a) The board shall fix and establish, by appropriate resolution entered in its minutes, directives governing the execution of matters within its jurisdiction. The board shall hold meetings in the election offices. Any specially called meetings held pursuant to the bylaws adopted by the board shall be held only after notification of the time and place of the holding of such meeting has been communicated in writing to the supervisor of elections to provide public notice of the meeting as required by law. All meetings of whatever kind of the board shall be conducted pursuant to chapter 14 of title 50 of the O.C.G.A., relating to open meetings. (b) The board shall maintain a written record of policy decisions that shall be amended to include additions or deletions. Such written records shall be subject to article 4 of chapter 18 of title 50 of the O.C.G.A., relating to inspections of public records. Section 16. - [Chairperson; duties; compensation.] (a) The chairperson of the board of elections and registration shall chair all meetings of the board and shall be the spokesperson for the board. (b) The members of the board shall receive such compensation for their services as members of the board as may be determined by the Board of Commissioners of Charlton County. In addition thereto, they shall be reimbursed for their actual and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their duties. (c) All amounts payable under this section shall be paid from the funds of Charlton County. Section 17. - [Administrative offices.] Subject to appropriation of funds by the commissioners, the board shall be authorized to expend public funds to provide for such proper and suitable administrative offices and for such clerical assistants and other employees as the board shall deem appropriate. Compensation for such administrative personnel shall be paid by the board under the county personnel systems wholly from county funds. This section shall not be construed so as to require the board to expend any funds simply because they are authorized to do so under this Act. Section 18. - [Transition.] On the first day of the month following the month in which this Act is approved by the Governor or in which it becomes law without such approval, the election superintendent of Charlton County and the board of registrars of Charlton County shall be relieved of all powers and duties to which the board succeeds by the provisions of this Act; and they shall deliver thereafter to the chairperson of the board, upon his or her written request, the custody of all equipment, supplies, materials, books, papers, records, and facilities of every kind pertaining to such powers and duties. LOCAL ACTS AND RELATED LAWS COMPARATIVE TABLE - GEORGIA LAWS This table shows the location of the sections of the basic Local Acts and Related Laws and any amendments thereto.
Subpart A - GENERAL CODE OF ORDINANCES

div.head: Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Home rule power of counties, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ I; construction of statutes, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1 et seq.; authority of municipality to adopt ordinances, resolutions or regulations, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-3.
Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances of Charlton County, Georgia," and may be so cited. Such Code may also be cited as the "Charlton County Code" or the "county Code." (Code 1999, § 1-1) State Law reference— Codification requirements, O.C.G.A. § 36-80-19. Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances, the following definitions and rules of construction shall be observed, unless inconsistent with the manifest intent of the board of commissioners or the context clearly requires otherwise: Board, board of commissioners. The terms "board" and "board of commissioners" mean the board of commissioners of Charlton County, Georgia. Bond. When a bond is required by law, an undertaking in writing, without seal, is sufficient; in all bonds where the names of the obligors do not appear in the bond, but are subscribed thereto, they shall be bound thereby. Code. The term "Code" means the Code of Ordinances of Charlton County, Georgia, as designated in section 1-1. Computation of time. Except as otherwise provided by time period computations specifically applying to other laws, when a period of time measured in days, weeks, months, years or other measurements of time except hours is prescribed for the exercise of any privilege or the discharge of any duty, the first day shall not be counted but the last day shall be counted; and, if the last day falls on Saturday or Sunday, the party having such privilege or duty shall have through the following Monday to exercise the privilege or to discharge the duty. When the last day prescribed for such action falls on a public and legal holiday, the party having the privilege or duty shall have through the next business day to exercise the privilege or to discharge the duty. When the period of time prescribed is less than seven days, intermediate Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays shall be excluded in the computation. Conjunctions. In a provision involving two or more items, conditions, provisions or events, which items, conditions, provisions or events are connected by the conjunction "and," "or" or "either/or," the conjunction shall be interpreted as follows, except that in appropriate cases the terms "or" and "and" are interchangeable: (1) The term "and" indicates that all the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events apply. (2) The term "or" indicates that the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events apply singly or in any combination. (3) The term "either/or" indicates that the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events apply singly, but not in combination. County. Whenever the terms "county," "the county" and "this county" are used they shall refer to Charlton County, Georgia. Court. The term "court" means the court provided by law for the punishment of offenders against the laws or ordinances of the county, whether it shall be the court now constituted or a court hereafter established pursuant to law. Day. The term "day" means a calendar day of 24 hours. Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision requires the head of a department or an official of the county to do some act or perform some function, it shall be construed to authorize the head of such department or the official to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to do the required act or perform the required function, unless the terms of the provisions designate otherwise. Gender. The masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter. Governor. The term "governor" means the governor of the State of Georgia. Joint authority. A joint authority given to any number of persons or officers may be executed by a majority of them, unless it is otherwise declared. Legislative intent. In all interpretations of this Code or of ordinances, resolutions or motions the courts shall look diligently for the intention of the board of commissioners, keeping in mind at all times the old law, the evil and the remedy. Grammatical errors shall not vitiate any provision, and a transposition of words, terms and phrases may be resorted to when a clause or sentence is without meaning as it stands. Month, year. The terms "month" and "year" mean calendar month and calendar year unless otherwise provided. Names of officers, departments. The name or title of any officer or department shall be read as though the words "of Charlton County" were added thereto. Nontechnical and technical terms. The ordinary significance shall be applied to all terms, except terms of art, or terms connected with a particular trade or subject matter, in which case they shall have the significance attached to them by experts in such trade, or with reference to such subject matter. Number. The singular or plural number shall each include the other, unless expressly excluded. Oath. The term "oath" includes an affirmation in all cases in which by law an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the terms "affirm" and "affirmed" shall be equivalent to the terms "swear" and "sworn." O.C.G.A. The abbreviation "O.C.G.A." means the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. Officer. The term "officer" includes officials appointed by the board of commissioners on a part-time or temporary basis, including the county attorney and magistrate court or state court judge. Or, and. The term "or" may be read "and" and the term "and" may be read "or," if the sense requires it. Owner. The term "owner," when applied to buildings or land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or part of such building or land. Person. The term "person" shall extend and be applied to firms, partnerships, associations, organizations, corporations and bodies politic, or any combination thereof, as well as to natural persons. Personal property. The term "personal property" includes every species of property except real property as defined in this section. Preceding, following. The terms "preceding" and "following" mean generally next before and next after, unless the context requires a different significance. Property. The term "property" includes real and personal property. Real property. The term "real property" includes lands, tenements and hereditaments. Requirements. In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirement adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of this Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than another more general provision, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed controlling. Residence. The term "residence" means the place adopted by a person as his place of habitation and to which, whenever he is absent, he has the intention of returning. When a person eats at one place and sleeps at another, the place where such person sleeps shall be deemed his residence. Right-of-way. The term "right-of-way" means land that is dedicated or otherwise legally established for public use. Roadway. The term "roadway" means that portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic. Schedule of fees and charges. The term "schedule of fees and charges" means the official consolidated list compiled and published by the county which contains rates for utility and other public enterprises, fees, deposit amounts and various charges as determined from time to time by the county commission, an official copy of which is maintained in the office of the county clerk where it is available for reference and review during normal business hours. Seal. The term "seal" means the county seal. Shall, may. The term "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory; the term "may" is permissive. Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" means that portion of the street right-of-way which is improved and designated for the use of pedestrians. Signature, subscription. The terms "signature" and "subscription" include the mark of an illiterate or infirm person. State. Whenever the term "state," "the state" or "this state" is used it shall refer to the State of Georgia. Street. The term "street" means and includes any public way, road, highway, street, avenue, boulevard, parkway, lane, path, viaduct, bridge or any other name a street is commonly known by, or any public place and the approaches thereto within the county when any part thereof is open to the use of the public and established for purposes of vehicular traffic. Substantial compliance. A substantial compliance with any requirement of this Code or ordinances amendatory hereof, especially on the part of public officers, shall be deemed and held sufficient; and no proceeding shall be declared void for want of such compliance, unless expressly so provided. Tenant, occupant. The terms "tenant" and "occupant," applied to a building or land, include any person who occupies the whole or part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. Tense. Terms used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and the present. Title of office. The title of any office shall be construed to include the words "of Charlton County, Georgia." Writing, written. The terms "writing" and "written" include printing and all numerals, as well as pictures, illustrations and printed or written designs. (Code 1999, § 1-2) State Law reference— Statutory definitions and rules of construction, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1 et seq.; computation of time, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1; construction of definitions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-2; meaning of certain words, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3; time, O.C.G.A. § 9-11-6. Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections; history notes; references. (a) The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections or as any part of the section nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. (b) The history notes appearing in parentheses after each section and the references and editor's notes scattered throughout the Code are for the benefit of the user of the Code and shall have no legal effect. (Code 1999, § 1-3) State Law reference— Notes and catchlines of Code sections not part of law, O.C.G.A. § 1-1-7. Sec. 1-4. - Code provisions considered continuations of existing ordinances. The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as ordinances adopted prior to this Code and included in such Code, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. (Code 1999, § 1-5) Sec. 1-5. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. (a) The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinance in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. (b) The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, or any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or matter covered under the ordinance repealed. (Code 1999, § 1-6) Sec. 1-6. - Amendments to Code. (a) All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code, may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion in this Code. In the case of the repeal of chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from this Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code of Ordinances by the board of commissioners. (b) Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section ____________ of the Code of Ordinances of Charlton County, Georgia, is hereby amended to read as follows:…." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. (c) If a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language shall be used: "That the Code of Ordinances of Charlton County, Georgia, is hereby amended by adding a section (division, article or chapter) to be numbered ____________ , which section (division, article or chapter) reads as follows:…." The new section, division, article or chapter shall then be set out in full as desired. (d) All sections, divisions, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed must be specifically repealed by section, division, article or chapter number, as the case may be. (Code 1999, § 1-7) Sec. 1-7. - Supplementation of Code. (a) By contract or by county personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared on an annual basis. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive, permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the board of commissioners during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages that have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. (b) In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. (c) When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier, meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement, may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the codifier may: (1) Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions. (2) Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles. (3) Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers. (4) Change the terms "this ordinance" or terms of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections ____________ through ____________ ," inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code. (5) Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meanings of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. (Code 1999, § 1-8) Sec. 1-8. - Severability of parts of Code. It is hereby declared to be the intention of the board of commissioners that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code is declared unconstitutional, invalid or unenforceable by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality, invalidity or unenforceability shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. (Code 1999, § 1-9) State Law reference— Severability, O.C.G.A. § 1-1-3. Sec. 1-9. - Altering Code. It shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or deletions any part or portion of this Code or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with this Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in sections 1-10 through 1-14. (Code 1999, § 1-10) State Law reference— Altering, falsifying or stealing public records unlawful, O.C.G.A. § 45-11-1. Sec. 1-10. - Enforcement of Code; citation. The sheriff of the county, the deputies thereof, constables, any lawfully appointed agent of the county and all other law enforcement officers shall be authorized to issue citations to violators of any provisions of this Code. Such citation shall state the time and place at which the accused is to appear for trial, shall identify the offense with which the accused is charged, shall have an identifying number by which it shall be filed with the court, shall indicate the identity of the accused and the date of service, and shall be signed by the officer who completes and serves it. Provided, however, violations or alleged violations of chapter 150 of this Code section may be cited and a citation as aforesaid, issued by the county building inspector. (Code 1999, § 1-11; Ord. of 7-5-1990, § 2; Ord. of 8-2-2001) Sec. 1-11. - Liability for violations by corporations, other associations. (a) Any violation of this Code by any officer, agent or other person acting for or employed by any corporation or unincorporated association or organization, while acting within the scope of his office or employment, shall in every case also be deemed to be a violation by such corporation, association or organization. (b) Any officer, agent or other person acting for or employed by any corporation or unincorporated association or organization shall be subject and liable to punishment as well as such corporation or unincorporated association or organization for the violation by it of any provisions of this Code, where such violation was the act or omission, or the result of the act, omission or order of any such person. (Code 1999, § 1-12) Sec. 1-12. - Court proceedings. (a) Violations of any section of this Code shall be tried upon citation as described in section 1-10 or upon accusation and may be tried with or without a prosecuting attorney. The county attorney, or an attorney who is a member of the state bar in good standing as designated by the board of county commissioners, shall serve as the prosecuting attorney. (b) Violations of this Code shall be tried in the magistrate court or state court of the county. (c) Each violation of this Code shall constitute a separate offense. (Code 1999, § 1-13) State Law reference— Magistrate courts, O.C.G.A. § 15-10-1 et seq.; violation of county ordinances, O.C.G.A. § 15-10-60 et seq.; punishment for misdemeanors, O.C.G.A. § 17-10-3; maximum punishments which may be imposed for violations of county ordinances, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20(b); county responsibility for sentencing and maintenance of inmates, O.C.G.A. § 42-5-51(a). Sec. 1-13. - General penalty. (a) In this section, the term "violation of this Code" means any of the following: (1) Doing an act that is prohibited or made or declared unlawful, an offense, a violation or a misdemeanor by ordinance, by statute adopted by reference in this Code, by state rule or regulation adopted by reference in this Code or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. (2) Failure to perform an act that is required to be performed by ordinance, by statute adopted by reference in this Code, by state rule or regulation adopted by reference in this Code or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. (3) Failure to perform an act if the failure is prohibited or is made or declared unlawful, an offense, a violation or a misdemeanor by ordinance, by statute adopted by reference in this Code, by state rule or regulation adopted by reference in this Code or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. (b) In this section, the term "violation of this Code" does not include the failure of a county officer or county employee to perform an official duty, unless it is specifically provided that the failure to perform the duty is to be punished as provided in this section. (c) Unless a higher penalty is otherwise specified, whenever in this Code or in any ordinance of the county any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in this Code or any ordinance the doing of any act is required and the failure to do such act is declared to be unlawful, and no specific penalty is provided, and unless otherwise provided by state law, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any such ordinance shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 and imprisonment in the county jail and work and labor on the streets or public works of the county, whether within or without the corporate limits, not to exceed six months, or both a fine and sentence of imprisonment and labor; and all sentences may be in the alternative and fines may be imposed with the alternative of sentence to imprisonment and labor if the fines are not paid. Each day any violation of this Code or of any ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. (d) Violations of this Code may be abated by injunctive or other equitable relief. The imposition of a penalty does not prevent injunctive relief. (Code 1999, § 1-14; Ord. of 9-5-1991) State Law reference— Punishment for misdemeanors generally, O.C.G.A. § 17-10-3; maximum sentences and fines which may be imposed for violation of municipal ordinance, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(2). Sec. 1-14. - Additional penalties. (a) In every case in which any court in this county, including any court of a municipality which has entered into the intergovernmental contract as provided for in this section, shall impose a fine, which shall be construed to include costs, for any offense against a criminal or traffic law of this state or any offense against a county or municipal ordinance, there shall be imposed as an additional penalty a sum equal to ten percent of the original fine. (b) At the time of posting bail or bond in any case involving a violation of a criminal or traffic law of this state or a violation of a county or municipal ordinance, an additional sum equal to ten percent of the original amount of bail or bond shall be posted. In every case in which any court of this county, including any court of a municipality which has entered into the intergovernmental contract as provided for in this section, shall order the forfeiture of bail or bond, the additional sum equal to ten percent of the original bail or bond shall be collected. (c) The additional penalties set forth in this section shall be in addition to that amount required by O.C.G.A. § 47-17-60 to be paid into the Peace Officers' Annuity and Benefit Fund, by O.C.G.A. § 47-11-51 to be paid into the Judges of Probate Courts Retirement Fund of Georgia, or by any other provision of law. (d) The additional penalties as prescribed in this section shall be assessed and collected by the clerk or court officer charged with the duty of collecting monies arising from fines and forfeited bonds. Such additional penalties shall be paid over to the board of commissioners by the tenth day of the month following the month in which these sums are collected. (e) All such sums collected and paid over to the board of commissioners shall be deposited into a special account which shall be known as the county jail fund. (f) All monies collected pursuant to this section and placed in the county jail fund shall be expended solely and exclusively for constructing, operating, and staffing the county correctional facilities, or for such other purposes as specified in O.C.G.A. § 15-21-95. (g) The additional penalties provided for by this section shall not be imposed or collected in any court operated by any municipality located in the county, unless the municipality and the county enter into an intergovernmental contract providing for use of the county jail, correctional institution or detention facility by municipal prisoners. (h) The chairperson of the county board of commissioners may execute on behalf of the county an intergovernmental contract with the City of Folkston concerning the imposition and collection of additional penalty assessments in criminal and traffic cases. Further, the county clerk may attest the contract on behalf of the county. (Code 1999, § 1-15; Res. of 11-28-1989; Res. of 9-18-1990) State Law reference— Additional penalty to be imposed in criminal and traffic cases to provide training to law enforcement officers and prosecuting officials, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-73; additional penalty assessments for jail construction and staffing, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-93; imposition of additional penalty for certain drug offenses, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-100; imposition of additional penalty for offense of driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-112. Sec. 1-15. - Interpretation of Code. In all interpretations of this Code, and ordinances, the courts shall look diligently for the intention of the board of county commissioners, keeping in view, at all times, the old law, the evil and the remedy. Grammatical errors shall not vitiate, and a transposition of words and clauses may be resorted to when the sentence or clause is without meaning as it stands. State Law reference— Similar provisions as to state laws, Ga. Code, § 1-3-1. Sec. 1-16. - Substantive compliance with Code. A substantial compliance with any requirement of this Code, or ordinances, on the part of public officers, shall be deemed and held sufficient, and no proceeding shall be declared void for want of such compliance, unless expressly so provided by the enactment. Sec. 1-17. - Prior offenses, penalties and rights not affected by adoption of Code. (a) Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty of forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. (b) Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed as abating any action pending under or by virtue of any general ordinance of the county repealed in this chapter, and all general ordinances contained in this Code shall be deemed to be continuing and not a new enactment of the same ordinance. This chapter shall not be deemed as discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering any penalty accrued or to accrue or as affecting the liability of any person or as waiving any right of the county under any ordinance or section thereof in force at the time of the adoption of this Code. Sec. 1-18. - Rates, charges and fees established. (a) Unless otherwise provided for, all rates, charges or fees necessary for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this Code shall be as currently established or as hereafter adopted by motion, resolution or ordinance of the board of county commissioners, from time to time. Any rates, charges or fees established by the county pursuant to the regulations or requirements established herein may be changed from time to time by the board of county commissioners, and such changes shall both be considered an amendment to this Code. (b) Whenever any provision of this Code provides that a rate, charge or fee shall be established by the board of county commissioners, from time to time, and the amount of such rate, charge or fee is not expressed in this Code in any dollar amount, then the amount of such rate, charge or fee shall be the most recent and latest amount established, set or fixed by the board of county commissioners by ordinance, resolution or motion. Sec. 1-19. - To provide for additional enforcement of county ordinances in the state court of the county. All previously enacted ordinances of the county, the violation of which may result in incarceration, are hereby amended so that the term "State Court of Charlton County" may be inserted in place of the term "magistrates' court." Further, the solicitor of the state court is given all powers needed to prosecute the violation of all county ordinances, either in the state court or magistrates' court. It is the intent of this section to allow for prosecution of any ordinance violation which, as of the date of the execution hereof, may be prosecuted in the magistrates' court of the county in the state court of the county without depriving the magistrates' court of any jurisdiction previously conferred. Violations of any county ordinance henceforth may be prosecuted by summons, uniform traffic citation or accusation, as allowed by the laws of the state. This ordinance shall immediately become effective upon two readings in open meeting and provision to the public of an opportunity to be heard. (Ord. of 5-10-2007) Sec. 1-20. - Ordinances not affected by Code. (a) Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following: (1) Any offense or act committed or done, any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. (2) Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the county or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the county or any evidence of the county's indebtedness. (3) Any contract or obligation assumed by the county. (4) Any ordinance or resolution establishing or fixing the salaries, retirement and pension plans, benefits, personnel policy and/or administrative procedures for county officers or employees not otherwise enumerated in this Code. (5) Any right or franchise granted by the county. (6) Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, widening, paving, etc., any street or public way in the county. (7) Any appropriation or budget ordinance. (8) Any ordinance which, by its own terms, is effective for a stated or limited term. (9) Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor. (10) Any zoning ordinance or ordinance rezoning specific property or amending the zoning map. (11) Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any subdivision plat or providing for subdivision regulations. (12) Any ordinance describing or altering the boundaries of the county. (13) The administrative ordinances, resolutions or motions of the county not in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of this Code. (14) Any ordinance levying or imposing taxes not included in this Code. (15) Any ordinance establishing or prescribing street grades in the county. (16) Any ordinance or regulation prescribing traffic regulations for specific locations concerning through streets, parking limitations, parking prohibitions, one-way traffic, limitations on loads of vehicles or loading zones not in conflict or inconsistent with this Code. (17) Any ordinance or resolution of agreement with another political subdivision. (18) Any ordinance or resolution establishing or imposing any county rates, charges or fees for the county that are not otherwise enumerated in this Code. (19) Any ordinance or resolution that is temporary, although general in effect. (20) Any ordinance or resolution that is special, although permanent in effect. (21) Any ordinance or resolution, the purpose of which has been accomplished. (b) No such ordinance shall be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance which is repealed by this chapter. All such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. (Code 1999, § 1-4) Sec. 1-21. - Procedure for the adoption of ordinances. There shall be two readings of each proposed ordinance at separate, meetings of the board of commissioners. Between the two meetings the title of the proposed ordinance shall be advertised twice in the legal organ of this county, and a copy shall be made available to any member of the public who requests same. Upon final adoption of an ordinance, it shall be authenticated by the signature of the chairman of the board of commissioners and attested by the county clerk. The county clerk shall see that all ordinances are codified and placed in the current Charlton County Code of Ordinances. (Ord. No. 3 of 2016, § 1-21, 2-4-2016)

div.head: Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Counties a body corporate and politic, Ga. Const. art. IX, § I, ¶ I; county officers, election, term, compensation, Ga. Const. art. IX, § I, ¶ III; home rule for counties, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ I; supplemental powers of municipalities and counties enumerated, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III; county government generally, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-1 et seq.; county a body corporate, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-3; board of commissioners authorized to adopt ordinances for the governing and policing of the unincorporated areas of the county, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20(a); organization of county government, O.C.G.A. § 36-5-20 et seq.; matters over which governing authority has jurisdiction, O.C.G.A. § 36-5-22.1; county property generally, O.C.G.A. § 36-9-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 2-1. - Policy of nondiscrimination on the basis of handicapped status adopted. The county board of commissioners does not discriminate on the basis of handicapped status in the admission or access to, or treatment or employment in, its programs or activities. The clerk of the county commission is designated to coordinate compliance with the nondiscrimination requirements contained in section 51.55 of the revenue sharing regulations. (Code 1999, § 2-1; Mo. of 1-5-1984) State Law reference— Handicapped persons, O.C.G.A. § 30-1-1 et seq.; Georgia Equal Employment for the Handicapped Code, O.C.G.A. § 34-6A-1 et seq. Sec. 2-2. - Records management. (a) The county board of commissioners hereby names and appoints the clerk of the county board of commissioners as the party responsible for records management activities. The clerk of the commission shall act for, and in behalf of, itself in directing and coordinating all records management matters. (b) Records shall be maintained in accordance with the retention schedules approved by the state records committee, and the recommended record management schedules are hereby approved and adopted. (Code 1999, § 2-2; Res. of 12-15-1983) State Law reference— Georgia Records Act, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-90 et seq. Sec. 2-3. - Purchase orders; designation of purchasing agent. (1) Purchase orders: A purchase order is to be obtained for all purchases of $100.00 or more from the county clerk. The road department and maintenance shop are required to obtain a purchase order for any amount greater than $500.00. Like items to be acquired from the same vendor shall be grouped together on one purchase order where possible for more economical purchases. a. Funds must be budgeted prior to making any acquisition of materials, supplies, services or equipment. The requesting department needs to post the budget account number where the funds are to be expended. b. Purchases that are $100.00, and below: Any purchase that is estimated to cost less than $100.00 will not require any documents to explain the purchase. Purchases for the road department and maintenance shop which equal less than $500.00 will not require any documents to explain the purchase. c. Purchase orders estimated to be $100.00 or more, up to $1,000.00: Any such purchase shall require quotes and be summarized on a quote form for each vendor's quote and submitted to the county clerk as documentation. Any purchase for the road department and maintenance shop that is greater than $500.00 shall require quotes and be summarized on a quote form for each vendor's quote and submitted to the county clerk as documentation. Any amount less than $500.00 for the road department and maintenance shop are referenced in part (b) of this section. d. Purchase orders estimated to be $1,000.00 or more, up to $5,000.00: Any such purchase shall require written quotes from each vendor, and be reviewed by the county commission office, for approval. e. Purchases estimated to be $5,000.00 or more: Any such purchase shall require formal bids to be submitted to the board of commissioners for award of the bid. f. Purchase orders estimated to be $3,000.00 or more shall require review by the county commission office, and to have been included in the budget prior to authorizing the purchase. (2) Award of bid criteria: The BOC and the staff in determining the lowest and best bidder shall consider the vendors ability, capacity, skill, character, integrity, reputation, judgement, experience, efficiency, previous performance, compliance to the law, service, maintenance ability, and financial resources of the bidders. "Products" shall be evaluated on quality, availability, adaptability, delivery time and future maintenance and service. The board of commissioners is to make the final selection or award based upon the "best value" for Charlton County. (3) Local vendor privilege: If a Local Vendor's bid shall meet all specifications and is within five percent of the lowest responsive bid, then the board of commissioners may consider the fact that the bidder is a local vendor in making the bid award. A "local vendor" for purposes of this section shall be defined as a vendor maintaining a physical presence within Charlton County, including, but not limited to the maintenance of one office within Charlton County and the continuous employment of not fewer than one person at such office for more than six months and hold a business license within Charlton County or the appropriate state license prior to the submission of such bid. The mere maintenance of a post office box within Charlton County shall not qualify a vendor as "local" for purposes of this policy. This preference shall not apply to road construction or public works construction governed by Georgia Law O.C.G.A. § 36-91-1 et seq. or to the purchase of any other goods and/or services for which such preference is prohibited by Georgia Law. (4) State contracts, general service administration and Us communities governmental purchasing alliances: Items available for purchase from these sources have already been through a formal bidding process, thus items purchased through these programs shall be exempt for the local bidding process. (5) Road contracts and public works contracts: Public Works Contracts shall be governed by O.C.G.A. § 36-91-1 Georgia Local Government Public Works Construction Law, which supersedes this purchasing ordinance. (6) Preference for Georgia products: In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 36-84-1 et seq., Charlton County shall give preference, as far as reasonable and practicable, to such supplies, materials, equipment and agricultural products as may be manufactured, produced or grown within the State of Georgia. Such preference shall not sacrifice quality or reasonable delivery time. (7) Utilities, service contracts, insurances and judicial services: The BOC reviews and approves the following by direct methods of review and approval. These types of agreements include the following: a. Utilities, including electricity, natural and propane gas, water, sewer, land line phones, cell phones and similar services, b. Service agreements, including sprinklers, fire extinguishers, alarm services, elevators, and pest control, lawn services, similar services, and c. Insurances, including general liability, fleet, fire, group health, life, workers compensation, and retirement. d. Judicial services: including indigent defense, public defenders, court reporting, probate services, appointed attorneys, jail services and similar services. e. Agency contracts: The BOC reviews agency contracts during the budget process. Agency contracts include the following: 1. Health department, 2. DFCS, 3. Library, 4. Unison (mental health), 5. Georgia Forestry Commission, 6. Seven River RDandC, 7. Southern Georgia Regional Commission, and 8. Similar agencies. Purchasing manual: A purchasing manual with related forms will provide a list of procedures once the BOC adopts the purchasing ordinance. (Code 1999, § 2-3; Mo. of 12-7-1989; Ord. No. 5 of 2016, §§ 1—7, 3-3-2016; Ord. No. 11 of 2017, 4-6-2017) State Law reference— Board of commissioners authority to control property of the county, O.C.G.A. § 36-5-22.1; county property generally, O.C.G.A. § 36-9-1 et seq. Sec. 2-4. - Fee for use of county facilities. There shall be a fee, as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges, for use of county facilities, i.e., St. George Community Room, Folkston Division Fire Station, for fundraising purposes for private groups and private purposes. (Code 1999, § 2-4; Res. of 6-25-1982) Sec. 2-5. - Use of county equipment. (a) There is a rental fee, as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges, per hour for county machines. County machines shall be operated only by county personnel. (b) The operator shall be paid by the person receiving services and shall be paid time and a half on weekends. (c) Payment for dirt or machine rentals shall be made in advance. The county shall charge a fee, as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges, per load for dirt, which shall be hauled only when equipment is working in the area. (d) These services shall be available only if no local contractor can provide them. (e) A waiting list shall be used. Services shall be available on a first come, first served basis. (Code 1999, § 2-5; Mo. of 3-21-1985) Sec. 2-6. - Franchise for cable TV service required. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or attempt to operate any business or undertaking for the transmission by cable and distribution of television energy in the county without first obtaining a franchise from the county government. (Code 1999, § 2-6; Ord. of 12-15-1980) Editor's note— The form for any franchise that may be granted to provide cable TV service in the county is on file in the office of the clerk of the county commissioners. State Law reference— County regulation of cable television systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-18-1 et seq. Secs. 2-7—2-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS
Sec. 2-31. - Meetings. (a) The only regularly scheduled meeting of the county board of commissioners shall be held at the county courthouse in Folkston, Georgia, on a day and time as established by the board of county commissioners from time to time. The commission shall hold such other called meetings as may be deemed necessary which are authorized by existing state laws. (b) Notice of the time and day of the regularly scheduled meetings of the board of commissioners shall be advertised in the official county organ. A copy of this section shall be posted in the county courthouse and a copy shall be given to the sheriff, clerk of superior court, tax commissioner, chief magistrate and probate judge of the county. (c) Whenever any meeting required to be open to the public is to be held at a time or place other than at the time and place prescribed for regular meetings, the board shall give due notice thereof in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1(d). (Code 1999, § 2-31) State Law reference— Meetings to be open to public, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1 et seq.; excluded proceedings, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-3. Sec. 2-32. - Recreation advisory board created; membership; appointments; terms of office; quorum; expenses. (a) Composition: There is hereby created the Charlton County Recreation Advisory Board which shall consist of five citizens of the County appointed to five posts. The members of the advisory board shall be appointed by the board of commissioners. (b) Terms: For initial terms, two members (Posts 1 and 3) shall be appointed for a term of one year; three members (Posts 2, 4 and 5) shall be appointed for two years. Thereafter all members shall serve for a term of two years. The members of the advisory board shall be eligible for re-appointment. (c) Officers: The advisory board shall elect a chairman, a vice chairman and secretary and such other officers as it deems necessary. (d) Compensation: The members and officers shall serve without compensation, but shall be entitled to reimbursement for actual travel, training and maintenance expenses incurred in the performance of their duties; provided that such expenses are first approved by the county administrator. (e) Quorum: Three members present at a meeting shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of any business. (f) Meetings: The advisory board shall establish a regular schedule of meeting which shall be open to the public. (Ord. No. 7 of 2016, § 1, 4-21-2016) Sec. 2-33. - Powers of the advisory board. The advisory board shall have the following powers, subject to the approval of this board of commissioners: (a) To make recommendations to this board of commissioners as to the selection and retention of the recreation director, the operation of the recreation facilities, recreation programs and services. (b) To assist in the preparation of long range plans for improvements to the recreation programs and facilities. (c) To assist in seeking grants for improvements, to accept donations, gifts, devises and endowments to be used for carrying out the purposes of this article. All funds so acquired shall held and disbursed by the county clerk's office. (d) The advisory board shall not have any authority to make any purchases or otherwise bind the county to any financial obligation or undertaking, the same being expressly prohibited. The financial requirements of the advisory board shall be meet in accordance with the purchasing policies of the board of commissioners. (Ord. No. 7 of 2016, § 2, 4-21-2016) Sec. 2-34. - Duties of the advisory board. (a) Supervise the management of the recreation facilities of this county, which presently include: Deuce Lloyd Park, Chatman-Mobley Park, St. George Park, Traders Hill Camp Grounds, and all Georgia DNR boat ramps including: Traders Hill, St. George, Camp Pinckney, and Burnt Fort. (b) Determine and set all policies, rules and regulations concerning the said recreation facilities and the activities permitted therein. (c) Review and make recommendations about the annual budget proposals prepared by the recreation director for submitting to the county administrator and the board of commissioners. (d) Assist the recreation director with the preparation and submittal of an annual report of all recreation activities to the county administrator and the board of commissioners. (e) Assist the recreation director in annually reviewing and updating the schedule of fees for the participation in recreation programs and the use of public facilities, to be recommended to the county administrator and the board of commissioners. (f) Supervise the policy that any incident resulting in injury to an individual on the property of a recreation facility during any event or activity authorized by this board and/or the recreation director shall be reported, in writing, to the county clerk's office and the county administrator within one business day after the incident. (g) Supervise the policy that the use of alcoholic beverages or illegal drugs in any form on the premises of a recreation facility shall not be permitted. (h) Supervise the policy that every person authorized by the recreation director or the advisory board to use the recreation facilities will be held responsible and accountable for the proper use and protection of all property which comes under his/her control, and such person shall not cause damage or waste to recreational property. (Ord. No. 7 of 2016, § 3, 4-21-2016) Secs. 2-35—2-50. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— The personnel management system policies including the recruitment policy and procedure as well as the grievance procedure is compiled and published separately by the county. An official copy is on file in the office of the clerk of the board of commissioners.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 2-51. - Seat belts. All persons who drive or ride in vehicles while on county business will, in all cases, wear a seat belt. (Code 1999, § 2-51; Ord. of 11-6-1997, § 3) Sec. 2-52. - Employee bond. All county employees of whom a bond is required for their employment shall be bonded in the amount of $100,000.00. (Ord. of 8-5-1999) Sec. 2-53. - Personnel management system incorporated by reference. The Charlton County Personnel Management System manual, as approved by the board of commissioners on December 4, 1997, and amended by the board from time to time, is hereby adopted by reference and incorporated herein to the same extent and effect as though it were fully set forth. Secs. 2-54—2-79. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - BENEFITS
Sec. 2-80. - Workers' compensation. Certain elected officials of the county shall be covered under the Association of County Commissioners of Georgia Group Self-Insured Workers' Compensation Fund. While performing their elected duties, the board of commissioners, sheriff, probate judge, clerk of court, magistrate judge, tax commissioner, coroner and volunteer firefighters shall be covered under the worker's compensation laws of the state. (Code 1999, § 2-61; Ord. of 12-3-1987, § 1) Sec. 2-81. - Social security. The county, by and through its lawfully constituted board of commissioners, hereby adopts the terms, conditions, requirements, reservations, benefits, privileges and other conditions thereunto appertaining, of title II of the Social Security Act (42 USCA § 401 et seq.), as amended by Public Law No. 761, 83rd Congress, for and on behalf of all the officers and employees thereof and of its departments and instrumentalities, except any such officers and employees who occupy any position, office or employment not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (Code 1999, § 2-62; Res. of 2-1-1955; Res. of 12-20-1984, § 1) State Law reference— Political subdivisions authorized to extend benefits of title II of the Social Security Act to employees, O.C.G.A. § 47-18-41. Secs. 2-82—2-105. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS, AUTHORITIES DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 2-106—2-123. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF TAX ASSESSORS[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Creation of county board of tax assessors, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-290.
Sec. 2-124. - Number of members. The county board of tax assessors shall consist of five members who shall be qualified, perform the duties and hold the office of tax assessor as prescribed by the laws of the state. (Code 1999, § 2-96; Res. of 2-20-1986) Secs. 2-125—2-146. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - VOLUNTEER FIRE DEPARTMENT BOARD OF DIRECTORS
Sec. 2-147. - Created. A board of directors of the voluntary fire units of the county is hereby created and established to serve at the discretion of the commission. (Code 1999, § 2-106; Res. of 4-7-1983, § A) Sec. 2-148. - Authority. The board of directors of the voluntary fire units are hereby delegated the authority and shall be charged with the responsibility of managing and directing the operations of the voluntary fire departments of the county, with the approval of the county commission, and shall report its actions to the board of commissioners. The board shall have any other incidental powers and authority to carry out the charge of this division. (Code 1999, § 2-107; Res. of 4-7-1983, § F) Sec. 2-149. - Composition. The board of directors of the voluntary fire units shall be composed of five persons who shall serve terms as set out in this division. (Code 1999, § 2-108; Res. of 4-7-1983, § B) Sec. 2-150. - Appointment of members. (a) Three members of the board of directors of the voluntary fire units shall be elected officials from the governing authorities of the City of Folkston, City of Homeland and this county. Each of these respective governmental authorities shall make their appointments to the board during their first meeting in January of each year. (b) The remaining two members of the board shall be appointed by the county board of commissioners and shall each serve a term of two years after the initial terms which shall be staggered so that one member shall be initially appointed for one year and the other for two years. The initial terms of the board members shall be determined by the flip of a coin after the appointments have first been made. The two board members who are not representatives of a governmental unit shall be appointed by virtue of their residency in the north and south ends of the county. That is, one member shall come from the north end of the county and one member shall come from the south end of the county. The nonelected members may be active voluntary firefighters. (c) The board of directors of the voluntary fire units shall have numbered posts and be designated as Post 1 (Charlton County), Post 2 (City of Folkston), Post 3 (City of Homeland), Post 4 (north) and Post 5 (south). (Code 1999, § 2-109; Res. of 4-7-1983, §§ C—E) Sec. 2-151. - Budget. The board of directors of the voluntary fire units shall propose an annual budget to the county commission for consideration and shall then operate within the financial confines of the adopted budget, unless the budget is amended by the county commission. (Code 1999, § 2-110; Res. of 4-7-1983, § G) Secs. 2-152—2-170. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - HOSPITAL AUTHORITY[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- State Law reference— Hospital Authorities Law, O.C.G.A. § 31-7-70 et seq.
Sec. 2-171. - Created. The hospital authority of the county is created and established by the board of commissioners by the adoption of the ordinance from which this section is derived. (Code 1999, § 2-121; Ord. of 3-4-1970) Secs. 2-172—2-195. - Reserved. DIVISION 5. - INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY[5]
Footnotes: --- (5) --- State Law reference— Development Authorities Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq.
Sec. 2-196. - Created. There is hereby created a public body corporate and politic to be designated as the county industrial development authority, having all the powers and privileges granted under state law. (Code 1999, § 2-131; Res. of 6-4-1963)

div.head: Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.; authority to adopt rules and regulations relating to manufacture, sale and distribution of distilled spirits, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-49.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. (a) The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Package means a bottle, can, keg, barrel or other original consumer container. Retail malt beverage dealer means and includes any person who engages in selling malt beverages at retail in the county without the corporate limits of any municipality located therein, and means and includes any person serving malt beverages for a pecuniary consideration in the county without the corporate limits of any municipality located therein. Retail wine dealer means and includes any person who engages in selling wine at retail in the county without the corporate limits of any municipality located therein, and means and includes any person serving wine for a pecuniary consideration in the county without the corporate limits of any municipality located therein. Sheriff means the sheriff or any deputy sheriff of the county. Wholesale malt beverage dealer means any person engaged in distribution or selling malt beverages to a retail malt beverage dealer, and not directly to the consumers. Wholesale wine dealer means any person engaged in distribution or selling wine to a retail wine dealer, and not directly to the consumers. (b) The definitions set forth in O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2 et seq. (Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code—Definitions), as amended, shall be effective as definitions of the words, terms and phrases used in this chapter. All words, terms and phrases used herein, other than those specifically defined elsewhere in this chapter, shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2 et seq., as amended, and shall have the same scope and effect that the same words, terms and phrases have where used in O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2 et seq., as amended. (Code 1999, § 3-1; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part I) Sec. 4-2. - Violation of chapter prosecuted in magistrate court or state court. Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or who shall assist another in evading or avoiding payment of the fees and/or taxes imposed by this chapter shall be cited for these violations and tried in the county magistrate court or state court, in accordance with the provisions of state law for violations of county ordinances. Upon conviction, a sentence may be imposed according to the general penalties described section 1-13. (Code 1999, § 3-2; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part VII, § 3) Sec. 4-3. - Compliance with state law. Each licensee under the provisions of this chapter shall comply with all applicable rules, regulations, laws and statutes of the state, and shall in addition thereto or in furtherance thereof: (1) Prohibit the sale, serving or consumption of malt beverages and wine in automobiles or other vehicles, or anywhere outside the main building or accessory thereto in which the business of such licensee is operated, excepting drive-in windows; and (2) Strictly adhere to the laws of the state respecting the sale of malt beverages and wine to persons under the age of 21, intoxicated persons or habitual drunkards. (Code 1999, § 3-3; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part III, § 10(a), (b)) Sec. 4-4. - Compliance with chapter. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any retail malt beverages and/or wine dealer to own, hold, possess or sell any malt beverages and/or wine in the county without the corporate limits of any municipality located therein, unless all the terms and provisions of this chapter shall have first been complied with. (Code 1999, § 3-4; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part III, § 14) Sec. 4-5. - Liability of licensee. No retail dealer for the sale of malt beverages and/or wine shall allow such malt beverages and/or wine to be consumed on his premises unless such dealer has a license for on-premises consumption. Any retail dealer with a license for off-premises consumption only shall be held responsible for such consumption by his customers or other parties. (Code 1999, § 3-5; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part V, § 2) Sec. 4-6. - Inspection of licensee's premises. The business premises of a holder of a license for the sale of malt beverages, including outbuildings, shall be opened to inspection at any and all times by the sheriff. (Code 1999, § 3-6; Ord. of 9-3-1987, Part V, § 1) Sec. 4-7. - Copy of chapter to be on premises. Each holder of a license for the sale of malt beverages and/or wine shall keep a copy of this chapter on his premises and instruct any person working there with respect to its terms. Each licensee and person selling such beverages shall, at all times, be familiar with the terms of this chapter. (Code 1999, § 3-7; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part V, § 3) Sec. 4-8. - Sign posted on premises. The holder of a license for the retail sale of malt beverages and/or wine shall post in a conspicuous place in his place of business a notice with letters not less than four inches in height which shall be clearly visible to all customers entering the establishment as follows: "Sale of malt beverages to persons under the age of 21 is strictly prohibited. Warning: Drinking alcoholic beverages during pregnancy can cause birth defects." (Code 1999, § 3-8; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part VII, § 1) State Law reference— Posting of warning by retailer that consumption of alcohol during pregnancy is dangerous, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-5; posting of laws concerning sales to underage persons O.C.G.A. § 3-3-24.2. Sec. 4-9. - Minors on premises. (a) A holder of a license for on-premises consumption shall not permit a minor, i.e., a person under the age of 18, to be on or about the licensed premises. (b) It shall be unlawful for any licensee to allow or require a person in his employment under 18 years of age to dispense, serve, sell or take orders for malt beverages or wine; provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not prohibit persons under 18 years of age who are employed in supermarkets, convenience stores or drugstores from selling or handling malt beverages or wine which are sold for consumption off the premises. (Code 1999, § 3-9; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part III, § 10(c), (d)) Sec. 4-10. - Advertising by signs. Wholesale dealers or retail dealers will be allowed to advertise malt beverages by use of signs under the following conditions: (1) Only one sign will be allowed for each business establishment, which sign may be double-faced. (2) The maximum dimensions for any sign shall be four feet in height and six feet in width. (3) Lighted signs shall be permitted. (4) All signs advertising malt beverages must be located on the premises of the establishment selling malt beverages. (Code 1999, § 3-10; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part VII, § 2) Sec. 4-11. - Hours of sale. (a) No malt beverages or wine will be sold between the hours of 12:00 midnight on Saturday night until the hour of 6:00 a.m. on Monday morning. No malt beverages shall be sold between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. on any day by a holder of a license for on-premises consumption. (b) No malt beverages shall be sold on election day or any other day on which the sale of malt beverages may be prohibited by state law. An election day, for the purposes of this chapter, is hereby defined as that period of time beginning one hour prior to the opening of the polls and ending one hour after the closing of the polls. The prohibition against the sale of malt beverages to any person on election days shall apply only within the territorial boundaries for which the election is being held. (c) Malt beverages may be sold at any time not specifically prohibited in this section. (Code 1999, § 3-11; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part IV, § 1) Sec. 4-12. - Excise taxes. (a) Malt beverages. There is hereby imposed upon each wholesale dealer of malt beverages an excise tax in the amount as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80. (b) Wine. There is imposed an excise tax upon each wholesale dealer of wine by the package in the amount of $0.22 per liter and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of a liter. (c) Collection. All wholesalers and distributors of malt beverage and/or wine wholesaling and/or distributing such commodity in the county shall add the amount of tax to be collected thereon, computed as provided in this section, to the invoice of sale to any and all retailers in the county, outside any municipality located therein, and remit the amount of such tax so computed to be due to the treasury of the county direct to the commission clerk, less the sum of five percent of such tax which is hereby allowed for the collection of such tax. Such wholesalers and/or distributors shall furnish the clerk of county commissioners copies of all such invoices together with the amount of tax so collected at the time of payment of such taxes which shall be made and filed with the clerk on or before the tenth day of each and every month. The records of wholesalers and/or distributors shall be made available periodically to a duly authorized agent of the county for inspection and confirmation of the taxes collected as provided in this article. (Code 1999, § 3-12; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part III, § 12) State Law reference— Imposition of excise tax on malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80; authorization to levy tax on wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-60. Secs. 4-13—4-42. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - LICENSES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Governing authority shall set forth ascertainable standards pertaining to the granting, refusal, suspension or revocation of alcoholic beverage permits or licenses, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2.
Sec. 4-43. - Issuance prerequisite to selling alcoholic beverages. No malt beverages or wine may be sold in the county except under a license issued in accordance with this article. Such privilege shall be held and enjoyed by the licensee only so long as the licensee complies with the requirements of this article and pays all required fees and taxes. (Code 1999, § 3-41; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part III, §§ 1, 15) Sec. 4-44. - Application—Form, contents. (a) Each application for a license for the sale of malt beverages and/or wine shall be made in person at the office of the clerk of the board of commissioners and shall be accompanied by a completed form furnished for this purpose by such clerk, which application shall contain the following information: (1) Full name, address and telephone number of the applicant and whether the applicant is an individual, partnership or corporation. If the applicant is a partnership, the name and address of each partnership must be shown. (2) Location or address of the place of business at which the applicant will engage in the retail of malt beverage and/or wine business if and when permission to do so is granted by the county commission and a license is issued. (3) Each applicant shall list in his application the name, home address, home telephone number and present place of employment of the person who will be employed by him as manager of the place of business for which the license is requested. No one shall be allowed to serve in a supervisory and/or managerial position who has, within five years immediately prior to the filing of the application, entered a plea of guilty, a plea of nolo contendere, or shall have suffered any conviction of a felony or any crime involving moral turpitude or involving alcohol control laws of this state, the United States, or any other state. Thereafter, if any person other than the person listed in the application as manager shall be employed as manager, the name, address and telephone number of the new manager shall be furnished to the clerk of the board of commissioners within five days from the date of employment of the new manager. (4) Such other information as the clerk of the county commission, under the direction of the board of commissioners, may from time to time require. (b) The applicant shall set forth in detail, under oath, such information as may be required. (Code 1999, § 3-42; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part II, § 2-A) Sec. 4-45. - Same—Notice. (a) The clerk of the commission shall cause a notice to appear in the official organ of the county for two weeks, once each week, that an application for a license required by this article has been made. The notice shall contain the name of the applicant, the address or location of the premises from where the sale will occur and the date and time when the application will be considered by the commission. The notice shall not be required for the renewal of any existing license. (b) The clerk shall collect the cost of publishing a notice from the applicant at the time the application is made and before submitting the notice for publication to cover the administrative cost and cost of publication. This cost is not a part of a renewed application. (Code 1999, § 3-43; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part II, § 3) Sec. 4-46. - Applicant, owner and manager to be same person. An individual applicant for a license required by this article must be the person who owns and manages the business where the sales of malt beverages and/or wine will occur. (Code 1999, § 3-44; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part II, § 1) Sec. 4-47. - Fingerprinting. (a) At the time any application for a license required by this article is filed at the office of the clerk of the board of commissioners, and as a prerequisite to the issuance of any license under the provisions of this article, the applicant shall have a complete set of his fingerprints made by the sheriff or his designee, which shall be forwarded to the state bureau of investigation who shall search the files of the state crime information center for a period of two years immediately preceding the date of such application for any instance of criminal activity, and the state bureau of investigation shall submit such fingerprints to the Federal Bureau of Investigation under the rules established by the United States Department of Justice for processing and identification records. Such record, if any, shall be obtained and returned to the governing authorities submitting such fingerprints. (b) If the license is to be issued to a firm or corporation, fingerprints shall be made by the sheriff or his designee and forwarded for investigation as set forth in subsection (a) of this section for all persons who will serve in a supervisory and/or managerial position with respect to the sale of malt beverages.
