If the firm or corporation changes the person in such supervisory and/or managerial position during any year, and designates such functions to a person who has not previously been responsible for such functions, referred to in this section as new person, then such firm or corporation shall notify the clerk of the commissioners, in writing, of the change in such supervisory and/or managerial personnel, giving the name, address of the new person, his address, the effective date of the change and shall furnish the clerk with the fingerprints of the new person. The notification and furnishing of the fingerprints shall be within five regular business days of the commissioners. Should the fingerprints or investigation of the new person reveal that he is objectionable, the commission shall notify the licensee immediately, upon the receipt of the notice, that the new person shall not serve in such capacity with the licensee until authorized by the commissioners. The licensee may appeal such objections to the commissioners within three days of the receipt of such notice, by delivering written notice of the appeal of the clerk. As soon as possible, the commissioners will hear evidence on such appeal, but the new person shall not serve in such capacity until and unless authorized by the commissioners. (Code 1999, § 3-45; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part II, § 2-B) Sec. 4-48. - Legal status of applicant. In no event shall any license be granted to any person where any of the individuals or any of the corporate officers, directors or majority stockholders, as the case may be, have, within ten years immediately prior to the filing of the applications, entered a plea of guilty, a plea of nolo contendere, or shall have suffered any conviction of a felony or crime involving moral turpitude or involving alcohol control laws of this state, the United States, or any other state. Should any licensee, partner, officer, director or a majority stockholder of a licensed corporation, after a license has been granted, be convicted or plead guilty or nolo contendere to a felony or a crime involving moral turpitude or to a violation of any laws of the United States or of this state relating to alcohol, the licenses issued to such licensee shall stand revoked and cancelled. (Code 1999, § 3-46; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part II, § 4) Sec. 4-49. - Conditions affecting granting of license. (a) The board of commissioners shall consider any extenuating circumstances which may reflect favorably or unfavorably on an applicant for a license required by this article, the application or the proposed location of the business. If, in their judgment, circumstances are such that the granting of the license would not be in the best interest of the general public, such circumstances may be grounds for denying the application. (b) In considering an application, the commissioners shall consider the following factors before making any decision on an application: (1) Is there any statutory prohibition in the law of the state against the issuance of such a license to such person at such location? (2) Is the proposed location primarily a residential neighborhood or business neighborhood? (3) Are there schools, churches and numerous dwelling houses in the immediate vicinity of the proposed license site? (4) Are there other such malt beverage or wine licenses in the immediate neighborhood of the proposed site? (5) Would the issuance of such a license be compatible to the neighborhood as it is now constituted? (6) Would the issuance of such a license in such location tend to diminish the property values of the adjoining lands? (Code 1999, § 3-47; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part II, § 5) Sec. 4-50. - Proximity of applicant's business to churches, schools. No application for a license to sell malt beverages or wine shall be approved where the proposed location is within 1,000 feet of a church, school or college campus, or school grounds teaching subjects commonly taught in the public schools of the state. In determining compliance with this section, the distance shall be determined by measuring in a straight line from the nearest point of the school or church building to the nearest point of the building where malt beverages and/or wine are being sold, with the exception that if a school or college is involved the measurement is to be from the school playground or campus to the building. (Code 1999, § 3-48; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part II, § 6-A) State Law reference— Sales of alcoholic beverages near churches, schools or college campuses, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-21. Sec. 4-51. - Proximity of retailers where consumption occurs to occupied dwellings. No application for a license to sell malt beverages or wine which may be consumed on the premises of the sale shall be approved where the proposed location is within 500 feet of any house which is then occupied or regularly occupied. (Code 1999, § 3-49; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part II, § 6-B) Sec. 4-52. - Grandfathering in of certain premises. No application for a license required by this article or for renewal shall be denied by reason of closeness to a church, school or residence or inadequate lighting as required under the provisions of this article if a license was granted prior to June 30, 1987, in reliance on the prior county malt beverage and wine license ordinance, and the premises have remained licensed without interruption. Further, any premises licensed under this article shall not be denied for licensing by reason that a house, school or church has been erected within the prohibited distance after the licensed establishment was opened, and it continued in operation without interruption. (Code 1999, § 3-50; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part VII, § 5) Sec. 4-53. - Completion of premises, plans prerequisite to issuance. (a) Plans to be attached to application. No retail license for the sale of malt beverages or wine shall be issued to any person unless the building in which the business will be located is complete and detailed plans of such building and outside premises are attached to the application. The completed building or proposed building shall comply with this Code, regulations of the state revenue commissioner and the laws of the state. (b) Final inspection and approval of building. A proposed building shall also be subject to a final inspection and approval when completed by the appropriate county official. Where the applicant has fulfilled all qualifications other than the completion of the building, the license may be approved subject to the satisfactory completion of the building in accordance with the plans presented, with the actual issuance of the license deferred until completion of the building and final inspection by the appropriate county official. (c) Lighting required. Each building in which the business will be located shall have sufficient lighting so that the building itself and the premises on all sides with entrances of the building are readily visible at all times from the front of the street on which the building is located and all of the outside premises of such building are revealed. All parking areas around such places shall be brightly lighted by a security-type light. (d) Evidence of ownership or leasing to be attached to application. Each applicant for a retail license shall attach to his application evidence of ownership of the building or proposed building or a copy of the lease if the applicant is leasing the building. (Code 1999, § 3-51; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part II, § 6-C) Sec. 4-54. - Payment of fees, taxes required for issuance. No license shall be issued pursuant to this article unless the applicant therefor shall have fully paid all license fees and ad valorem taxes due to the county. (Code 1999, § 3-52; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part III, § 18) Sec. 4-55. - Fees—Amounts. For each license year commencing January 1 and ending December 31, there is hereby levied and imposed a special privilege and license fee in an amount annually as established by the board of county commissioners from time to time. (1) For each retail malt beverage and wine dealer applying for a license for on-premises consumption. (2) For each retail malt beverage and wine dealer applying for a license for off-premises consumption only. (3) For each wholesale dealer's license. (Code 1999, § 3-53; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part III, §§ 11, 12) Sec. 4-56. - Same—Payment. The license fees required by this article shall be paid by certified check attached to the application, initial or renewal, for the license as required by the provisions of this article. If the commission denies the application for license, the license fee shall be returned to the applicant. (Code 1999, § 3-54; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part II, § 3, part III, § 13) Sec. 4-57. - Off- or on-premises consumption—Designation generally. All licenses approved, authorized and issued under the provisions of this article shall authorize the retail sale of malt beverages and wine either for off-premises consumption only or for on-premises consumption. (Code 1999, § 3-55; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part III, § 4) Sec. 4-58. - Same—Marked on license. All licenses approved, authorized and issued on and after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived shall be plainly and conspicuously marked either "For Off-Premises Consumption Only" or "For On-Premises Consumption." (Code 1999, § 3-56; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part III, § 5) Sec. 4-59. - Same—Stores, outlets, etc. All licenses approved, authorized and issued for retail supermarkets, grocery stores, quick food outlets or other similar retail stores shall be plainly and conspicuously marked "For Off-Premises Consumption Only." (Code 1999, § 3-57; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part III, § 6) Sec. 4-60. - Same—Lounges, etc. All licenses approved, authorized and issued for malt beverage parlors, lounges or other similar establishments shall be plainly and conspicuously marked "For On-Premises Consumption." (Code 1999, § 3-58; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part III, § 7) Sec. 4-61. - Intent of licensing authority. It is the intention of the licensing authority in the adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived to prohibit the consumption of malt beverages or wine on the premises of any retail outlet under the authority of any license held under section 4-59 and to permit the consumption of any malt beverages or wine on the premises of any retail outlet under the authority of any license held under section 4-60. (Code 1999, § 3-59; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part III, § 8) Sec. 4-62. - Number of on-premises licenses restricted. In the exercise of its judgment and discretion, after giving thorough consideration to all the implications involved, and keeping always in mind the public interest and the welfare of the citizens of the county, a limitation on the total number of licenses issued for on-premises consumption is hereby established. Notwithstanding any other provisions set forth in this article for the issuance of a license for the sale of malt beverages and/or wine, there shall only be issued 11 licenses for on-premises consumption until the population of the county outside the corporate limits of the municipalities reaches 5,946, at which time such licenses shall be issued on the basis of one license per 540 persons. (Code 1999, § 3-60; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part III, § 9) Sec. 4-63. - Display. Each person holding a license issued pursuant to this article shall display the license prominently at all times on the premises for which the license is issued. (Code 1999, § 3-61; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part VII, § 6) Sec. 4-64. - Transfer; closure of business. No license for the sale of malt beverages shall be transferable, and if a licensed business is sold or closed, the licensee must immediately surrender his license to the sheriff. All licenses shall be issued to specific persons and shall be applicable to and valid with respect only to the business location referred to therein. (Code 1999, § 3-62; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part III, § 2) Sec. 4-65. - Renewal—Expiration date, application, fee; review by county attorney. (a) All licenses granted pursuant to this article shall expire on December 31 of each year. Licensees who desire to renew their license shall file an application with the required fee with the clerk of the commissioners on the form provided for the renewal of the license for the ensuing year. The county shall mail renewal notices by October 15, and applications for renewal must be filed no later than November 30 of each year; otherwise, no renewal license shall be granted but an applicant shall be required to comply with all rules and regulations for the granting of licenses as if no previous license had been held. All licenses granted shall be for the calendar year and a full license fee shall be paid for a license issued prior to July 1 of each year. One-half of the full license fee shall be paid for a license after July 1 of each year. No refund shall be made upon the revocation or suspension of any license. (b) The county attorney is hereby designated and granted the authority and duty to review the applications for renewal of malt beverages and wine licenses. Upon the review of such license applications, if the designee finds that there has been no change from the previous year of the requirements of the malt beverages and wine sale and this article, then the attorney or his designee is directed to reissue the license for the following year. If changes have been made, the license renewal application is to be denied. (Code 1999, § 3-63; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part III, §§ 3, 19; Ord. of 12-3-1998) Sec. 4-66. - Same—Denial due to adverse conditions. Should the holder of a license required by this article carry on his business in such a way that the conduct of that business creates a continuing public disturbance, traffic congestion and/or obnoxious loud noises, his license will be given careful review by the commission upon application for renewal. If the commission finds there has been just and substantial complaints made with or by the sheriff, the licensee shall be warned and informed to eliminate the adverse conditions existing on, at or around the licensed premises. After warning, should the licensee fail to eliminate the adverse conditions, the commission will be authorized to refuse to renew a license to such licensee and/or to such licensed premises. (Code 1999, § 3-64; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part VII, § 7) Sec. 4-67. - Violations—Confiscation of license; right to hearing. (a) The sheriff or his lawful deputies shall be authorized, if at any time the holder of a license for the sale of malt beverages and wine shall be found in violation of this chapter or in violation of any of the state and federal laws or regulations, to pick up the license and present to the clerk of the board of commissioners with a written report stating the violation. (b) The licensee shall have the right to call for a hearing within ten days or such other time as the commissioners shall designate. Should a hearing be so called for, such hearing must be held within 72 hours of requesting it, exclusive of Sundays. If a hearing is not held within such time, then the license shall be returned until further action by the commission. (c) The owner or employees shall cease to sell malt beverages and wine until the matter is concluded. (Code 1999, § 3-66; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part VI, § 2-B) Sec. 4-68. - Same—Temporary suspension. A license for the sale of malt beverages and wine may be temporarily suspended, and the place of business closed if the license is for on-premises consumption, upon receipt of evidence by the board of commissioners from the sheriff of any violation referred to in this chapter. (Code 1999, § 3-67; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part VI, § 2-A) Sec. 4-69. - Same—Penalties. (a) Any license for the sale of malt beverages and wine may be suspended for a definite length of time, revoked and/or personal performance bond posted by the licensee forfeited in whole or in part. (b) No license shall be revoked and no bond shall be forfeited unless the licensee has been given at least three days' written notice, in person or by registered mail, of the intention of the board of commissioners to take such action. Such notice shall specify the time, place and purposes of the hearing and a statement of the charges upon which the commissioners propose to take action. At such hearings conducted by the commissioners, the licensee shall have the right to appear in person and by attorney, and the sheriff, county attorney or the commissioners, and the licensee shall have the right to present evidence relating to the question as to whether or not a violation, as set forth in this chapter, has occurred, as well as evidence relating to any extenuating or mitigating circumstances. (c) After consideration of such evidence, the commissioners shall, by a majority, determine whether the license shall be revoked and whether the personal performance bond shall be forfeited or whether the license shall be suspended for a definite length of time not to exceed one-half of the remaining license year. (Code 1999, § 3-68; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part VI, §§ 3—5) Sec. 4-70. - Same—Grounds for revocation. (a) Violations generally. The performance of any act prohibited by this chapter or the failure to perform any act required by this chapter, as well as the violation of any law, state or federal, relating to the sale of malt beverages and wine shall constitute grounds for revocation of a license and for the refusal thereafter to issue again any license to a violator under this article. (b) False information. The making of any statement on an application for a license to sell malt beverages and wine which shall be later found to be false shall constitute grounds for revocation of the license. (Code 1999, § 3-69; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part III, §§ 16, 17, part VI, § 1) Sec. 4-71. - Same—Disposal of merchandise in lieu of hearing. If the licensee does not desire a hearing as specified in section 4-67 before the board of commissioners or fails to appear, the sheriff shall be authorized to then permit the owner to dispose of the merchandise within a ten-day period, to be designated by the sheriff and under his supervision. Such merchandise may not be sold except in bulk only. (Code 1999, § 3-70; Ord. of 9-3-1987, part VI, § 6)

div.head: Chapter 6 - ANIMALS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Authority to exercise animal control, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(3); dogs generally, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-1 et seq.; Georgia Animal Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq.; rabies control and licensing of animals by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 6-1. - Dog control officer. (a) Appointment; compensation. The board of commissioners shall appoint a dog control officer who shall serve at the pleasure of the board of commissioners and whose compensation shall be established from time to time by the board of commissioners. (b) Duty to investigate reports. The dog control officer, upon receiving a report of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within the county from a law enforcement agency, animal control agency, rabies control officer or the county board of health, shall make such investigations and inquiries with regard to such report as may be necessary to determine the validity of such report and whether the dog should be classified as a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog or reclassified as a dangerous dog if previously classified as a potentially dangerous dog. (c) Classifying dog; notifying owner. Should the dog control officer determine that a dog is a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog, the officer shall classify such dog accordingly and he shall notify the dog's owner, in writing by certified mail to the owner's last known address, of such classification or reclassification. Such notice shall be complete upon its mailing. (Code 1999, § 4-40; Ord. of 7-6-1989, § 3) Secs. 6-2—6-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - DOGS[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Dogfighting prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-37.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 6-21—6-43. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - DANGEROUS DOGS[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- Editor's note— Forms for the dog classification notice and certificate of registration of dogs are on file in the office of the clerk of the board of county commissioners. State Law reference— Dangerous Dog Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.; Georgia Animal Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq.; liability of owner or keeper of vicious or dangerous animal for injuries caused by animal, O.C.G.A. § 51-2-6.
Sec. 6-44. - Intent of division; liability. It is the intention of this article to adopt the minimum standards and requirements for the control of dangerous dogs and potentially dangerous dogs in compliance with the dangerous dog control law (see O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.). Therefore, as stated by the general assembly of the state, the owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall be solely liable for any injury to or death caused by such dog. Under no circumstances shall the county or any employee or official of the county which enforces or fails to enforce the provisions of the law or this division shall be held liable for any damages to any person who suffers an injury inflicted by: (1) A dog that has been identified as being a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog; (2) A dog that has been reported to the proper authority as being a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog; (3) A dog that the county has failed to identify as a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog; (4) A dog which has been identified as being a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog but has not been kept or restrained in the manner prescribed by law; or (5) A dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog whose owner has not maintained insurance coverage or a surety bond as required by law. (Code 1999, § 4-36; Ord. of 7-6-1989, § 7) Sec. 6-45. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Dangerous dog means any dog that, according to the records of an appropriate authority: (1) Causes a substantial puncture of a person's skin by teeth without causing serious injury; provided, however, that a nip, scratch or abrasion shall not be sufficient to classify a dog as dangerous under this definition; (2) Aggressively attacks in a manner that causes a person to reasonably believe that the dog posed an imminent threat of serious injury to such person or another person although no such injury occurs; provided, however, that the acts of barking, growling or showing of teeth by a dog shall not be sufficient to classify a dog as dangerous under this definition; or (3) While off the owner's property, kills a pet animal; provided, however, that this definition shall not apply where the death of such pet animal is caused by a dog that is working or training as a hunting dog, herding dog or predator control dog. Dog control officer means an individual selected by the board of commissioners pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 4-8-22(c) to aid the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this division and other related laws of the state. Owner means any natural person or any legal entity, including, but not limited to, a corporation, partnership, firm or trust owning, possessing, harboring, keeping or having custody or control of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within this county. Potentially dangerous dog means: (1) Any dog that, without provocation, bites a human being on public or private property; (2) Any dog that, without provocation, and while not present on real property owned by such dog's owner, acts in an aggressive or menacing manner towards any human being so that a reasonable person would be placed in apprehension of receiving bodily injury; and (3) Any dog that enters on the real property of any person, other than the owner of the subject dog, and aggressively attacks and injures any domesticated animal kept thereupon. Proper enclosure means an enclosure for keeping a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog, while on the owner's property, securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked pen, fence or structure suitable to prevent the entry of young children and designed to prevent the dog from escaping. Any such pen or structure shall have secure sides and a secure top, and, if the dog is enclosed within a fence, all sides of the fence shall be of sufficient height and the bottom of the fence shall be constructed or secured in such a manner as to prevent the dog's escape either from over or from under the fence. Any such enclosure shall also provide protection from the elements for the dog. Records of an appropriate authority means: (1) Records of any state, county, or municipal law enforcement agency; (2) Records of any county or municipal animal control agency; (3) Records of any county board of health; (4) Records of any federal, state or local court; and (5) Records of any dog control officer; as provided for in this division and by the laws of the state. Severe injury or serious injury means any physical injury that creates a substantial risk of death; results in death, broken or dislocated bones, lacerations requiring multiple sutures or disfiguring avulsions, requires plastic surgery or admission to a hospital or results in protracted impairment of health, including transmission of an infection or contagious disease, or impairment of the function of any bodily organ. (Code 1999, § 4-37; Ord. of 7-6-1989, § 1(a); Ord. of 8-7-2008, §§ (1), (2)) Sec. 6-46. - Conditions exempting dogs. A dog shall not be a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog if: (1) The dog inflicts an injury upon a person when the dog is being used by a law enforcement officer to carry out the law enforcement officer's official duties. (2) Any injury inflicted by the dog was sustained by a person who, at the time, was committing a willful trespass or other tort, was tormenting, abusing or assaulting the dog or had in the past been observed or reported to have tormented, abused or assaulted the dog, or was committing or attempting to commit a crime. (Code 1999, § 4-38; Ord. of 7-6-1989, § 1(b)) Sec. 6-47. - Classification. In classifying or reclassifying dangerous dogs or potentially dangerous dogs, the dog control officer must comply with procedure for classification set forth in O.C.G.A. § 4-8-23 and the procedure is incorporated in this division as if fully set out in this section. (Code 1999, § 4-41; Ord. of 7-6-1989, § 4) Sec. 6-48. - Requirements for possession. (a) No person shall have or possess within the county a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog without a certificate of registration issued in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 4-8-27 and the provisions thereof are incorporated in this division as if fully set forth in this section. (b) The owner of each dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall pay an annual registration fee at the time of the issuance of the annual certificate of registration. The annual registration fee for a potentially dangerous dog and for a dangerous dog are set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. Registrations shall be renewed in the month of the initial registration. (c) The dog control officer shall require evidence from the owner or make such investigation as may be necessary to verify that the dangerous dog or the potentially dangerous dog is confined or continuing to be confined in a proper enclosure and that the owner is in compliance with, or continues to be in compliance with, the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 4-8-27(b) and (c). (d) The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the dog control officer if he is moving from the county. The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog who is a new resident of the county shall register the dog as required by this division and the dangerous dog control law of the state within 30 days after becoming a resident. (e) The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the dog control officer within 24 hours if the dog is on the loose, unconfined, has attacked a human, has died or has been sold or donated. If the dog has been sold or donated, the owner shall provide the dog control officer with the name, address and telephone number of the new owner of the dog. (f) The issuance of a certificate of registration or the renewal of a certificate of registration by the county does not warrant or guarantee that the requirements specified in O.C.G.A. § 4-8-27(b) and (c) are maintained by the owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog on a continuous basis following the date of the issuance of the initial certificate of registration or following the date of any annual renewal of such certificate. (Code 1999, § 4-42; Ord. of 7-6-1989, § 5) Sec. 6-49. - Confiscation of dogs and the disposition thereof. (a) A dangerous dog shall be immediately confiscated by the dog control officer, by a law enforcement officer or by another person authorized by the dog control officer if the: (1) Owner of the dog does not secure liability or bond as required by O.C.G.A. § 4-8-27(c); (2) Dog is not validly registered as required by this division; (3) Dog is not maintained in a proper enclosure; or (4) Dog is outside a proper enclosure in violation of state law. (b) A potentially dangerous dog shall be confiscated in the same manner as a dangerous dog if the dog is: (1) Not validly registered, as required by this division and O.C.G.A. § 4-8-25; (2) Not maintained in a proper enclosure; or (3) Outside a proper enclosure in violation of state law. (c) Any dog that has been confiscated pursuant to the provisions of this section shall be returned to its owner upon the owner's compliance with the provisions of this division and O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq., and upon the payment of the cost of confiscation. If the owner has not complied with the provisions of this section within 20 days of the date the dog was confiscated, such dog shall be destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner. (d) When a dog is classified by the county animal control officer or any law enforcement agent with the power to effect arrest in the county to be a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog and no person comes forward as owner of such dog and no owner, as defined by section 6-45, is otherwise readily apparent: (1) Such dog shall be confiscated; (2) Notice of such confiscation shall be given to all putative owners of the subject dangerous or potentially dangerous dog by posting a description of the same with a statement requiring all persons claiming the subject dog to contact the animal control officer within ten days of the date of the notice or the subject dog will be destroyed; (3) The requisite notice shall be posted in the county courthouse in the place of posting public notices; and (4) If no person claims any dog confiscated under this subsection or presents themselves within ten days of the posting the requisite notice, the subject dog shall be destroyed in a humane manner. (Code 1999, § 4-43; Ord. of 7-6-1989, § 6; Ord. of 8-7-2008, § (3)) Sec. 6-50. - Vicious dogs. (a) Any dog that has attacked and bitten a person or other animal without provocation or has attempted to bite a person or other animal without provocation shall be deemed a vicious dog. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, permit, accompany or be responsible for the presence of any vicious dog in public places of the county or allow the dog to run on the premises of another, at any time; unless the dog shall be securely muzzled to effectively prevent it from biting any person or other animal. (c) Any person violating this section may be punished as provided in section 1-13 of part II of this Code. (Ord. No. 10 of 2016, 8-4-2016)

div.head: Chapter 8 - BUSINESSES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Local taxes and fees, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV, ¶ I; limitation on expanding the power of municipal regulation over any business activity regulated by the public service commission, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(5);
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 8-1—8-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Peddlers and itinerant traders, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-1 et seq.; exception from local peddler or itinerant vendor licensing requirements for persons selling agricultural products, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-6; transient merchants, O.C.G.A. § 43-46-1 et seq.
Sec. 8-21. - License required. It shall be unlawful for a transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor to engage in such business within the legal limits of the county and outside of the legal limits of any municipality therein without first obtaining a license therefor in compliance with the provisions of this article. (Ord. of 7-3-1973, § 101) Sec. 8-22. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor means any person, firm or corporation, whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, whether a resident of the county or not, who engages in the temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares and merchandise, including the sale of pecans either in bulk or by the bag, and who, in furtherance of such purpose, uses or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, wagon, roadside stand, tent, boat, railroad boxcar, public room in hotels, lodginghouses, apartments, shops, or any public street, road, alley, park or any other public place within the county, or any property adjacent thereto, for exhibition and sale of goods, wares and merchandise, including pecans. The person, firm or corporation so engaged shall not be relieved from complying with the provisions of this article by reason of associating temporarily with any established dealer, trader or merchant having a license for a fixed place of business. (Ord. of 7-3-1973, § 102) Sec. 8-23. - Application. Applicants for license under this article, whether a person, firm or corporation, shall file a written application signed by the applicant with the county clerk showing: (1) The name or names of the person or persons having the management or supervision of applicant's business during the time that it is proposed that it will be carried on in the county; (2) The local address or addresses of such person or persons while engaged in such business; (3) The permanent address or addresses of such person or persons; (4) The capacity in which such person or persons will act, that is, whether as proprietor, agent or otherwise; (5) The name and address of the person, firm or corporation for whose account the business will be carried on, if any; and if a corporation under the laws of what state the same is incorporated; (6) The place or places in the county where it is proposed to carry on applicant's business and the length of time during which it is proposed that said business shall be conducted; (7) A statement of the nature, character and quality of the goods, wares or merchandise to be sold or offered for sale by applicant in the county; (8) Such other reasonable information as to the identity or character of the person or persons having the management or supervision of applicant's business or the method or plan of doing such business in the county as may be required by the board of commissioners in order to fulfill the purpose of this article in the protection of the public good and general welfare. (Ord. of 7-3-1973, § 103) Sec. 8-24. - Investigation and issuance. Upon receipt of such application the county clerk shall cause an investigation to be made of such person's business responsibility or moral character as he or she deems necessary to the protection of the public good and a report thereof together with the application presented at the next regular meeting of the board of commissioners for consideration and approval or rejection. (Ord. of 7-3-1973, § 104) Sec. 8-25. - Fees. Licensees under this article shall pay an annual license fee or tax in an amount per year or any part thereof, based on the county fiscal year beginning July 1 and ending midnight of June 30, as established by the board of county commissioners from time to time, provided, however, that the applicant is a legal resident of and living in the county. If the applicant is not a legal resident of and is not living in the county the licensee shall pay an annual license fee or tax in an amount as established by the board of county commissioners from time to time. (Ord. of 7-3-1973, § 105 Sec. 8-26. - Duty of sheriff to enforce. It shall be the duty of the sheriff and his lawful deputies to examine all places of business and persons subject to the provisions of this article to determine if this article has been complied with and to enforce the provisions of this article against any person found to be violating the same and the violation of this article is hereby declared to constitute a misdemeanor. (Ord. of 7-3-1973, § 106) Secs. 8-27—8-41. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - SOLICITATION
Sec. 8-42. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Solicitation activities means the practice of solicitors as listed in subsections (1) and (2) of the term "solicitor." Solicitor means any person, whether a resident of the county or not, including an employee or agent of another, traveling either by foot, automobile, truck or some other type or form of conveyance, who engages in the practice of going door-to-door, house-to-house or along any streets within the county. (1) Selling or taking orders for, or offering to sell or take orders for, goods, merchandise, wares or other items of value for immediate delivery or future delivery, or services to be performed immediately or in the future, for commercial purposes; or (2) Requesting contribution of funds, property or anything of value, or the pledge of any type of future donation, or selling, or offering for sale, any type of property, including, but not limited to, goods, tickets, books and pamphlets for political, charitable, religious or other noncommercial purposes. (Ord. of 5-4-2006, § 1) Sec. 8-43. - License required. It shall be unlawful for any solicitor to engage in solicitation activities in the county without first obtaining a license from the county. (Ord. of 5-4-2006, § 2) Sec. 8-44. - Exemptions. (a) Ordinary commercial vendors who sell to local markets, organizations that have a local presence, minors under the age of 18 who participate in solicitation activities for school and youth-related purposes are exempt from licensing of this article except when they are acting as agents of adults covered by this article. (b) Any solicitation activity exempted as a result of state statutes. (Ord. of 5-4-2006, § 3) Sec. 8-45. - Application. The application for a solicitor's license shall contain all information relevant and necessary to determine whether a particular license may be issued, including, but not limited to: (1) Proof of the identity and residence address of the applicant; (2) A brief description of the nature, character and quality of the goods or merchandise to be sold; and (3) If the solicitor is employed by another, the name and business address of such person, firm, association, organization, company or corporation. (Ord. of 5-4-2006, § 4) Sec. 8-46. - Licenses and identification badges. (a) The permit issued to a solicitor shall not be transferable and shall be carried with the solicitor while he is engaged in the business of soliciting. A license and identification badge shall be used only by the person to whom they were issued. (b) In addition to the license, the county shall issue an identification badge to every solicitor. Solicitors shall wear badges in such a way that the badge may be easily read while doing business. If a badge becomes damaged or obscured, the solicitor shall return it to the county and receive a replacement. (Ord. of 5-4-2006, § 5) Sec. 8-47. - Fees and duration. (a) Each non-exempt individual to engage in solicitation activities in the county shall be required to make application for and receive the requisite solicitor's license prior to engaging in such activity. (b) Possession of the requisite license shall entitle the licensed individual to obtain a solicitation permit; possession of a solicitation permit shall be required prior to engaging in covered activities and failure to obtain the required permit shall be held a violation of this article. (c) Application for a solicitor's license shall be accompanied by an application fee in an amount as established by the board of county commissioners from time to time. A solicitor's license shall be valid for one year from the date of issuance. (d) Application for a solicitor's permit shall be accompanied by a permit fee in an amount as established by the board of county commissioners from time to time, and shall be valid for a period of seven days from the date of issuance. (e) Failure to possess the requisite license and/or valid permit as required hereby on the person of any individual engaged in solicitation activities shall be held as a violation of this article. (Ord. of 5-4-2006, § 6; Ord. of 12-6-2007, § 6) Sec. 8-48. - Regulations. The following regulations apply to solicitors engaged in solicitation activities in the county: (1) Solicitors shall be allowed to conduct solicitation activities only between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m., or sunset, which ever comes first. (2) No solicitor shall engage in solicitation activities regulated under this article on county property without first procuring special authorization from the county manager. Such authorization shall be withheld only when failure to do so would harm a compelling interest to the county. (3) No person shall engage in business as a solicitor in defiance of any notice exhibited by a residence or business indicating that solicitors are not welcome or not invited. (Ord. of 5-4-2006, § 7) Sec. 8-49. - Suspension or revocation of license. (a) Any license issued under this article may be suspended or revoked by the county manager for any of the following reasons: (1) Fraud or misrepresentation in the application for a license; (2) Fraud or misrepresentation in the course of conducting solicitation activities; (3) Conducting solicitation activities contrary to the conditions of the license; or (4) Conducting solicitation activities in such a manner as to create a public nuisance or constitute a danger to public health, safety or general welfare. (b) Upon suspension or revocation, the county manager shall deliver written notice to the license holder stating the action taken and the reasons supporting such action. The written notice shall be delivered to the license holder or his place of business or mailed to the license holder's last known address. (Ord. of 5-4-2006, § 8) Sec. 8-50. - Appeals. Persons who are denied licenses or whose license have been suspended or revoked, may appeal by filing a written notice of appeal with the county. The appeal must be filed within ten days after receipt of the notice of denial, suspension or revocation. The county commissioners shall hear and determine the appeal and the decision of the commissioners shall be final. (Ord. of 5-4-2006, § 9) Sec. 8-51. - Renewals. Licenses may be renewed, provided an application for renewal and license fees are received by the county commissioners clerk no later than the expiration date of the current license. Applications received after that date shall be processed as new applications. The county manager shall review each application for renewal to determine that the applicant is in full compliance with the provisions of the article. If the county manager finds that the application meets such requirements, the county shall issue a new license. (Ord. of 5-4-2006, § 10) Secs. 8-52—8-77. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT ESTABLISHMENT[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Governing authority has power to enact legislation to restrict operation of adult bookstores, explicit media outlets, and adult movie houses to areas zoned for commercial or industrial purposes, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-3; establishment, maintenance or use of building, structure or place for unlawful sexual purposes, O.C.G.A. § 41-3-1.
Sec. 8-78. - Purpose. The purpose of this article is to regulate certain types of businesses to the end that the many types of criminal activities frequently engendered by such businesses and the adverse affect on property values and on the public health, safety and welfare of the county, and on its citizens and property, and on the character of its neighborhoods and development will be curtailed. This article is intended to represent a balancing or competing interests: reduced criminal activity and protection of the neighborhoods and development through the regulation of adult entertainment establishments versus any legally protected rights of adult entertainment establishments and patrons. This article is not intended to allow or license any business, establishment or activity which would otherwise be unlawful. (Code 1999, § 6-66; Ord. of 6-6-1996, § 1) Sec. 8-79. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Adult entertainment establishment means the premises on which defined establishments operate or on which defined activities occur. Adult business means: (1) Any business or establishment to which the public or any portion thereof is permitted which is conducted exclusively for the patronage of adults and as to which minors are specifically excluded from patronage thereat either by law or by the operators of such business or establishment; (2) Any business or establishment to which the public or any portion thereof is permitted where employees or patrons expose specified anatomical areas or engage in specified sexual activities; or (3) Any other business or establishment to which the public or any portion thereof is permitted which offers its patrons services or entertainment characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing, discussing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. Church means a place where persons regularly assemble for religious worship. Conviction means adjudication of guilt, plea of guilty, plea of nolo contendere or the forfeiture of a bond when charged with a crime, but does not include a discharge under provisions of what is commonly called the State of Georgia First Offender Act (O.C.G.A. § 42-8-60 et seq.). Distance and measurement means the measurement in lineal feet from the center of any door of customer entry of the proposed premises of an adult entertainment establishment (or if not on ground level, then the beginning point for measuring the distance shall be the point of ground level determined by measuring from the center of any door of customer entry perpendicular to the ground level) to the nearest property line of any church, library, school, college, public park, residence, or hospital. A radius shall be measured from the center of any door of customer entry of the proposed premises to the nearest property line of any church, library, school, college, public park, residence or hospital. Employee means any person engaged to provide or in fact providing services for an adult entertainment establishment to patrons on a regular basis whether for legal consideration or otherwise. Independent contractors, such as entertainers, shall be considered an employee. Good moral character means a person has not been convicted of a felony, any crime not a felony if it involves moral turpitude or a drug related, alcohol related or sex related crime in the past ten years. Lingerie modeling studio means a business or establishment to which the public or any portion thereof is permitted whose primary business activity consists of persons exhibiting or modeling lingerie or similar undergarments and characterized or distinguished by an emphasis on specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. Minor means any person who has not attained the age of 18 years. Park means any lands or facility owned, operated, controlled or managed by a county, city, state or federal government or any governmental entity or agency in and upon which recreational activities or places are provided for the recreation and enjoyment of the general public. Residence means a house, apartment, mobile home, boardinghouse or roominghouse, duplex or other multifamily housing, for human dwelling, or any properties owned therefor. School means state, county, city, church or other schools, public or private, that teach the subjects commonly taught in the common schools of this state, and vocational schools, colleges, post high school learning centers, kindergartens and day care centers for persons of all ages. Specified anatomical areas includes the following: (1) Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals, pubic region or anus; or female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola; or (2) Human male genitalia in a discernible turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. Specified sexual activities includes any of the following: (1) Actual or simulated sexual intercourse, oral copulation, anal intercourse, oral-anal copulation, bestiality, direct physical stimulation of unclothed genitals, flagellation or torture in the context of a sexual relationship, or the use of excretory functions in the context of a sexual relationship, and any and all of the following sexually oriented acts or conduct: sodomy, cunnilingus, fellation, lesbianism, homosexuality; (2) Clearly depicted human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation, arousal or tumescence; (3) Use of human or animal ejaculation, sodomy, oral copulation, coitus or masturbation; (4) Fondling of the human genitals, pubic region, buttocks or female breast so as to arouse or excite the sexual desires of the partner; (5) Sexually oriented torture; or (6) Fondling or other sexual contact with an animal so as to arouse or excite the sexual desires of a partner. (Code 1999, § 6-67; Ord. of 6-6-1996, § 2) Sec. 8-80. - Regulations. The following regulations apply to all adult entertainment establishments as described in this article and located within the unincorporated areas of the county: (1) It shall be unlawful for a licensee to employ, admit or permit the admission of minors within a licensed premises. (2) It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, barter or give to any minor any service, material, device or thing sold or offered for sale by an adult entertainment establishment. (3) No adult entertainment establishment shall be located within the following distances as defined and measured as stated in this section: a. Within 1,000 feet of any single-family or multifamily residence, or within 1,000 feet of any parcel of land which is zoned for single or multifamily uses or purposes; b. Within 1,000 feet of a church, school, governmentally owned or operated building, library, civic center, public park, hospital, nursing home or community club; c. Within 1,000 feet of another adult entertainment establishment; or d. Within 1,000 feet of an establishment selling alcoholic beverages. Notwithstanding the provisions of subsections (3)a through (3)d of this section, an adult entertainment establishment operating in an unincorporated area of the county on the date of the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall not be required to meet the distance requirements as they pertain to such location for so long as the licensee holds a legally recognized and perfected property right to use and possess such location as of the date of filing of an application for adult entertainment license or renewal thereof, but only if such legal right as to such location was vested at the time of the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived, and such vested legal right has continued without the necessity of act or consent to renew, continue or extend such applicant's property right by applicant or other party holding a superior legal property right in such location. (4) No adult entertainment establishment licensee shall employ or contract with any person to provide services or perform in such establishment who is a person not permitted for employment pursuant to this article. (5) An adult entertainment establishment licensee shall maintain and retain for a period of two years the names, addresses, dates of birth and social security numbers of all employees. (6) An adult entertainment establishment shall be closed between 12:00 midnight and 8:00 a.m. Monday through Saturday, on Sunday and on Christmas Day. (7) No booth, screen, partition or other obstruction shall be permitted within the interior of any adult entertainment establishment so as to prevent a clear view throughout the premises, except for separate offices, kitchens, restrooms or the areas not frequented by patrons. (8) No premises for an adult entertainment establishment shall have any interior connections or doors with any other place of business. (9) No adult entertainment establishment shall be operated so that the activity on the interior of the premises is visible from the exterior of the premises. (10) No licensee shall permit the use of alcoholic beverages of any kind to be sold, possessed or consumed in or on the premises. (11) No licensee shall permit the use of illegal drugs or illegally controlled substances of any kind to be allowed, permitted, used, possessed or sold, and no gambling shall be allowed or permitted in or on the premises. (12) No licensee shall permit an employee to expose for public view his specified anatomical areas in a lewd and obscene fashion. (Code 1999, § 6-68; Ord. of 6-6-1996, § 3) Sec. 8-81. - Additional regulations applicable to adult dancing establishments, erotic entertainment/dance establishments and lingerie modeling studios. The following additional regulations apply to adult dancing establishments, erotic entertainment/dance establishments and lingerie modeling studios (herein referred to as adult dance establishments) as described in this section: (1) All live dancing and entertainment shall occur on a platform intended for that purpose which is raised at least two feet from the next highest level of the remainder of the floor. (2) No live dancing or entertaining shall occur closer than ten feet from any patron. (3) No dancer, entertainer or employee shall fondle or caress any patron and no patron shall fondle or caress any dancer, entertainer or employee, so as to arouse or excite the sexual desires of a patron. (4) No patron shall directly pay or give any gratuity to any dancer or entertainer. (5) No dancer or entertainer shall solicit or accept any pay or gratuity directly from any patron nor shall any patron pay or give any gratuity to any dancer or entertainer. (6) All areas of the licensed premises shall be fully lighted at all times when open for business, which shall mean illumination equal to 3.5 footcandles per square foot. (7) No licensee shall permit any employee to use artificial devices or inanimate objects to depict any of the prohibited activities described in this article. (8) No licensee shall permit an employee to insert an object into their vagina or their anal orifice, except for personal hygiene or necessity. (9) No licensee shall permit an employee to engage in actual or simulated genital masturbation. (10) No licensee shall permit a male employee to exhibit an unclothed erect penis. (11) No licensee shall permit an employee to engage in or simulate bestiality. (12) No licensee shall permit an employee to engage in actual or simulated sexual activity with any other person. (13) No licensee shall permit an employee to sit upon or straddle the leg, legs, lap or body of any patron, or to engage in or simulate sexual activity while touching or being touched by any patron. (14) No licensee shall permit or allow upon the licensed premises a patron to participate in any act or activity which an employee is prohibited from performing. (Code 1999, § 6-69; Ord. of 6-6-1996, § 4) Sec. 8-82. - License required. It shall be unlawful for any person or legal entity to engage in, conduct or carry on, in or upon any premises within the unincorporated area of the county, any of the adult entertainment establishments defined in this article, without a license to do so. No license so issued shall condone or make legal any activity thereunder if the license is deemed illegal or unlawful under the laws of this state or the United States. (Code 1999, § 6-70; Ord. of 6-6-1996, § 5) Sec. 8-83. - Operation of unlicensed premises unlawful. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate an adult entertainment establishment unless such business shall have a currently valid license or shall have made proper application for renewal within the time required under this article, which license shall not be under suspension or permanently or conditionally revoked. (Code 1999, § 6-71; Ord. of 6-6-1996, § 6) Sec. 8-84. - Application for license. (a) For purposes of this section, the term "managing capacity" means the president or chief executive officer or managing or general partner of a corporation or partnership, or a person who has responsibility for management of the operations at the location to be licensed and who is a full-time employee of the corporation, partnership, proprietor or other ownership entity. (b) Any person or legal entity desiring to obtain a license to operate, engage in, conduct or carry on any adult entertainment establishment shall make an application to the board of commissioners. Prior to submitting such application, a nonrefundable fee, established by resolution of the county, shall be paid to the clerk of the county to defray, in part, the cost of investigation and report required by this article. Such fee shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. (c) The application for license does not authorize the engaging in, operation of, conduct of or carrying on of any adult entertainment establishment. (d) All licenses required in this section shall be a mere grant of privilege to carry on such business during the term of the license subject to all the terms and conditions imposed by this article and related laws, applicable provisions of this article and other ordinances and resolutions of the county relating to such business. (e) All licenses required in this section shall have printed on the front these words: "This license is a mere privilege subject to be suspended and revoked under the provisions of the Ordinances of Charlton County." (f) A separate license shall be required for each place of business. (g) Where the applicant: (1) Is a corporation, any license shall be applied for by, and shall be issued to, the corporation and either the majority shareholder thereof, or a person employed full-time in a managing capacity by the corporation. (2) Is a partnership, any license shall be applied for by, and shall be issued to, the partnership and either the managing general partner thereof or a person employed full-time in a managing capacity by the partnership. (3) Is a sole proprietor, any license shall be applied for by, and shall be issued to, the sole proprietor if he is working full-time in a managing capacity on the premises; and, if not, then to the sole proprietor and a person employed full-time in a managing capacity by the sole proprietor. (Code 1999, § 6-72; Ord. of 6-6-1996, § 7) Sec. 8-85. - Application contents; supporting documents. (a) Each application for an adult entertainment establishment license shall contain the following: (1) Application for licenses shall be written and on forms supplied by the office of the board of commissioners of the county. Such application shall state the name, address, social security number and date of birth of the applicant, and the nature and character of the business to be carried on. (2) If the applicant is a corporation, the name of the corporation shall be set forth exactly as shown in its articles of incorporation or charter, together with the state and date of incorporation, the social security numbers of each of its current officers and directors, as well as all stockholders holding more than five percent of the outstanding shares of the corporation. If the applicant is a partnership, whether general or limited, the applicant shall set forth the names, residence addresses, dates of birth and social security numbers of the partners. If one or more of the partners is a corporation, the provisions of this subsection pertaining to corporations shall apply. (3) The address of the premises to be licensed. (4) The name of the owner of the premises and, if leased, a copy of the lease agreement. (5) A plat, filed in triplicate, by a registered land surveyor, licensed by the state, showing the location of the proposed premises is not inconsistent with the provisions contained in section 8-80(3) which provide that no adult entertainment establishment shall be located: a. Within 1,000 feet of any residential premises, parcel of land which is zoned for multifamily or single-family use or purposes; b. Within 1,000 feet of any parcel of land upon which a church, school, governmental building simultaneously owned and occupied by such government, library, civic center, neighborhood public park or neighborhood playground is located; c. Within 1,000 feet of any parcel upon which another establishment regulated or defined hereunder is located; or d. Within 1,000 feet of any establishment selling alcoholic beverages. (6) The name, address, social security number and date of birth of any and all persons who have a financial interest of any type in the entity which is applying for the license. (7) Any other information reasonably required by the county code department in verifying the right of the applicant to obtain a license. (b) Should the requirements of this article dictate that more than one individual and/or entity apply for a license issued to such applicants, then all such applicants shall, on such application, designate the name, address and telephone number of an individual county resident to act as agent for all applicants/licensees for the purpose of receiving communications and notices under this article. Proof of delivery to such agent shall be conclusive proof of receipt by a licensee of such notice, process or information. (c) Each application must be complete in its entirety before being accepted by the county for filing and processing. (d) All applicants for licenses as to any premises which is to be subsequently renovated or improved shall furnish, in triplicate, plans and renderings of the premises as it is to exist at the time of opening. Any premises to be constructed or renovated prior to opening shall be constructed, renovated or built so as to be equal to and compatible with the surrounding neighborhood or better. The premises shall comply with all building, health and similar county codes. (e) Each application for an adult entertainment establishment license shall be verified and acknowledged under oath to be true and correct by: (1) If the applicant is an individual, the individual. (2) If a partnership, the manager or general partner. (3) If a corporation, the president of the corporation. (4) If any other organization or association, the chief administrative official. (Code 1999, § 6-73; Ord. of 6-6-1996, § 8) Sec. 8-86. - Notice of intent to engage in business. (a) Purpose and publication of notice. All applicants for licenses under this article shall give notice that the application has been filed and of the purpose of making such application by publication of an advertisement once a week for four consecutive weeks prior to the date of consideration of the application by the board of commissioners in the newspaper in which legal advertisements are published. The first advertisement shall not appear more than 40 days prior to the date of such consideration. The advertisement shall be of type not smaller than ten point capital and lower case and shall be at least a two-inch column. The advertisement shall appear on the same days as legal advertisements are regularly published, but not among the generally published legal ads. (b) Information on proposed business. The notice shall contain a particular description of the location of the proposed business, the name of the applicant, the date, time and place of hearing, and a statement that any legal objections to the issuance must be made at or prior to the time of hearing, and, if prior to the time of hearing, must be in writing and received by the office of the board of commissioners on or before the date and time of hearing. (c) Proof of publication. Applicants shall provide proof of such notice by providing the board of commissioners at the time of the hearing on license issuance the affidavit of the publisher of the newspaper in which the notice was published, which affidavit shall reflect the content of the notice and the dates of publishing. (d) Signs. (1) The applicant shall cause to be placed upon the location of the proposed business a sign stating the following: "Charlton County Adult Entertainment License Applied For. A hearing before the Board of Commissioners of Charlton County shall be held on the ____________ day of ____________ / ____________ / ____________ , 20 ____________ . All interested persons take notice." (2) The sign shall be at least 18 inches by 24 inches in size and shall face toward all public streets, sidewalks or other public property which adjoins the location so as to be clearly visible by persons using such public area. (3) The sign shall be posted on the property from the date of the first publication of the legal advertisement through the date of consideration by the board of commissioners. (Code 1999, § 6-74; Ord. of 6-6-1996, § 9) Sec. 8-87. - Application; investigation; issuance. (a) The chairperson of the board of commissioners or his designee shall have a reasonable time, not to exceed 30 days, to investigate the application and the background of the applicant. Upon completion of the investigation and after holding a public hearing, the board of commissioners shall issue such license if it is determined: (1) The application conforms in all respects to the provisions of this article. (2) The applicant has not made a material misrepresentation in this application. (3) The applicant has fully cooperated in the investigation of his application. (4) The applicant, if an individual, or any officers or directors or shareholders holding more than five percent of the outstanding shares of the corporation, if the applicant is a corporation, or any partners, including limited partners, if the applicant is a partnership, has not been convicted in a court of competent jurisdiction of any crime involving sexual assault, sexual battery, prostitution, rape, sexual offenses against children, unnatural sex acts, public indecency, or any other sex act, whether attempted or consummated, prohibited by law for which: a. Less than two years have elapsed since the date of conviction or the date of release from confinement imposed for the conviction, whichever is the later date, if the conviction is of a misdemeanor offense; b. Less than five years have elapsed since the date of conviction or the date of release from confinement for the conviction, whichever is the later date, if the conviction is a felony offense; c. Less than five years have elapsed since the date of the last conviction or the date of release from confinement for the last conviction, whichever is the later date, if the convictions are of two or more misdemeanor offenses or combination of misdemeanor offenses occurring within any 24-month period. (5) The applicant, if an individual, or any officers or directors or shareholders holding more than five percent of the outstanding shares of the corporation, if the applicant is a corporation, or any of the partners, including limited partners, if the applicant is a partnership, has not, during the past ten years, had an adult entertainment establishment license or other similar license or permit denied or revoked in this county or any other local governmental jurisdiction located in or out of this state prior to the date of application. (6) The building, structure, equipment or location of such business, as proposed by the applicant, would comply with all applicable distance provisions of this article and would qualify to receive a certificate of occupancy. (7) The applicant is at least 21 years of age. (8) On the date the business for which a license is required in this article commences and thereafter, there will be a responsible person on the premises to act as manager at all times during which the business is open. (b) Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, no license shall be issued to an applicant if within 12 months immediately preceding the filing of an application one or more of the following shall have occurred: (1) The same applicant for a license or renewal has been rejected for any location, if such rejection was based upon the applicant's failure to meet the terms of this article applicable to the applicant as opposed to rejection for reasons related to the location itself. (2) The location has been rejected for any applicant. (3) The applicant has withdrawn, without providential cause, an application at any time within seven days immediately preceding the time and date set for the hearing before the board of commissioners unless at least one year shall have expired from such withdrawal. The one year waiting period will not apply where the applicant shall apply for a new location which has not been rejected within the preceding 12 months, except if the applicant has had an application for another location rejected within the preceding 12 months because of lack of qualifications of the applicant. (c) Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, no license shall be issued until an annual license fee, established by resolution of the county and prorated on a calendar year basis, is paid to the county clerk. Such fee shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. (Code 1999, § 6-75; Ord. of 6-6-1996, § 10) Sec. 8-88. - License renewal. Licenses for adult entertainment establishments shall be renewed on a calendar year basis provided that the licensee continues to meet the requirements set out in this article. The renewal fee for the adult entertainment establishment license shall be established by resolution of the board of commissioners. Such fee shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. Renewal applications shall be submitted by November 15 of each year prior to January 1 of the year for which such license is requested. (Code 1999, § 6-76; Ord. of 6-6-1996, § 11) Sec. 8-89. - License nontransferable. No adult entertainment establishment license may be sold, transferred or assigned by a licensee, or by operation of law, to any other person. Any such sale, transfer or assignment, or attempted sale, transfer or assignment shall be deemed to constitute a voluntary surrender of such license and such license shall thereafter be null and void. However, if the licensee is a partnership or corporation, and one or more of the partners or shareholders, as the case may be, should die, one or more of the surviving partners or shareholders who were partners or shareholders at the time of issuance of the license may acquire, by purchase or otherwise, the interest of the deceased partner or shareholder without affecting a surrender or termination of such license; and in such case, the licensee shall immediately notify the office of the board of commissioners. An adult entertainment establishment license issued to a corporation shall be deemed terminated and void when either any outstanding stock of the corporation is sold, transferred or assigned after the issuance of a license, or any stock authorized but not issued at the time of the granting of a license under this article is thereafter issued and sold, transferred or assigned. (Code 1999, § 6-77; Ord. of 6-6-1996, § 12) Sec. 8-90. - Change of location. No licensee shall change the location of the establishment without obtaining a new license. (Code 1999, § 6-78; Ord. of 6-6-1996, § 13) Sec. 8-91. - Change of name. No licensee shall advertise, operate, conduct, manage, engage in, or carry on an adult entertainment establishment under any name other than his name and the name of the business as specified on his license. (Code 1999, § 6-79; Ord. of 6-6-1996, § 14) Sec. 8-92. - Modification of licensed premises. After issuance of any license, no change in the location of the building within the premises, customer entry locations or other changes shall be made which would affect compliance with any distance or other requirement of this article. (Code 1999, § 6-80; Ord. of 6-6-1996, § 15) Sec. 8-93. - License refusal. If the chairperson or his designee, following investigation of the applicant, deems that the applicant does not fulfill the requirements as set forth in this article, he shall so notify the applicant of such decision in writing and the basis thereof. Any such decision shall be final unless appeal is filed with the board of commissioners by any aggrieved party on or before ten days of the date of the decision. A hearing by the board of commissioners of the appeal shall occur within 30 days of its filing at a regular or special meeting of the board. (Code 1999, § 6-81; Ord. of 6-6-1996, § 16) Sec. 8-94. - Suspension; revocation; appeals; violations, penalties; service of notice. (a) Suspension of license. The chairperson of the board of commissioners may suspend a license for a period of 180 days if he determines that the licensee or an employee has violated any section of this article. If the chairperson deems a license suspension appropriate, he shall notify the licensee of such decision in writing and the basis thereof. Such suspension shall take effect ten days following the licensee's notification thereof unless an appeal is filed with the board of commissioners by the aggrieved party on or before ten days of the date of receipt by the aggrieved party of the decision. A hearing by the board of commissioners of the appeal shall occur within 30 days of its filing in a regular or special meeting of the board. Enforcement of the suspension shall stay pending the board's ruling on the licensee's appeal. (b) Revocation of license. (1) The chairperson may revoke a license if a cause for suspension occurs and the license has been suspended within the past 12 months. (2) The chairperson may also revoke a license if he determines that: a. A licensee gave false or misleading information in the material submitted during the application process. b. A licensee or an employee knowingly operated the sexually oriented business during a period of time when the licensee's license was suspended. c. A licensee or an employee has knowingly allowed any act of sexual intercourse, sodomy or copulation, masturbation or other illegal sexual conduct to occur in or on the licensed premises. d. The owner or operator of the licensed establishment knowingly allowed a person under 18 years of age to enter the establishment. (3) If the chairperson deems a license revocation appropriate, he shall so notify the licensee of such decision in writing and the basis thereof. Such revocation shall take effect ten days following the chairperson's serving of his written decision upon the licensee unless an appeal is filed with the board of commissioners by the aggrieved party on or before ten days of the date of receipt by the aggrieved party of the decision of the chairperson. A hearing by the board of commissioners on the decision shall occur within 30 days of its filing in a regular or special meeting of the board. Revocation shall continue for a one year period from the date revocation becomes effective. (c) Appeal procedure. An applicant or licensee who has timely filed an appeal with the board of commissioners as allowed by this article shall be entitled to a hearing before the board of commissioners. At the time set for the hearing, the board of commissioners shall receive all relevant testimony in evidence from county staff or interested parties, and from the licensee or employee. In all hearings pursuant to this article, the following procedures shall apply: (1) The chairperson of the board of commissioners shall read or cause to be read the charges and specifications against the charged party. He shall then read or cause to be read any response filed by the charged party. (2) The board of commissioners shall hear the evidence upon the charges and specifications as filed against the charged party and shall not consider any additional evidence beyond the scope of the charges and may exclude evidence which is purely cumulative. (3) The order of proof shall be as follows: a. The county representative shall present his evidence in support of the charges; the charged party shall then present his evidence. b. Evidence of each party may be supported by submission of pertinent documents. c. Each party shall be allowed to present pertinent rebuttal evidence. (4) The charged party and the county may be represented by counsel, and may present, examine and cross examine witnesses. Additionally, the board of commissioners may interrogate all parties and witnesses to obtain necessary information. (d) Violations and penalties. (1) Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be punishable by fine not to exceed $1,000.00 per violation or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed six months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. (2) Should any license be revoked or suspended, all signs indicating such businesses conducted on the premises shall be removed from the premises during the period of revocation or suspension. (3) The violation of provisions of this article by any person may be enjoined by instituting appropriate proceedings for injunction in any court of competent jurisdiction. Such action may be maintained notwithstanding that other adequate remedies at law exist. (e) Service of notice. (1) Any notice required to be given under this article to any applicant, licensee or employee may be given either by personal delivery or by certified United States mail, postage prepaid, return receipt requested, addressed to the most recent address as specified in the application for license/permit, or such updated address which may have subsequently been provided in writing to the county clerk. Notices mailed as described in this subsection shall be deemed given on the second day subsequent to their deposit in the United States mail. (2) It shall be the duty of each applicant, licensee and employee to furnish notice to the county clerk in writing of any change of mailing address. (Code 1999, § 6-82; Ord. of 6-6-1996, § 17) Sec. 8-95. - Adult entertainment employees. (a) Approval for employment. (1) Permit to work in or be employed by an adult entertainment establishment shall be required for all employees thereof.
