For the purpose of this article, independent contractors whose main purpose is to provide entertainment or other services to patrons, including, but not limited to, dancers and waitresses, employed or hired by an adult entertainment establishment, shall be considered as employees and shall be licensed as employees, regardless of the business relationship with the owner or licensee of any adult entertainment establishment. (2) No person requiring a permit may be employed by or work in an establishment until such person has filed an application and paid the fee for and obtained a work permit from the county clerk. The county clerk shall immediately issue the permit upon the filing of an application and payment of the fee, which permit shall be conditional and subject to revocation upon the determination by the county clerk following investigation of the applicant that the applicant is not qualified to be an employee under this article. Upon such determination the county clerk shall notify the applicant of such decision. Such decision shall be final unless an appeal is filed with the board of commissioners by the aggrieved party on or before ten days of the date of the decision of the county clerk. A hearing by the board of commissioners of the appeal shall occur within 30 days of its filing at a regular or special meeting of the board. (b) Application for permit. Application for permit shall be written and on forms supplied by the office of the county clerk. Such application shall state the name, address, social security number and date of birth of the applicant, the name and address of the employer, the name and address of the place of employment and any other information reasonably required by the county clerk in verifying the right of the applicant to obtain a permit. (c) Expiration of permit. Any permit for employment issued under this section shall expire 12 months from the date of issuance unless earlier revoked. A nonrefundable fee, established by resolution of the county, shall be paid to the county clerk to defray, in part, the cost of investigation and report required by this article. Such fee shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. (d) Conviction of crime. No person who has been convicted by a court of competent jurisdiction of any crime involving use, possession or sale of any drug or controlled substance; or prostitution, sexual battery, rape, sexual assault, public indecency or any other sex act, whether consummated or attempted, unless five years have elapsed since the date of conviction, or date of release which is the later date, shall be issued a work permit. (e) Future employment. No person who is convicted in a court of competent jurisdiction of any of the crimes specified in section 8-87(a)(4) while employed in an adult entertainment establishment shall thereafter work on any premises requiring a license under this article for the applicable time period described in subsection (d) of this section. (Code 1999, § 6-83; Ord. of 6-6-1996, § 18)

div.head: Chapter 10 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Georgia Mutual Aid Act, O.C.G.A. § 36-69-1 et seq.; Georgia Emergency Management Act of 1981, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-1 et seq.; Emergency Management Assistance Compact, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-80 et seq.
Sec. 10-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Disaster means any natural, technological, civil emergency or threat thereof that causes or has the potential to cause damage of sufficient severity and magnitude to result in a declaration of a state of emergency declared by a county, the governor or the President of the United States. Emergency means any natural or manmade event requiring the activation of the local emergency operations plan. Emergency management means the preparation for the carrying out of all emergency functions other than functions for which military forces are primarily responsible to prevent, minimize, and repair injury and damage resulting from emergencies, energy emergencies, disasters, or the imminent threat thereof, of manmade or natural origin. "These functions include, without limitation, firefighting services; police services [public safety]; medical and health services; rescue; engineering; warning services; communications; defense from radiological, chemical and other special weapons; evacuation of persons from stricken areas; emergency welfare services; emergency transportation; [nuclear power] plant protection; temporary restoration of public service utility services; and other functions related to civilian protection, together with all other activities necessary or incidental to the preparation for and carrying out of the foregoing functions." (Georgia Emergency Management Act of 1981, as amended December 1992, chapter 3, article 1, 38-3-3.) Local emergency management director means the person nominated by the local governments and appointed by the state emergency management director to implement the local emergency operations plan. State emergency management director means the person appointed by the governor to head the state emergency management agency. (Code 1999, § 7-27; Res. of 7-6-1990, § I; Ord. of 1-8-2009, § I) Sec. 10-2. - Local organization for emergency management. In agreement with the governing officials of the cities within the county, there is herby established the county emergency management agency. The chairperson of the county commissioners, with the concurrence of officials of the cities within the county, shall nominate, for appointment by the state emergency management director, a director of the county emergency management agency. Upon appointment, the local emergency management agency director shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration and operations of the local organization for emergency management, subject to the direction and control of the executive officer or governing body and shall serve at the pleasure of such executive officer or governing body. When appointed, the local emergency management director is charged with the following duties: (1) Represent the governing officials of the county on matters pertaining to emergency management. (2) Assist local officials in organizing county departments for emergency operations. (3) Develop, in conjunction with county and city departments, the county emergency operations plan for emergency functions. Such plan will be in consonance with the state emergency operations plan and shall be submitted to the governing officials of the county and the cities within the county for approval, and thence to the state emergency management agency for approval. (4) Maintain the emergency management agency and carry out the day-to-day administration of the county emergency management program, including the submission of required reports to the state emergency management agency. (5) Submit reports as required by governmental officials in keeping with good management practices, e.g., financial, daily activities, etc. (6) Obtain, with the authority of governing officials, a facility to be used as the county emergency operations center. (7) Coordinate the activities of the county emergency operating staff during periods of emergency, and under the supervision of county governing officials. (Code 1999, § 7-28; Res. of 7-6-1990, § II; Ord. of 1-8-2009, § II) Sec. 10-3. - County emergency management agency. The county emergency management agency shall be established around existing county and city departments. Functions should be assigned consistent with the local emergency operations plan. Heads of county departments listed in the county emergency management operations plan are responsible for developing appropriate annexes and standard operating procedures (SOPs) to the emergency operations plan (EOP) for their assigned emergency functions. Such annexes and/or SOPs will be submitted to the emergency management director for inclusion in the local EOP for submission to appropriate local officials for approval. (Code 1999, § 7-29; Res. of 11-5-1987, § III; Res. of 7-6-1990, § III; Ord. of 1-8-2009, § III) Sec. 10-4. - Director—Appointed. The chairperson of the board of commissioners, with concurrence of the mayors of cities within the county, shall nominate for appointment by the director of the state emergency management agency a local director of emergency management for the entire county. (Code 1999, § 7-30; Res. of 7-6-1990, § II) Sec. 10-5. - Same—Duties. The emergency management director is charged with the following duties of: (1) Representing the governing officials of the county and cities therein on matters pertaining to emergency management. (2) Assisting county and city officials in organizing county and city departments for emergency operations. (3) Developing, in conjunction with county and city departments, the county plan for emergency functions set forth in section 10-1. Such plan will be in consonance with the state natural disaster operations plan and nuclear emergency operations plan, and shall be submitted to the governing officials of the county and the cities therein for approval and then to the state emergency management agency for approval. (4) Maintaining the emergency management agency and carrying out the day-to-day administration of the county emergency management program, including the submission of required reports to the state emergency management agency. (5) Submitting reports as required by governing officials in keeping with good management practices, e.g., financial, daily activity, etc. (6) Obtaining, with the authority of governing officials, a facility to be used as the county emergency operating center. (7) Coordinating the activities of the county emergency operating center staff during periods of an emergency, under the supervision of the county governing officials. (Code 1999, § 7-31; Res. of 11-5-1987, § II; Res. of 7-6-1990, § II) Sec. 10-6. - Powers during an emergency or disaster. In the event of a manmade or natural disaster or any other emergency which may effect the lives and property of the citizens of the county, the chairperson of the county commissioners separately, or jointly with the mayors of Folkston and Homeland or in their absence their legally appointed successors, may determine that an emergency or disaster exists and thereafter shall have and may exercise for such periods as such emergency or disaster continues, the following powers: (1) To appropriate and expend funds, execute contracts and to obtain and distribute equipment, materials and supplies for emergency management purposes; (2) To provide for the health and safety of persons and property, including emergency assistance to the victims of any emergency or disaster resulting from manmade or natural causes or enemy attack and to direct and coordinate the development of emergency management plans and programs in accordance with the policies and plans set by the federal and state emergency management agencies; (3) To appoint, employ, remove or provide, with or without compensation, chiefs of services, warning personnel, rescue teams, auxiliary fire and police personnel and other emergency management workers; (4) To establish a primary and one or more secondary control centers to serve as command posts during an emergency or disaster; (5) Subject to the order of the governor or the chief executive of the political subdivision, to assign and make available for duty the employees, property or equipment of the subdivision relating to firefighting, engineering, rescue, health, medical and related services, and to police, transportation, construction and similar items or services for emergency management purposes, within or outside of the physical limits of the subdivision; (6) In addition to the heretofore stated powers and authorities, to acquire, temporarily or permanently, by purchase, lease or otherwise, sites required for installation of temporary housing units for disaster victims; and to enter into whatever arrangements, including purchase, of temporary housing units and payment of transportation charges, which are necessary to prepare or equip such sites to utilize the housing units (Chapter 3, article 2, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-27). (Code 1999, § 7-32; Res. of 11-5-1987, § IV; Res. of 7-6-1990, § IV; Ord. of 1-8-2009, § IV) Sec. 10-7. - Volunteers. All persons, other than officers and employees of the county, performing emergency functions pursuant to this chapter, shall serve with or without compensation. While engaged in such emergency functions, duly assigned volunteers shall have the same immunities as county officers and employees. Immunity does not apply in cases of willful misconduct, gross negligence or bad faith (Chapter 3, article 2, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-35). (Code 1999, § 7-33; Res. of 11-5-1987, § V; Res. of 7-6-1990, § V; Ord. of 1-8-2009, § V) Sec. 10-8. - Violation of chapter. Any person violating any provision of this chapter, rule, order or regulation made pursuant to this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as a misdemeanor. (Code 1999, § 7-34; Res. of 11-5-1987, § VI; Res. of 7-6-1990, § VI; Ord. of 1-8-2009, § VI) Sec. 10-9. - Emergency management and response powers. (a) Declaration of local emergency. (1) Grant of authority. In the event of an actual or threatened occurrence of a disaster or emergency, which may result in the large-scale loss of life, injury, property damage or destruction or in the major disruption of routine community affairs, business or governmental operations in the county and which is of sufficient severity and magnitude to warrant extraordinary assistance by federal, state and local departments and agencies to supplement the efforts of available public and private resources, the chairperson of the board of commissioners may declare a local emergency for the county. The form of the declaration shall be similar to that provided in subsection (b) of this section. (2) Request for state assistance. Consistent with a declaration of local emergency, the chairperson may request the governor to provide assistance, provided that the disaster or emergency is beyond the capacity of the county to meet adequately and state assistance is necessary to supplement local efforts to save lives and protect property, public health and safety, or to avert or lessen the threat of a disaster. (3) Continuance. The declaration of local emergency shall continue until the chairperson finds that emergency conditions no longer exist, at which time, the chairperson shall execute and file with the clerk of the board of commissioners a document marking the end of the state of emergency. No state of local emergency shall continue for longer than 30 days, unless renewed by the chairperson. The board of commissioners may, by resolution, end a state of local emergency at any time. (4) Effect of declaration of emergency. a. Activation of emergency operations plan. A declaration of emergency by the governor or a declaration of local emergency by the chairperson shall automatically activate the county emergency operations plan and shall be the authority for deployment of personnel and use of any forces to which the plan applies and for use or distribution of any supplies, equipment, materials and facilities assembled, stockpiled or arranged to be made available pursuant to the Georgia Emergency Management Act or any other laws applicable to emergencies or disasters. 1. The county emergency management agency (EMA) director shall have the legal authority to exercise the powers and discharge the duties conferred upon the emergency management agency, including the implementation of the emergency operations plan, coordination of the emergency responses of public and private agencies and organizations, coordination of recovery efforts with state and federal officials and inspection of emergency or disaster sites. 2. In responding and conducting necessary and appropriate investigations, the director or his designee is authorized to enter at a reasonable time upon any property, public or private, for the purpose of investigating and inspecting sites involved with emergency management functions. The director is authorized to execute a right of entry and/or agreement to use property for these purposes on behalf of the county; however, any such document shall be later presented for ratification at a meeting of the board of commissioners. 3. No person shall refuse entry or access to any authorized representative or agent of the county who requests entry for purposes of inspection and who presents appropriate credentials. Nor shall any person obstruct, hamper or interfere with any such representative while that individual is in the process of carrying out his official duties. b. Emergency powers. Following a declaration of emergency and during the continuance of such state of emergency, the chairperson is authorized to implement local emergency measures to protect life and property or to bring the emergency situation under control. In exercising this authority, the chairperson may cause to become effective any of the following sections of this chapter as appropriate: Section 10-12 (registration of building and repair services) to become effective if the governor declares a state of emergency; and section 10-13 (closed or restricted areas and curfews). If any of these sections are included in a declaration of local emergency, the same shall be filed in the office of the clerk of the board of commissioners and shall be in effect until the declaration of local emergency has terminated. c. Authority to waive procedures and fees. Pursuant to a declaration of emergency, the board of commissioners is authorized to cause to be effective any of the subsections of section 10-11, as appropriate. The implementation of such subsections shall be filed in the office of the clerk of the board of commissioners. d. Additional emergency powers. The chairperson of the board of commissioners shall have, and may exercise for such period as the declared emergency exists or continues, the following additional emergency powers: 1. To direct and compel the evacuation of all or part of the population from any stricken or threatened area, for the preservation of life or other disaster mitigation, response or recovery; 2. To prescribe routes, modes of transportation and destinations in connection with evacuation; 3. To suspend or limit the sale, dispensing or transportation of alcoholic beverages, firearms, explosives and flammable liquids and substances; 4. To make provision for the availability and use of temporary emergency housing, emergency shelters and/or emergency medical shelters; 5. To transfer the direction, personnel or functions of any county departments and agencies or units thereof for the purpose of performing or facilitating emergency services; 6. To utilize all available resources of the county and subordinate agencies over which the county has budgetary control as reasonably necessary to cope with the emergency or disaster; 7. To utilize public property when necessary to cope with the emergency or disaster or when there is compelling necessity for the protection of lives, health and welfare, and/or the property of citizens; 8. To suspend any law, code provision or regulation prescribing the procedures for conduct of county business, or the orders, rules or regulations of any county agency, if strict compliance with any ordinance, resolution, order, rule or regulation would in any way prevent, hinder or delay necessary action in coping with the emergency or disaster, provided that such suspension shall provide for the minimum deviation from the requirements under the circumstances and further provided that, when practicable, specialists shall be assigned to avoid adverse effects resulting from such suspension; 9. To provide benefits to citizens upon execution of an intergovernmental agreement for grants to meet disaster-related necessary expenses or serious needs of individuals or families adversely affected by an emergency or disaster in cases where the individuals or families are unable to meet the expenses or needs from other means, provided that such grants are authorized only when matching state or federal funds are available for such purposes; 10. To perform and exercise such other functions, powers and duties as may be deemed necessary to promote and secure the safety and protection of the civilian population, including individuals with household pets and service animals prior to, during and following a major disaster or emergency. (b) Form of declaration of local emergency. Upon the declaration of local emergency, an official declaration of local emergency, in substantially the same form set forth in this subsection, shall be signed and filed in the office of the county clerk and shall be communicated to the citizens of the affected area using the most effective and efficient means available. The declaration shall state the nature of the emergency or disaster, the conditions that require the declaration and any sections of this chapter which shall be in effect. DECLARATION OF LOCAL EMERGENCY WHEREAS, Charlton County, Georgia has experienced an event of critical significance as a result of [description of event] on [date]; and WHEREAS, in the judgment of the Chair of the Charlton County Board of Commissioners, with advice from the Charlton County Emergency Management Agency, there exist emergency circumstances located in [describe geographic location] requiring extraordinary and immediate corrective actions for the protection of the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of Charlton County, including individuals with household pets and service animals; and WHEREAS, to prevent or minimize injury to people and damage to property resulting from this event. NOW, THEREFORE, pursuant to the authority vested in me by local and state law; IT IS HEREBY DECLARED that a local state of emergency exists and shall continue until the conditions requiring this declaration are abated. THEREFORE, IT IS ORDERED: (1) That the Charlton County Emergency Management Agency activates the Emergency Operations Plan; (2) That the following sections of the Charlton County Code of Ordinances be implemented: [If deemed appropriate, choose from the following: Section 10-12, Registration of Building and Repair Services, to be effective only if the Governor has declared a state of emergency; and/or Section 10-13, Closed or Restricted Areas and Curfews]; and (3) That the following measures also be implemented: [If deemed appropriate, select items from Section 10-9(a)(4)c. or d., or such other measures as appropriate.] ENTERED at [time] on [date]. (signature) Chairman, Charlton County Board of Commissioners (c) Contracts with municipalities. In addition to the normal agreements embodied in the county's emergency operations plan for mutual emergency assistance, the board of commissioners may contract with any municipality for the administration of an emergency response program. (Code 1999, Ch. 7; Ord. of 3-1-2012(03), § 2) Sec. 10-10. - Enforcement and remedies. (a) Law enforcement. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 38-3-4, the county sheriff's office shall be authorized to enforce the orders, rules and regulations contained in this chapter and/or implemented by the chairperson or local governing authority during a declared emergency. (b) Penalties. Failure to comply with any of the requirements or provisions of the regulations contained in this chapter, or with any code section, order, rule or regulation made effective by the chairperson or local governing authority upon or after the declaration of an emergency, shall constitute a violation of the provisions of this chapter. Any person who violates any provision in this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00, imprisonment for a term not exceeding 60 days, or both such fine and imprisonment, for each violation. Each person assisting in the commission of a violation shall be guilty of separate offenses. Each day during which a violation or failure to comply continues shall constitute a separate violation. Each violation may be prosecuted in any court of competent jurisdiction, including the state court of the county. (c) Injunctive relief. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 38-3-5, in addition to the remedies prescribed in this section, the EMA director is authorized to obtain an injunction to restrain violation of laws, code sections, orders, rules and regulations which are contained in the Georgia Emergency Management Act and/or this Code, and/or which are implemented by the local governing authority during a declared emergency. (d) Enforcement. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, this chapter may be enforced by the county sheriff's office, the EMA director and any other competent authority or designee or appointee of the county board of commissioners. (Code 1999, Ch. 7; Ord. of 3-1-2012(03), § 3) Sec. 10-11. - Authority to waive procedures and fee structures. (a) County business. Upon declaration of an emergency or disaster by the governor or chairperson of the board of commissioners, the affairs and business of the county may be conducted at places other than the regular or usual location, within or outside of the county, when it is not prudent, expedient or possible to conduct business at the regular location. When such meetings occur outside of the county, all actions taken by the board of commissioners shall be as valid and binding as if performed within the county. Such meetings may be called by the presiding officer or any two members of the governing body without regard to, or compliance with, time-consuming procedures and formalities otherwise required by law. (b) Public works contracts. Upon declaration of an emergency or disaster by the governor or chairperson of the board of commissioners, the board of commissioners may contract for public works without letting such contract out to the lowest, responsible bidder and without advertising and posting notification of such contract for four weeks; provided, however, that the emergency must be of such nature that immediate action is required and that the action is necessary for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare. Any public works contract entered into pursuant to this subsection shall be entered on the minutes of the county as soon as practical and the nature of the emergency described therein in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 36-91-22(e). (c) Purchasing. Upon declaration of an emergency or disaster by the governor or chairperson of the board of commissioners, the purchasing ordinances, regulations or policies may be suspended. County officials shall continue to seek to obtain the best prices during the state of local emergency. (d) Code enforcement. Upon declaration of a state of emergency or disaster by the governor or the chairperson of the board of commissioners, the board of commissioners may temporarily suspend the enforcement of the ordinances of the county, or any portion thereof, where the emergency is of such nature that immediate action outside the Code is required, such suspension is consistent with the protection of the public health, safety and welfare, and such suspension is not inconsistent with any federal or state statutes or regulations. (e) Fees. Upon declaration of a state of emergency or disaster by the governor or the chairperson of the board of commissioners, the board of commissioners may temporarily reduce or suspend any permit fees, application fees or other rate structures as necessary to encourage the rebuilding of the areas impacted by the disaster or emergency. The term "fees" includes fees or rates charged by the county for building permits, land disturbance permits, zoning applications, special land use permits, temporary land use permits and other fees relating to the reconstruction, repair and cleanup of areas impacted by the disaster or emergency. The term "fees" does not include fees collected by the county on behalf of the state or federal government or fees charged by the county pursuant to a state or federal statute or regulation. (f) Temporary dwellings. Upon the declaration of a state of emergency or disaster by the governor or chairperson of the board of commissioners, the board of commissioners or its designees may issue temporary mobile home, trailer, recreational vehicle or other temporary dwelling structures or parks in any zoning district, even though not otherwise permitted by the development code, while the primary dwelling is being repaired, provided that such temporary dwellings or parks are designed by an engineer and the plans are approved by the county health department and development services. The temporary permit shall not exceed six months in duration. In the case of a continuing hardship, and in the discretion of the board of commissioners or its designee, the permit may be extended for a period of up to an additional six months. Upon expiration of the temporary permit and/or extension, the temporary dwelling must be removed. (Code 1999, Ch. 7; Ord. of 3-1-2012(03), § 4) Sec. 10-12. - Registration of building and repair services. (a) In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 38-3-56, before building, constructing, repairing, renovating or making improvements to any real property, including dwellings, homes, buildings, structures or fixtures within an area in the unincorporated area of the county designated in a declared emergency or disaster, any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity must register with the county and secure a building permit that is posted at the work site. Each day any such entity does business in the unincorporated areas of the county without complying with this chapter constitutes a separate offense. (b) The cost of registration fees in a declared emergency or disaster is fixed at $100.00 per annum. Registration is nontransferable. The cost of the emergency building permit shall be equal to the cost for a building permit under existing regulations. The permit shall only be authorized for repairs. (c) When registering, any person, partnership, corporation or other entity making an application must, under oath, complete an application, providing the following information: (1) Name of the applicant; (2) Permanent address and phone number of the applicant; (3) Applicant's social security number or federal employer identification number; (4) If the applicant is a corporation, the state and date of incorporation; (5) Tag registration information for each vehicle to be used in the business; (6) List of cities and/or counties where the applicant has conducted business within the past 12 months; (7) State sales tax number or authorization; (8) State business license number, if required; (9) Copy of license from the secretary of state, if required. (d) Effective date. This section shall become effective only upon a declaration of emergency by the governor and a local declaration stating this section is in effect. Unless otherwise specified in the declaration of emergency or otherwise extended by the board of commissioners, the provisions of this section shall remain in effect during the state of emergency and for a subsequent recovery period of three months. (Code 1999, ch. 7; Ord. of 3-1-2012(03), § 5) Sec. 10-13. - Closed or restricted areas and curfews during emergency. (a) To preserve, protect or sustain the life, health, welfare or safety of persons, or their property, within a designated area under a declaration of emergency, it shall be unlawful for any person to travel, loiter, wander or stroll in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, lanes, parks or other public grounds, public places, public buildings, places of amusement, eating places, vacant lots or any other place during a declared emergency between hours specified by the chairperson until the curfew is lifted. (b) To promote order, protect lives, minimize the potential for looting and other crimes, and facilitate recovery operations during an emergency, the chairperson shall have discretion to impose reentry restrictions on certain areas. The chairperson shall exercise such discretion in accordance with the county emergency operations plan, which shall be followed during emergencies. (c) The provisions of this section shall not apply to persons acting in the following capacities: (1) Authorized and essential law enforcement personnel; (2) Authorized and essential health care providers; (3) Authorized and essential personnel of the county; (4) Authorized National Guard or federal military personnel; (5) Authorized and essential firefighters; (6) Authorized and essential emergency response personnel; (7) Authorized and essential personnel or volunteers working with or through the county emergency management agency (EMA); (8) Authorized and essential utility repair crews; (9) Citizens seeking to restore order to their homes or businesses while on their own property or place of business; (10) Other authorized and essential persons as designated on a list compiled by EMA, the director of public safety and/or the county sheriff. (d) Enforceability. This section shall be enforced by officers of the law enforcement personnel approved to provide aid and assistance during the emergency. Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit a law enforcement officer from bringing other charges under state law. (e) Effective date. This section shall become effective only upon the signing of a declaration of emergency, stating this section is in effect. (Code 1999, Ch. 7; Ord. of 3-1-2012(03), § 6)

div.head: Chapter 12 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Authority to provide public health facilities and services, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(3); powers and duties of county boards of health, O.C.G.A. § 26-2-373; County boards of health, O.C.G.A. § 31-3-1 et seq.
Sec. 12-1. - Rules, regulations incorporated by reference. There are currently in existence certain rules and regulations adopted by the Charlton County Board of Health with the purpose of preserving the public health, safety, and welfare of citizens of Charlton County, Georgia. This section specifically incorporates by reference the provision of the following rules and regulations which are in force at the time of the adoption of this ordinance: (a) Rules and regulations pertaining to food service (adopted by the department of public health and the Charlton County Board of Health and being Chapter 290-5-14 as subsequently amended and updated), and policies of the Charlton County Board of Health pertaining to Food Service; (b) Rules and regulations for on-site sewage management systems (adopted by the department of public health and the Charlton County Board of Health and being Chapter 511-3-1 as subsequently amended and updated), and policies of the Charlton County Board of Health pertaining to on-site sewage management systems; (c) Rules and regulations for mass gatherings (adopted by the department of public and the Charlton County Board of Health and being Chapter 511-3-2 as subsequently amended and updated), and policies of the Charlton County Board of Health pertaining to mass gatherings; (d) Rules and regulations pertaining to drinking water supply (adopted by the department of public health and the Charlton County Board of Health and being Chapter 511-3-3 as subsequently amended and updated), and policies of the Charlton County Board of Health pertaining to drinking water supply; (e) Rules and regulations pertaining to solid waste (adopted by the department of public health and the Charlton County Board of Health and being Chapter 511-3-4 as subsequently amended and updated), and policies of the Charlton County Board of Health pertaining to solid waste; (f) Rules and regulations pertaining to public swimming pools, spas, and recreational water parks (adopted by the department of public health and the Charlton County Board of Health and being Chapter 511-3-5 as subsequently amended and updated), and policies of the Charlton County Board of Health pertaining to public swimming pools, spas, and recreational water parks; (g) Rules and regulations pertaining to portable sanitation contractors (adopted by the department of public health and the Charlton County Board of Health and being Chapter 511-3-6 as subsequently amended and updated), and policies of the Charlton County Board of Health pertaining to portable sanitation; (h) Rules and regulations pertaining to Georgia Smoke Free Air Act of 2005 (adopted by the department of public health and the Charlton County Board of Health and being Chapter 511-3-7 as subsequently amended and updated), and policies of the Charlton County Board of Health pertaining to smoke free air; (i) Rules and regulations pertaining to rabies control (adopted by the department of public health and the Charlton County Board of Health and being Chapter 511-4-2 and the "rabies control ordinance" as subsequently amended and updated), and policies of the Charlton County Board of Health pertaining to rabies control; (j) Rules and regulations pertaining to tourist accommodations (adopted by the department of public health and the Charlton County Board of Health and being Chapter 511-6-2 as subsequently amended and updated), and policies of the Charlton County Board of Health pertaining to tourist accommodations; (k) Rules and regulations pertaining to body art and/or tattooing (adopted by the department of public health and/or the Charlton County Board of Health and being rules and regulations for body art studios and artists as subsequently amended and updated), and policies of the Charlton County Board of Health pertaining to body art and/or tattooing; and A copy of all these rules and regulations are attached to this ordinance. (Code 1999, § 11-1; Ord. of 10-4-2007(03); Ord. No. 8 of 2016, § I, 3-22-2016) Sec. 12-2. - Enforcement of chapter. The duty of implementation and enforcement of these regulations rest with the Charlton County Board of Commissioners, and by virtue of this ordinance is hereby expressly delegated to the Charlton County Board of Health who is hereby charged with promulgation of sufficient procedures for insuring compliance with these rules and regulations by the citizens of Charlton County or those individuals found within the boundaries of Charlton County. The Charlton County Board of Health is directed to implement procedures which will insure that the citizens of Charlton County or those individuals found within the boundaries of Charlton County will receive all procedural rights to which they are entitled under the laws of the State of Georgia. (Code 1999, § 11-2; Ord. of 8-7-1986, § I; Ord. No. 8 of 2016, § II, 3-22-2016) Sec. 12-3. - Violation of chapter—Prosecution in magistrate's court or state court. The magistrate's court of Charlton County shall have jurisdiction over violators of this ordinance and all procedures for enforcement of such ordinance shall be as provided in Article 4, Chapter 10 of Title 15, Official Code of Georgia. Complaints of violation of any provision of this ordinance shall be brought before the magistrate's court by a designated representative of the Charlton County Board of Health and shall be prosecuted through that court. (Code 1999, § 11-3; Ord. of 8-7-1986, § IV; Ord. No. 8 of 2016, § IV, 3-22-2016) Sec. 12-4. - Same—Penalty. Any violation of the rules and regulations hereby referenced shall be a violation of this ordinance and shall be a misdemeanor offense. Any violator shall be subject to the imposition of a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 and/or imprisonment for a period not to exceed 60 days. Any failure of payment of inspection fees listed within the fee schedule adopted by Charlton County Board of Health and approved the Charlton County Board of Commissioners within 60 days of first notice, may result in suspension of permit. (Code 1999, § 11-4; Ord. of 8-7-1986, § III; Ord. No. 8 of 2016, § III, 3-22-2016) Sec. 12-5. - Acts of tattooing and body piercing. (a) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Body piercing means the creation of an opening in an individual's body, other than the individual's ear, to insert jewelry or other decoration. Tattoo means to mark or color the skin by pricking, piercing or implanting indelible pigments or dyes under the skin. (b) Acts of tattooing and body piercing banned within the county. No acts of tattooing or body piercing shall be allowed within the territorial limits of the county, except if performed by a licensed physician for a medical purpose. (c) Violation of section is a misdemeanor. Violation of this section shall be a misdemeanor offense, punishable according to the general penalties described in sections 1-13 and 1-14. (d) Enforcement. Deputies of the county sheriff's office, a county code enforcement officer, and the county attorney are authorized to prosecute violations of this section by citation or accusation. (e) Jurisdiction of the magistrate's court of the county or state court over violators. The magistrate's court of the county or state court shall have jurisdiction over violators of this section. Complaints of violation of this section shall be brought before the magistrate's court or state court by an authorized individual and may be prosecuted in such court. However, individuals prosecuted under this section shall have the right to request a trial by jury in any other court of competent jurisdiction, with such right invoked by a written request tendered to the magistrate's court or state court prior to the submission of evidence by the prosecutor. (Ord. of 9-4-2003, § 11-5)

div.head: Chapter 14 - NUISANCES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Nuisances generally, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-1 et seq.; municipal authority to require by ordinance the repair, closing, or demolition of unfit dwellings or other unfit structures intended for human habitation, O.C.G.A. § 36-61-11.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 14-1—14-39. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - CLEAN COMMUNITY
Sec. 14-40. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Building means any structure having a roof supported by columns or walls intended for shelter, housing or enclosure of persons, animals, chattels or property of any kind. Building materials means any material such as lumber, roofing material, brick, concrete block, plaster, gutters, sand, gravel or other substances used in repair or alteration of existing buildings, construction of new buildings or demolition of existing buildings. Business trash means a form of waste such as dust, paper, cardboard, excelsior or other substances which are usually attendant to the operation of stores, offices, commercial buildings and similar type activities. Commercial establishment means any building devoted to retail or wholesale sales, uses, religious uses, governmental uses or other nonresidential uses. Household trash means a form of waste such as paper, sweepings, dust, rags, bottles, cans or other materials of any kind, other than garbage, which is normally attendant to the occupancy of a building for dwelling purposes. Junk means any dilapidated furniture, appliance, vehicle, machinery, equipment or other items which is either in a partially rusted, wrecked, junked, dismantled or inoperative condition. Litter means all garbage, refuse, waste materials, sand, gravel, slag, brick bats, rubbish, tin cans, trash, debris, dead animals or any other discarded, used or unconsumed substance. Refuse means solid waste consisting of garbage, household trash or business trash as defined in this section. Road or street. The terms "road" and "street" are mutually inclusive, and likewise include any alley, lane, court and other thoroughfare, however described or designated. Rubbish means and includes waste, paper, cartons, boxes, wood, tree branches, yard trimmings, furniture, appliances, metal, cans, glass, packing material and similar material. Screened area means an area that is totally surrounded by uniform material, not of patchwork type material, all of the same color and design. Screening materials may be of steel or other metals, durable woods such as hard cypress, redwood or other wood treated with a preservative or walls of masonry, concrete block, brick, stone or other like material. The fencing material may be chainlink type fencing with aluminum, steel, plastic or wood slat inserts or of wooden type with basket weave, palisade, board-on-board, louver or other like material and design. Also, the screening material may be an earthen wall, grassed and landscaped. Screens shall not be used for advertising purposes except that a space no larger than six feet by 12 feet may be used to advertise the business of the owner. Small dead animals means cats, dogs, small household pets and other animals of similar size having a weight of less than 100 pounds. Trash means any business trash, household trash or yard trash. Yard trash means a form of waste such as tree branches, tree limbs, parts of trees, bushes, shrubbery cuttings or clippings or lawn grass or dry leaf rakings, or other natural waste. (Code 1999, § 9-86; Ord. of 1-6-1994, § 2) Sec. 14-41. - Public health nuisances. No person shall create upon his property or property occupied by him a public health nuisance or to allow a public health nuisance to remain on his property or property occupied by him. Dead animals, stagnant water, the accumulation of decayed vegetables, fruits, refuse, garbage, trash, litter, building materials, rubbish, junk or anything that may cause injury or damage to the health or life or property of any other person, are declared nuisances. (Code 1999, § 9-87; Ord. of 1-6-1994, § 3) Sec. 14-42. - Maintenance of premises. (a) No person shall maintain his premises, including vacant lots or land, in such a way as to allow trash, litter, garbage, refuse, building materials, rubbish, small dead animals or junk to accumulate, so that the condition of the property causes a nuisance or causes injury to the neighboring property, and no removal efforts are instituted within 30 days of notice by the county of the existence of the nuisance. Any failure of an owner or occupant of property to remove and correct any such accumulation as mentioned herein after 30 days' written notice from the county shall raise the presumption that such person intended to violate this article. (b) No person shall leave outside any building in a place accessible to children any appliance, refrigerator or other container which has an airtight snap lock or similar device without first removing therefrom the lock or door. This section does not apply to any appliances, refrigerators or containers which have been crated, strapped or locked so that it is impossible for a child to obtain access to any compartment thereof. (Code 1999, § 9-88; Ord. of 1-6-1994, §§ 4, 5) Sec. 14-43. - Exemption. This article shall not apply to junk or building materials located on any parcel of land situated more than 1,000 feet from any street or federal highway or 500 feet from any occupied residence, church, commercial establishment or public park or public use facility, and there exists a vegetated buffer of at least 200 feet within the separation area. (Code 1999, § 9-90; Ord. of 1-6-1994, § 7) Sec. 14-44. - Junk or building materials; enclosure. It shall not be a violation of this article for any person to accumulate junk or building materials on any property for his personal use or for sale if such junk or building materials is completely enclosed within a building or contained within a screened area. (Code 1999, § 9-91; Ord. of 1-6-1994, § 8) Sec. 14-45. - Penalty. (a) No person accused of violating this article shall be arrested prior to trial, but any person who fails to appear for trial shall be arrested thereafter on the warrant of the magistrate and required to post bond for his future appearance. (b) Violations of this article shall be tried upon citations which shall be issued to an alleged violator of any provisions of this article. Such citation shall state the time and place at which the accused is to appear for trial, shall identify the offense with which the accused is charged, shall have an identifying number by which it shall be filed with the court, shall indicate the identity of the accused and the date of service and shall be signed by the representative of the county who completes and serves it. The citation may be served by certified mail, return receipt requested. (c) Citations issued under this article may be tried without a prosecuting attorney, however, in the event the prosecuting attorney is needed the county attorney shall serve as the prosecuting attorney. (d) Violations of this article shall be tried in the magistrate court or state court of the county and shall be tried in accordance with O.C.G.A. chapter 15-10. (e) Nothing in this article shall prevent the board of commissioners from bringing any civil action for injunction, or other proceedings to present, correct or abate any violation of this article or other state or federal law. No sanction, penalty or remedy prescribed in this section shall be considered exclusive of any other remedy, but shall be available in addition to any other sanctions, penalties or remedies provided by law. (f) Each violation of this article shall constitute a separate offense. (Code 1999, § 9-93; Ord. of 1-6-1994, § 10) Sec. 14-46. - Citation service. Citations for the violation or alleged violation of the Clean Community Ordinance of Charlton County, Georgia, adopted January 6, 1994, as may be amended, shall be issued and served upon the person or persons alleged to have violated said ordinance, and said citation shall require said persons to appear in the magistrate court or state court at a date and time certain to answer said charges. (Ord. of 11-2-2000, § 1) Sec. 14-47. - Building inspector to serve citation. The county building inspector or a county code enforcement officer is hereby appointed as the agent of the county board of commissioners for the purpose of serving said citation and any other notices provided for by said ordinance. (Ord. of 11-2-2000, § 2) Secs. 14-48—14-69. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - NOISE
Sec. 14-70. - Prohibited conduct. (a) Prohibition. It shall be unlawful and shall be held a violation of this article for any person, group of persons, regardless of number, to willfully make, continue, or cause to be made or continued any loud, raucous and disturbing noise, which shall mean any sound which, because of its volume level, duration and character, annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, health, peace or safety of reasonable persons of ordinary reason sensibilities within the county. The term "loud, raucous and disturbing noise" is limited to loud, raucous and disturbing noises heard on the public streets, on any public property, school or other public building or grounds thereof when in use, in any church, hospital or grounds thereof when occupied, or in or upon any residential property which is not the source of such noise. (b) Evaluation. In determining whether a noise is unreasonably loud, raucous and disturbing, the following factors incident to such noise shall be considered: (1) Time of day; (2) Proximity to residences; (3) Whether the noise is recurrent, intermittent, or constant; (4) The volume and intensity; (5) Whether the noise has been enhanced in volume or range by any electronic or mechanical means; (6) The character and population density of the area; and (7) Whether the noise is subject to being controlled without unreasonable effort or expense to the creator thereof. (c) Declared nuisances. The following acts are declared to be nuisances in violation of this article, but this enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive: (1) Prohibited hours for noises. Making loud, raucous and disturbing noise or sound between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., if such noise is plainly audible across any residential property line shall be held to be prima facie evidence of a violation of this article; and (2) Continuation of noise after notice. Continuing to make, create or knowingly assist in creating a loud, raucous and disturbing noise or sound after receiving actual notice that such noises or sounds are disturbing residents or other persons in the vicinity shall be held to be prima facie evidence of a violation of this article. (d) Exemption. The following shall be exempt from the application of this article: (1) Agricultural and horticultural. Noise resulting from agricultural and horticultural operations conducted in a reasonable manner and during reasonable hours; (2) Authorized emergency vehicles. Noise resulting from any authorized emergency or public safety vehicle when responding to an emergency call or acting in the time of an emergency; (3) Safety, warning signals. Noise of safety signals, warning devices and emergency pressure valves; (4) Emergency repair. Noise resulting from emergency work needed to restore property to a safe condition after a fire, accident or natural disaster, or to restore public utilities; (5) Motor vehicles. Noise from motor vehicles in proper operating condition and properly equipped with the manufacturers' standard mufflers and noise reducing equipment; (6) Military or law enforcement activities. Noise resulting from any military or law enforcement activities of the federal, state or local government; (7) Construction noises between 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. Noise generated in construction operations between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m., so long as reasonable steps to abate construction noise are taken; (8) Landscaping noises between 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. Noise generated by lawn mowers and other landscaping equipment used between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. so long as such equipment is in proper working order and equipped with manufacturers' noise reduction equipment; (9) Bells or chimes from churches, clocks, schools, etc. Noise of any bell or chime which emanates from any church, building clock, school or public building; (10) Hunting. Noise from dogs and/or firearms while being used in a lawful hunt; and (11) Firearms used in training, sport shooting. Noise from firearms while being used in law enforcement training or sport shooting such as clay shoots, turkey shoots and the like. (e) Enforcement. The terms of this article shall be enforced by any and all qualified law enforcement officers and any person so designated by the county board of commissioners. Violations of this article may be prosecuted on accusation or summons in the magistrates court or state court. (f) Penalty. Violation of this article may be punished according to section 1-13. (Ord. of 8-3-2006)

div.head: Chapter 16 - OFFENSES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Limitation on home rule powers of municipal corporations with respect to duplication of state criminal offenses, Ga. Const. art. III, § VI, ¶ IV; violation of ordinances of counties and state authorities, O.C.G.A. § 15-10-60; Criminal Code of Georgia, O.C.G.A. § 16-1-1 et seq.; authorization to adopt ordinances for the governing and policing of the unincorporated areas of the county, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20.
Sec. 16-1. - Possession and use of alcohol. (a) No person shall consume or possess an opened container of distilled spirits, wine or malt beverages at or on any public place in the county. (b) No person shall be and appear in an intoxicated condition in any public place or within the curtilage of any private residence not his own other than by invitation of the owner or lawful occupant, which condition is made manifest by: (1) Boisterousness; (2) Indecent condition or act; or (3) Vulgar, profane, loud or unbecoming language. (c) The term "public place" includes any public park, public schoolyard, public building, public highway or road right-of-way, cemetery, any property which is owned or leased by the county or any privately owned business premises where the general public has regular access. The term "public place" does not include the area within a building which composes a business establishment properly licensed by the county to sell alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption, nor does it include the area inside a motor vehicle traveling upon any public highway or road. (d) Violations of this section shall be punished in accordance with the provisions of sections 1-10 through 1-14. (Code 1999, § 13-1; Ord. of 8-2-1990, § 1; Ord. of 7-5-1990, § 1; Ord. of 8-22-1989, §§ 1—4) State Law reference— Public drunkenness, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41. Sec. 16-2. - Tampering with public signs. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to alter, change, rearrange or damage in any way any public road sign or public directional sign erected by the county or its agents on any public right-of-way or any other location in the county. (b) It shall be the duty of any citizen of the county or any member of the public to: (1) Report to any city or county law enforcement officer the violation of this section in the manner described in this section by any member of the public; (2) Sign a written complaint against such offender; (3) Appear as a witness against such offender in a court of law; and (4) Make a citizen's arrest of any such offender in the manner authorized by the laws of the state. (c) Any person charged with and found guilty of a violation of this section shall be punished for a misdemeanor. (Code 1999, § 13-2; Ord. of 8-1-1979, §§ 1—3) Sec. 16-3. - Loud, offensive and disturbing noises. (a) Prohibited. No person shall make or continue, or cause to be made or continued, loud, offensive and disturbing noises within the unincorporated areas of the county. (b) Enumerated. Noises which shall be deemed to be loud, offensive and disturbing are as follows: (1) Radios, pianos, phonographs, etc. Any noise made within 1,000 feet of an occupied church, school, hospital, nursing home or residence which either annoys, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health or safety of others, unless the making and continuing of such noise shall be absolutely necessary for the protection or preservation of property or the health, safety, life or limb of some person. It is not the intention of this section to prohibit or interfere with the use of any radio, piano, phonograph, Victrola or other similar instrument or device used in the usual and customary manner and where sufficiently muted so as to not unduly disturb others in the same neighborhood, but applying to the use of such instruments when so operated as to cause an unusually loud and offensive disturbance to others residing in the same neighborhood. Such a noise must first be reported to the county sheriff or his lawful deputy, and the maker of such noise informed by the sheriff or his deputy that such noise is annoying, injurious or endangering the comfort, repose, health or safety of a person who is within 1,000 feet of the point of creation of the noise, and after such notice the noise is continued, before such noise shall be deemed to be a loud, offensive and disturbing noise; (2) Unnecessary blowing of bells, horns, whistles, etc. Any unnecessary blowing of any bell, horn, whistle or like sound device on any vehicle within 1,000 feet of any occupied church, school, hospital, nursing home, residence or operating business when not being sounded for emergency use in keeping with proper traffic operating procedures; provided, however, this shall not be construed to prevent the use of such sounding devices during a parade or other such organized gala celebration which occurs between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m.; or (3) Vehicles. Any vehicle that is left unattended with its engine running for more than five minutes and situated within 1,000 feet of any occupied church, school, hospital, nursing home or residence. (c) Penalty. Violations of this section shall be punished in accordance with the provisions of sections 1-10 through 1-14. (Code 1999, § 13-3; Ord. of 3-2-1989, §§ 2, 3) Sec. 16-4. - Disorderly conduct. (a) Prohibited. No person shall engage in or exhibit disorderly conduct within the unincorporated areas of the county. (b) Definition. The term "disorderly conduct" means conduct which shall be deemed to be offensive and adverse to public safety and which is exhibited or occurs when: (1) Any person acts in a violent or tumultuous manner towards another whereby any person fears for the safety of his life, limb or health; (2) Any person acts in a violent or tumultuous manner towards another whereby the property of any person is placed in danger of being destroyed or damaged; (3) Any person endangers the lawful pursuits of another by acts of violence, angry threats and abusive language; (4) Any person causes, provokes or engages in any fight, brawl or riotous act which endangers the life, limb, health or property of another; (5) Any person utters, while in a state of anger in a public place, any bawdy, lewd, obscene or fighting words or epithets directed toward another person to demean or provoke such person; or (6) Any person congregates with another in or on any public way so as to halt the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic and refuses to clear such public way when so ordered by a lawful authority. (c) Penalty. Violations of this section shall be punished in accordance with the provisions of sections 1-10 through 1-14. (Code 1999, § 13-4; Ord. of 2-1-1990, §§ 2, 3) Sec. 16-5. - Debris in ditches and canals. No person or corporation shall place or permit anyone to place any debris of any kind, including, but not limited to, logs, limbs and/or general trash, in any drainage ditches or canals along county roads or located on lands of the county, or on lands for which the county has an easement. (Code 1999, § 13-5; Ord. of 12-6-1984, § 1) Sec. 16-6. - Interfering with automobile traffic on roads. (a) No person or corporation shall engage or permit anyone to engage in any activities on county roads which, while being carried on, interferes with or impedes the normal automobile traffic thereon. (b) Violations of this section shall be punished in accordance with the provisions of sections 1-10 through 1-14. (Code 1999, § 13-6; Ord. of 12-6-1984, § 2) Sec. 16-7. - Hunting on county-owned land. (a) Prohibited generally. There shall be no hunting permitted upon any property owned by this county. (b) Exceptions. There shall be no exceptions. (c) Violation of section. Any person hunting on lands of the county other than as permitted in this section shall be deemed a trespasser. Violations of this section shall be punished in accordance with the provisions of sections 1-10 through 1-14. (Code 1999, § 13-7; Ord. of 11-1-1984, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 11-2-1995, § 1; Ord. of 12-4-1997, § 2; Ord. No. 6 of 2016, 4-7-2016) Sec. 16-8. - County boat ramps, docks or piers. (a) Swimming by any individual shall be prohibited on and within 30 feet of any and all boat ramps, docks or piers owned, maintained or operated by the county. (b) No adult shall knowingly allow any child in their care, custody, or control to swim on or within 30 feet of any and all boat ramps, docks or piers, owned, maintained or operated by the county. (c) Violation of this section may be prosecuted by summons in the magistrate court or state court. (d) Violation of this section may be punished according to the general penalties described in sections 1-14 and 1-15. (Ord. of 11-2-2006; Ord. of 6-5-2007)

div.head: Chapter 18 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Power to provide parks, recreation areas, programs and facilities, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(5); establishment of recreation systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-64-1 et seq.
Sec. 18-1. - Areas covered by chapter. The general recreational areas covered by this chapter are: (1) The County Recreation Park; (2) The Deuce Lloyd Field; (3) The Burntfort Boatramp and parking area; (4) The Traders Hill River Park and Boatramp; (5) The Camp Pinkney Boatramp, parking and picnic area; (6) The Chatman-Mobley Recreation Park; (7) Future developed recreational areas. (Code 1999, § 14-1; Res. of 3-15-1984, § II) Sec. 18-2. - Responsible use of areas. Every person authorized by the recreation director to use recreational areas will be held responsible and accountable for the proper use and protection of all property which comes under his control, and he shall not cause damage or waste to recreational property. (Code 1999, § 14-2; Res. of 3-15-1984, § III(4)) Sec. 18-3. - Nature of authorized activities. All activities in recreational areas or units under the authority granted to the recreation director shall be wholesome, carried out with proper supervision and be designed to meet the needs of the various leisure interests of the citizens of the county. (Code 1999, § 14-3; Res. of 3-15-1984, § III(1)) Sec. 18-4. - Injuries at events to be reported. Any accident to an individual on the property of a recreational facility during any event authorized by the recreation director shall be reported, in writing, to the clerk of the board of commissions or the county administrator within 24 hours after the injury. (Code 1999, § 14-4; Res. of 3-15-1984, § III(2)) Sec. 18-5. - Alcoholic beverages. The use of alcoholic beverages in any form on the premises of a recreational area or unit shall not be permitted. (Code 1999, § 14-5; Res. of 3-15-1984, § III(3)) Sec. 18-6. - Limit use of county lands for camping. (a) The county provides camping facilities with potable water and sanitation facilities for a modest fee. (b) Long-term campers on public lands of the county, especially on or near playgrounds, boat ramps, docks, swimming areas and picnic areas, pose a public health and safety risk. (c) The county must limit camping or residing on the public lands of the county to seven days at a time and no more than three separate occasions in any calendar year. The designated camping areas at Traders Hill Recreation Area is excepted from this chapter. (d) Persons in violation of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a fine not to exceed $250.00 or ten days in jail, or both. Upon being found guilty, the offender and his personal property will be removed from the public county property immediately. (Ord. No. 2008-1, 3-6-2008)

div.head: Chapter 20 - ROADS AND BRIDGES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Power to construct and maintain roads, including curbs, sidewalks, street lights and devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4); damaging public property, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25; Georgia Code of Public Transportation, O.C.G.A. § 32-1-1 et seq.; governmental authorization for construction or maintenance of any private road unlawful, O.C.G.A. § 32-1-8; county road systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-40 et seq.; grants for construction and maintenance of county roads, O.C.G.A. § 36-17-20 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 20-1. - Criteria and standards. (a) Geometric design of improvements will conform to the state department of transportation's current approved standards. The desirable conditions in these standards will apply for each project, except where physical conditions dictate that all the desirable features cannot be obtained. In these instances minimum design features may be acceptable. (b) Bridges shall be 24 feet wide, curb-to-curb, unless otherwise approved by the state highway engineer. Right-of-way requirements for a two-lane rural road section will be a minimum of 80 feet. In those instances where the county grades and drains a roadway at its own expense on projects with less than 80 feet of right-of-way but not less than 60 feet of right-of-way, the base and pavement may be provided through a county contract, but in all instances the roadway must be adequately drained. For city street improvements, the minimum width for a two-lane connector street shall be no less than 28 feet, curb-to-curb. Minimum right-of-way width for this section shall be 40 feet. Where a rural section is designed for a city street, the minimum right-of-way shall be 60 feet. On arterial streets or streets on the state highway system where county contracts are authorized the width shall be not less than 44, feet, curb-to-curb, on a right-of-way of 60 feet. Streets which are proposed to be four lanes or are to be constructed initially as two lanes and expected to require four lanes in the future to serve anticipated traffic volumes, shall be no less than 48 feet, curb-to-curb. Minimum right-of-way width for this section shall be 60 feet. These widths are to be at least 64 feet and 80 feet respectively, when parking is to be permitted. Minimum right-of-way width for projects which involve only resurfacing of existing pavements shall be that required for the resurfacing and to provide for adequate drainage. In all of the above right-of-way requirements a lesser right-of-way width shall be considered where the district engineer certifies that the lesser width is adequate for construction, drainage and maintenance of the project. (Code 1999, § 15-1; Mo. of 2-4-1982) Sec. 20-2. - Driveway drainage pipes. (a) The county shall install all driveway drainage pipes. (b) The cost to the requesting land owner shall be uniform and established from time to time by resolution of the board of commissioners. (Code 1999, § 15-2; Res. of 8-22-1975, § 4; Ord. No. 15 of 2018, 5-17-2018) Sec. 20-3. - PVC pipe. Plastic pipe with a minimum wall thickness of three-fourths inches (PVC) may be used for driveways upon approval by the road superintendent. (Code 1999, § 15-3; Mo. of 5-3-1990) Secs. 20-4—20-24. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - UTILITY ENCROACHMENTS[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Obstructing, encroaching on, or injuring public roads, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-1.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 20-25. - Violation of article. (a) No person accused of violating this article shall be arrested prior to trial, but any defendant who fails to appear for trial shall be arrested thereafter on the warrant of the magistrate and shall be required to post a bond for his future appearance. (b) Nothing in this article shall prevent the board of commissioners from bringing any civil action to present, correct or abate any violation of this article. No penalty or remedy prescribed in this Code shall be considered exclusive of any other remedy, but shall be available in addition to any other penalty or remedy by law. (Code 1999, § 15-31; Ord. of 6-20-1985, §§ 3(b), 4(c)) Sec. 20-26. - Location of utilities. All utilities crossing the right-of-way should be placed three feet below the ditch bottom and those running parallel with the right-of-way or the roadway should be placed either two feet inside the right-of-way on the back slope or on paved roads three feet from the edge of the pavement 2.5 feet deep. Cuts may not exceed 12 inches. (Code 1999, § 15-32; Ord. of 2-4-1976, § 1) Sec. 20-27. - Allocation of costs. (a) The entire cost of installing, maintaining, repairing, operating or using the pole line, buried cable, pipeline or miscellaneous facility, performing miscellaneous operations and any other expense whatsoever incidental to the facilities or operations authorized by the permit shall be paid for by the applicant. (b) The applicant shall, in addition to the payment required by subsection (a) of this section, reimburse the county for any reasonable and necessary expense that the department may incur in connection with the facilities or operation authorized by the permit required by this article. The reimbursement to the county shall be made by the applicant within 30 days after receiving a statement from the chairperson of the county board of commissioners. (c) The applicant, upon notification in writing by the county manager, shall pay a reasonable market price for any materials removed from the right-of-way or destroyed as a result of operations authorized by the permit. (Code 1999, § 15-33; Ord. of 2-4-1976, § 1) Sec. 20-28. - Safety requirements. (a) The applicant shall employ any and all methods in performing the operations authorized by the permit required by this article which the chairperson of the board of commissioners or designated agent may require in order to properly protect the public from injury and the highway from damage. (b) During the initial installation or construction of the facilities authorized by the permit, or during any future repair, removal or relocation thereof, or during any miscellaneous operations, the applicant shall at all times maintain such flagmen, signs, lights, flares, barricades and other safety devices as the chairperson may reasonably deem necessary to properly protect traffic upon the highway, and to warn and safeguard the public against injury or damage. The applicant shall maintain a watchman, as required, to maintain such signs, flares, barricades and other safety devices during nonwork hours and shall upon request furnish the county warden the telephone number and/or address of such watchman. (c) The applicant shall so conduct his operations so that there will be a minimum of interference with or interruption of traffic upon and along the highway. Except in emergencies, there shall be no interference with or interruption of traffic upon and along the road or highway until a plan for the satisfactory handling of traffic has been worked out and approved by the chairperson of the board of commissioners or the county road superintendent as soon as practicable. (d) All roads should be bored where feasibly possible. Dry bore or controlled wet bore shall be employed. (e) Any supervision and/or control exercised by the county road superintendent shall in no way relieve the applicant of any duty or responsibility to the general public, nor shall such supervision and/or control relieve the applicant from any liability for loss, damage or injury to persons or property. (Code 1999, § 15-34; Ord. of 2-4-1976, § 1) Sec. 20-29. - Repairing of cuts. Any area where grass is destroyed shall be re-grassed. All applicants shall comply with the following county specifications: (1) All cuts across or into county paved roads shall: a. First, be tamped by pneumatic tamp. b. Filled with eight inches of concrete. c. Finished with two inches of asphalt. (2) Final inspection shall be approved by either the chairperson of the board of commissioners or a designated agent, i.e., county road superintendent. (3) The applicant shall re-grass to state highway department specifications all county right-of-way area which is damaged or disturbed during work authorized in this section. (Code 1999, § 15-35; Ord. of 2-4-1976, § 1) Sec. 20-30. - County's right to cause taking up of relocating facility. If the board of commissioners should in the future decide to relocate or widen the existing road, the county reserves the right to require the utility owner to take up and relay such sections of the facility which may be necessary from an engineering standpoint. The taking up and relaying shall be at the expense of the utility owner, without regard to the type of road construction or maintenance work involved. (Code 1999, § 15-36; Ord. of 2-4-1976, § 1) Secs. 20-31—20-48. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - UTILITY PERMITS
Sec. 20-49. - Required; application, plan. (a) It shall be unlawful for any utility facility, public, private or otherwise, to encroach upon any public road maintained by the county outside the city limits of any municipality in the county, except rural road projects, without first applying to and obtaining a permit from the board of commissioners. Such application shall be in substantially the following form:
Application is hereby made by (Name of Applicant—Utility Owner—Municipality) _____ (Mailing Address) For permission to make the following described utility installation within the limit of rights-of-way for County Maintained Road No. ____________ in Charlton County: Description of utility to be installed, etc.: _____ Location of utility and/or any other to be installed: _____ The utility covered hereby shall be installed with the attached plan and subject to the printed Rules and Regulations for the Control and Protection of County Maintained Roads and Rights-Of-Way, on file in the county commissioners' office and made a part hereof by reference thereto, and particularly to the applicable provisions of the Rules and Regulations shown on page 2 of this permit and any special requirements set forth herein, and applicant by making this application hereby agrees to comply with and be bound by such Rules and Regulations. Special requirements: (as shown on page 2) Permit requested this ____________ day of ____________ / ____________ / ____________ , 20 ____________ .
Permit granted to make the above described Utility Facility and/or any installation in accordance with the applicable section of the printed Rules and Regulations hereby made a part of this permit by reference thereto, this ____________ day of ____________ / ____________ / ____________ , 20 ____________ . This permit is to be strictly construed and no work other than that specifically described above is hereby authorized. Subsequent normal maintenance excepted.
The installation described on this permit form has been completed in accordance with the provisions of the permit and the plan attached hereto. Date _____ Signed _____ (b) The application shall include: (1) Name and a mailing address of owner or lessee, statement and description of the type of work intended and three copies of a plan. The plan should show the centerline and the right-of-way line indicating width, also the width of pavement, the location of existing driveways and drainage structures, elevation and/or sections when necessary and the boundaries of the contemplated work. When the grading is proposed, the drainage plan shall be shown. The plan must contain a certified plat or drawing showing the exact location where the utility line or structure shall be placed including the depth of any underground line. (2) County, state route number, and distance from geographical point such as intersecting highways, city or village corporate limits, or county highways. (Code 1999, § 15-46; Ord. of 2-4-1976, § 1; Ord. of 6-2-1983) Sec. 20-50. - Qualifications of applicants. Applications for permits pursuant to this division will be accepted only from a political entity, an individual, partnership or corporation, or other body recognized by law as owning all or the major interest in the property abutting the highway right-of-way, or the proposed facility, which will be principally affected by the performance of the work covered by the permit or by the lessee of property or business. Such qualified persons will be referred to in this division as applicants. (Code 1999, § 15-47; Ord. of 2-4-1976, § 1) Sec. 20-51. - Place of filing. Application and permit forms required by this division will be filed with the county clerk's office. (Code 1999, § 15-48; Ord. of 2-4-1976, § 1) Sec. 20-52. - Specifications. (a) Enumerated. The provision of any permit granted pursuant to this division shall be construed as regulatory and not as contractual.
