No interest or right of an applicant shall be transferred to another except by written consent of the board of commissioners. No inherent or retained right or privilege belonging to any abutting property owner is affected, interfered with or abridged through, or because of, this division or any permit issued pursuant to this division, nor is the county or state highway department responsible for any damage claim which may arise between the applicant and any property owner concerning such right-of-way, its occupancy or use. (b) County manager's decision final. The decision of the county manager or his designated agent shall be final and conclusive with respect to any of the conditions, terms, stipulations and provisions of the permit. This shall not foreclose the applicants' right of appeal. (Code 1999, § 15-49; Ord. of 2-4-1976, § 1) Sec. 20-53. - Costs. The board of commissioners shall establish, from time to time, the amount of the charges for permits for right-of-way encroachments. (Code 1999, § 15-50; Ord. of 2-4-1976, § 1) Sec. 20-54. - Revocation. Any permit granted by the county manager or his designee shall be revocable at the pleasure of the county manager. If any facilities after construction become dangerous, unsafe or a nuisance to the traveling public using the highways, or if such facilities should create any unreasonable interference with the proper use of the highways by the traveling public, or in case it becomes necessary to use all the right-of-way to widen the existing roadway or to construct service roads or to make any other revisions in location, alignment or grade of the roadway, making the approved entrance plan impractical, hazardous or otherwise objectionable, the permit for such work may be revoked; provided, however, that the permittee shall be given ten days' written notice prior to such revocation. (Code 1999, § 15-51; Ord. of 2-4-1976, § 1)

div.head: Chapter 22 - SOLID WASTE[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Municipal authority to provide for garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. 1983, Art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(2); Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.; transporting garbage or waste across state or county boundaries pursuant to contract, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-16; Resource Recovery Development Authorities Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-63-1 et seq.; littering highways, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-249.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 22-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Garbage means household or office waste, including, but not limited to, rubbish, paper, cartons, boxes, tin cans, food waste, glass, plastic containers, metal, cloth, ashes and other nondescript items of waste as may be otherwise identified as garbage. Refuse means wood, tree branches, yard trimmings, furniture, appliances, street debris, dead animals, animal manure, tires, construction waste, food processing waste, demolition waste, dredging waste, sewage sludge, industrial waste including sludge and all forms of waste generated in industrial operations, residue from incineration and any other waste material in a solid or semisolid state not otherwise defined or stated. (Code 1999, § 16-1; Res. of 10-24-1989, § 1) Sec. 22-2. - Enforcement. The sheriff, the deputies, the constables and all other law enforcement officers shall be authorized to issue citations to violators of any provisions of this chapter in accordance with the provisions of section 1-10. (Code 1999, § 16-2; Res. of 10-24-1989, § 3) Sec. 22-3. - Violation; penalty. (a) Any person violating this chapter or any provision hereof, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in sections 1-13 and 1-14. (b) Violations of this chapter shall be tried in the magistrate court or state court, and shall be tried in accordance with state law. (c) Nothing in this chapter shall prevent the board of commissioners from bringing any civil action to present, correct or abate any violation of this chapter. No penalty or remedy prescribed in this section shall be considered exclusive of any other remedy, but shall be available in addition to any other penalty or remedy by law. (d) Each violation of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense. (Code 1999, § 16-3; Res. of 10-24-1989, § 4) Secs. 22-4—22-24. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 22-25. - Disposal not to create nuisance. No garbage or refuse may be disposed of in any manner which would create a nuisance. (Code 1999, § 16-31; Res. of 10-24-1989, § 2(D)) Sec. 22-26. - Disturbing, scattering waste. No person shall disturb or scatter garbage or refuse in and around any garbage or refuse collection containers. (Code 1999, § 16-32; Res. of 10-2419-89, § 2(G)) Sec. 22-27. - Property owner's approval required. No person shall place, deposit, put, throw or by any manner dispose of garbage or refuse on any public or private property not especially approved for garbage or refuse and authorized by the owner thereof. (Code 1999, § 16-33; Res. of 10-24-1989, § 2(H)) Sec. 22-28. - Responsibility of resident. The owner or occupant of any premises must be responsible for the sanitary handling of garbage and refuse on the premises occupied by him. (Code 1999, § 16-34; Res. of 10-24-1989, § 2(C)) Sec. 22-29. - Bulk container service. (a) Where the county provides a bulk containerized waste collection system, containers will be serviced and emptied each week. (b) Persons using the container shall deposit all garbage and other acceptable refuse inside the container. (c) No person shall set fire to the contents of any container. (d) No person shall deposit any burning or smoldering material in any container. (e) No dead animals shall be deposited in any container. (f) No person shall deposit large noncompatible articles in containers such as stoves, refrigerators, bed springs, tires, large tree limbs or similar items. (g) No person shall deposit any flammable or explosive materials in any container. (h) No person shall willfully damage or alter the location of any container without the consent of the board of commissioners. (i) The collection of garbage or refuse and the manner thereof will be at the discretion of the county. (Code 1999, § 16-35; Res. of 10-24-1989, § 2(F)) Sec. 22-30. - Landfill. Garbage or refuse generated in the county not disposed of in containers that may be provided by the county must be deposited in a landfill that has been issued a permit by the state; however, no person shall: (1) Set fire to any of the garbage or refuse disposed of at county landfills. (2) Deposit tires in any location other than a tire waste receiving and disposal facility that has been approved of and issued a permit by the state. (Code 1999, § 16-36; Res. of 10-24-1989, § 2(E)) Sec. 22-31. - Depositing tires; location. No tires shall be deposited in any dumpsters. (Code 1999, § 16-38; Ord. of 9-5-1991, § 2) Sec. 22-32. - Vehicles for hauling waste. (a) All collection vehicles hauling wet or moist garbage or refuse must be sufficiently watertight. (b) All open vehicles shall be covered when hauling garbage or refuse. (Code 1999, § 16-39; Res. of 10-24-1989, § 2(A), (B)) Secs. 22-33—22-56. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - YARD TRIMMINGS DISPOSAL REGULATIONS
Sec. 22-57. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Commercial solid waste means all types of solid waste generated by stores, offices, restaurants, warehouses and other nonmanufacturing activities, excluding residential and industrial wastes. Composting means the controlled biological decomposition of organic matter into a stable, odor-free humus. Leachate collection system means a system at a landfill for collection of the leachate which may percolate through the waste and into the soils surrounding the landfill. Municipal solid waste means any solid waste derived from households, including garbage, trash and sanitary waste in septic tanks and includes solid waste from single-family and multifamily residences, hotels and motels, bunkhouses, campgrounds, picnic grounds and day use recreation areas. The term "municipal solid waste" includes yard trimmings and commercial solid waste, but does not include solid waste from mining, agricultural or silvicultural operations or industrial processes or operations. Municipal solid waste disposal facility means any facility or location where the final deposition of any amount of municipal solid waste occurs, whether or not mixed with or including commercial or industrial solid waste, including, but not limited to, municipal solid waste landfills. Municipal solid waste landfill means a disposal facility where any amount of municipal solid waste, whether or not mixed with or including commercial waste, industrial waste, nonhazardous sludges or small quantity generator hazardous waste, is disposed of by means of placing an approved cover thereon. Yard trimmings means leaves, brush, grass clippings, shrub and tree prunings, discarded Christmas trees, nursery and greenhouse vegetative residuals and vegetative matter resulting from landscaping development and maintenance, other than mining, agricultural and silvicultural operations. (Code 1999, § 16-66; Ord. of 10-3-1996, § 2) Sec. 22-58. - Placement and disposal of yard trimmings; prohibitions. (a) No person shall place or mix yard trimmings with municipal solid waste within the unincorporated area of the county and within any municipality located in the county which has not adopted substantially similar provisions as this division. (b) Yard debris must be separated from man-made debris. County will not pick up anything not separated. • Yard debris include trees, leaves, and limbs. • Man-made debris include old furniture, plastic, water hoses, toys, swing sets, ladders, mattresses, patio sets, treated and untreated lumber. (c) Debris must be placed within five feet of the property access point from which the debris originated. (d) Only yard debris, or man-made debris, will be picked up from residences. No pick up of debris from any business. Commercial businesses must make separate arrangements with commercial garbage companies. (e) No pick up of yard debris as a result of lot/land clearing, development, or major landscaping activities. The maximum size pile is five cubic yards. Amounts of debris larges than this must be disposed of by the resident/owner/developer through other means. Licensed contractors are responsible for the removal and disposal from their work sites. (f) No pick up of any man-made debris as a result of any major construction or demolition. The maximum size pile of man-made debris is five cubic yards. New construction or remodeling by contractors cannot be accepted. Licensed contractors are responsible for the removal and disposal from their work sites. (g) County will not pick up metal goods (freezers, refrigerators, washers, and dryers). Metal items can be disposed at commercial locations that accept metal. (Code 1999, § 16-67; Ord. of 10-3-1996, § 3; Ord. No. 14 of 2018, 5-17-2018) Sec. 22-59. - Methods of sorting, storing or handling of yard trimmings. The productivity of the soils requires that nature's way of recycling vegetative matter be respected and such matter should be returned to the soil rather than being wastes by being buried in landfills. Therefore, as set forth by the general assembly of the state, and codified in O.C.G.A. § 12-8-21(g), the following is recommended to all persons in the county for the handling of yard trimmings: (1) Naturalized, low-maintenance landscaping requiring little or no cutting; (2) Grass cycling by mowing it high and letting it lie; (3) Stacking branches into brush piles for use as wildlife habitats and for gradual decomposition into the soil; (4) Composting on the site where the material was grown, followed by incorporation of the finished compost into the soil at that site; (5) Chipping woody material on the site where such material was generated; (6) Collecting yard trimmings and transporting them to another site to be chipped or composted for later use; and (7) Chipping woody material for later use as fiber fuel. (Code 1999, § 16-68) Sec. 22-60. - Penalties. Any person violating section 22-58 shall be punished according to the general penalties described in sections 1-13 and 1-14. (Code 1999, § 16-69) Sec. 22-61. - Enforcement. (a) The county sheriff, the deputies, any designated county ordinance or code enforcement officer and all other law enforcement officers shall be authorized to issue citations to violators of any provisions of this division. Such citation shall state the time and place at which the accused is to appear for trial, shall identify the offense with which the accused is charged, shall have an identifying number by which it shall be filed with the court and shall be signed by the officer who completes and services it. (b) No person accused of violating this division shall be arrested prior to trial, but any defendant who fails to appear for trial shall be arrested thereafter on the warrant of the magistrate and required to post a bond for his future appearance. (Code 1999, § 16-70; Ord. of 10-3-1996, § 6)

div.head: Chapter 24 - TAXATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Taxation power of county governments, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV, ¶ I(a) and (b)(2); county taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-220.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 24-1. - Exemptions for certain classes of goods (Freeport exemption). (a) Authority for section. This section and the tax exemptions provided for in this section are made under authority of Ga. Const. art. VII, § I, ¶ III, as amended (1976 Ga. Laws (Act No. 118), pages 1755 through 1759). (b) Unfinished goods. There is hereby exempted from taxation 20 percent of the value of the inventory of goods in the county in the process of manufacture or production which shall include all partly finished goods and raw materials held for direct use or consumption in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's manufacturing or production business in the state. The exemption provided for in this subsection shall apply only to tangible personal property which is substantially modified, altered or changed in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's manufacturing, processing or production operations in this state. (c) Finished goods in storage. There is hereby exempted from taxation 20 percent of the value of the inventory of finished goods which, on January 1, are stored in a warehouse, dock or wharf, whether public or private, in the county and which are destined for shipment to a final destination outside the state and inventory of finished goods which are shipped into the state from outside this state and stored for transshipment to a final destination outside this state. The exemption provided for in this subsection shall be for a period not exceeding 12 months from the date such property is stored in this state. (Code 1999, § 17-1; Res. of 4-2-1981, §§ 1, 2, 4) State Law reference— Ad valorem taxation of property, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-1 et seq. Secs. 24-2—24-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Taxation of financial institutions generally, O.C.G.A. § 48-6-90 et seq.; authorization to levy and collect a business license tax from depository financial institutions, O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93.
Sec. 24-21. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Depository financial institution means any state or national bank, state building and loan association and federal savings and loan association. Gross receipts means gross receipts as defined in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. (Code 1999, § 17-26; Res. of 11-3-1983, § 1) Sec. 24-22. - Levy; rate. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93, there is hereby levied for each year an annual business license tax upon all depository financial institutions located within the county at a rate of 0.25 percent of the gross receipts of the depository financial institutions. (Code 1999, § 17-27; Res. of 11-3-1983, § 1) Sec. 24-23. - Minimum amount. The minimum annual amount of the business license tax due from any depository financial institution pursuant to section 24-21 shall be $1,000.00. (Code 1999, § 17-28; Res. of 11-3-1983, § 2) Sec. 24-24. - Filing of return. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93(c), each depository financial institution subject to this tax shall file a return of its gross receipts with the board of commissioners on March 1 of the year following the year in which such gross receipts are measured. The return shall be in the manner and in the form prescribed by the commissioner of the department of revenue based on the allocation method set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93(d). The board of commissioners shall assess and collect the tax levied pursuant to this article based upon the information provided in the return. (Code 1999, § 17-29; Res. of 11-3-1983, § 3) Sec. 24-25. - Due date. Taxes levied pursuant to this article shall be due no later than 30 days after filing of the return prescribed by section 24-24 unless extended by the board of commissioners. (Code 1999, § 17-30; Res. of 11-3-1983, § 4) Secs. 24-26—24-53. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - INSURANCE OTHER THAN LIFE INSURANCE[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— General assembly authorized to provide for taxation of insurance companies based on gross direct premiums received from insurance policies within the unincorporated areas of counties, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV, ¶ I(c); powers of municipal corporations to impose license fees on life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8; local tax on life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1; local tax on other than life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2.
Sec. 24-54. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Gross direct premiums means gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2(a). (Code 1999, § 17-51; Res. of 9-1-1983, § 1) Sec. 24-55. - Levy. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2, there is hereby levied for each year an annual tax upon each insurer doing insurance business within the unincorporated area of the county, in an amount equal to 2.5 percent of the gross direct premiums received during the calendar year on all insurance other than life insurance as defined in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5(2) through (6). (Code 1999, § 17-52; Res. of 9-1-1983, § 1) Secs. 24-56—24-83. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - SALES AND USE
Sec. 24-84. - County-city local sales and use tax levied (LOST tax). The board of commissioners is authorized to levy a combination county-city local sales and use tax as approved by referendum of the county citizens and a joint agreement with any city located within the county territories. (Code 1999, § 17-76; Res. of 3-29-1979; Mo. of 5-4-1979) State Law reference— Counties and municipalities authorized to levy joint sales and use tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-8-82. Sec. 24-85. - Local sales and use tax levied (SPLOST tax). The county hereby levies a local sales and use tax of one percent in the county. (Code 1999, § 17-77; Res. of 12-7-1977) Secs. 24-86—24-113. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - BUSINESS OCCUPATION TAX[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- State Law reference— Business and occupation taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-2 et seq.
Sec. 24-114. - Short title. This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Charlton County Business and Occupational Tax Ordinance." (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 1) Sec. 24-115. - Occupational tax required for business dealings in the county. For each year, each person, or other nonexempt entity, engaged in a business, trade, profession or occupation in the unincorporated aspect of the county (or in the case of an out-of-state business with no location in the state but exerting substantial efforts within the county as per O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7) shall pay an occupation tax for said business, trade, profession or occupation; a business tax registration certificate shall be conspicuously displayed in the taxpayer's place of business, if the taxpayer has a permanent business location in the county. If the taxpayer has no permanent business location in the county, such business tax certificate shall be shown to the clerk of the board of commissioners, or any designee of the county board of commissioners or to any law enforcement officer of the county, upon request. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 2) Sec. 24-116. - Purpose and scope of tax. The business and occupation tax levied herein is for revenue purposes only and is not for regulatory purposes, nor is the payment of the tax made a condition precedent to the practice of any such profession, trade, or calling. The tax only applies to those businesses and occupations which are covered by the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-5 through 48-13-26. Any other applicable business licenses imposed pursuant to general state law and/or local ordinance are not repealed, included or affected in any manner by this article. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 3) Sec. 24-117. - Construction of term; definitions. (a) The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Business tax or occupation tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations, or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession or business for revenue raising purposes. Jurisdiction means the unincorporated areas of the county. Person includes sole proprietors, corporations, partnerships, nonprofits or any other form of business organization, but specifically excludes charitable nonprofit organizations qualified as a 501(c) entity by federal law. Practitioner or professional means a person who by state law is required to possess state licensure in order to engage in such profession, practice or occupation. (b) The definitions set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-5 (Specific, Business, and Occupation Taxes—Definitions), shall be effective as definitions of the words, terms and phrases used in this article. All words, terms and phrases used herein, other than those specifically defined elsewhere in this article, shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-5 and shall have the same scope and effect that the same words, terms and phrases have where used in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-5. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 4) Sec. 24-118. - Occupation tax levied; restrictions. (a) An occupation tax shall be levied upon those businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations with one or more locations or offices in the unincorporated area of the county and/or upon the applicable out-of-state businesses with no location or office in the state as per O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7 based upon the following criteria: A flat fee as per O.C.G.A. § 48-13-10(a)(4). (b) The county board of commissioners shall, by resolution, adopt a flat fee, the amount of which shall be within the discretion of the board and may, from time to time, be altered, in compliance with section 24-140. (c) No business or practitioner shall be required to pay more than one occupation tax for each of its locations. No occupation tax shall be required from those real estate brokers, real estate agents, or real estate companies whose offices are located outside the jurisdiction and who sell property inside the jurisdiction. (d) Where a business subject to the tax levied by this article begins operation in the first half of the calendar year, then the full tax shall be paid; if the business begins operation after July 1, then one-half of the tax shall be paid. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 5) Sec. 24-119. - Paying occupation tax of business with no location in the state. The requirements of this article shall apply fully to those businesses and practitioners of professions with no location or office in the state if the subject person's or entity's largest dollar volume of business in the state is in the county and the business or practitioner: (1) Has one or more employees or agents who exert substantial efforts within the jurisdiction of the county for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients; or (2) Owns personal or real property which generates income and which is located within the jurisdiction of the county. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 6) Sec. 24-120. - Each line of business to be identified on business registration. The business registration of each business operated in the county's jurisdiction shall identify the line or lines of business that the business conducts. No business shall conduct any line of business without first having that line of business registered with the county and that line of business being noted by the county government upon the business registration form which is to be displayed by the business owner. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 7) Sec. 24-121. - The number of businesses considered to be operating in the county. Where a person conducts business at more than one fixed location, each location or place shall be considered a separate business for the purpose of the occupation tax. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 8) Sec. 24-122. - Professionals as classified in state law. Practitioners of professions as described in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c)(1) through (18) shall pay the same flat fee as a tax as is required of all businesses. Provided however, any professional or practitioner whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the United States, this state, a municipality or county of the state, instrumentalities of the United States, this state or a municipality or county of the state shall not be required to obtain a license or pay an occupation tax for that practice. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 9) Sec. 24-123. - When tax due and payable; effect of transacting business when tax delinquent. (a) Each such occupation tax shall be for the current calendar year, and succeeding calendar years thereafter unless otherwise specifically provided. Said registration and occupation tax shall be payable January 1 of each year and shall, if not paid by March 31 of each year, be subject to penalties for delinquency as prescribed in this article. On any new profession, trade or calling begun in the county, the registration and tax shall be due immediately upon beginning business. A ten percent penalty shall be imposed if the tax levied herein has not been paid within 90 days of its due date. The tax registration herein provided for shall be issued by the clerk of the county commission and if any person, firm or corporation whose duty it is to obtain a registration shall, after said registration or occupation tax becomes delinquent, transact or offer to transact, in the county, any of the kind of profession, trade or calling subject to this article without having first obtained said registration, such offender shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine and/or imprisonment as provided in this article. (b) In addition to the remedies in subsection (a) of this section, the tax may be collected in the same manner as provided by law for tax executions; the clerk of the board of commissioners is authorized to issue executions against the delinquent taxpayer as provided for by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-26(a). (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 10) Sec. 24-124. - Exemption on grounds that business is operated for charitable purpose. No business on which a business registration or occupation tax is levied by this article shall be exempt from said registration or tax on the ground that such business is operated as a charitable nonprofit organization qualified as a 501(c) entity by federal law. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 11) Sec. 24-125. - Liability of officers and agents; registration required; failure to obtain. Any person subject to the occupation tax levy pursuant to this article shall be required to obtain the necessary registration for said business as described in this article, and in default thereof the officer or agent soliciting for or representing such persons shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons who fail to obtain a registration. Any business required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency or any other regulatory matter shall first, before the issuance of a the county business registration, show evidence that such requirements have been met; no registration shall issue in the absence of such proof. Every person commencing business in the county after January 1 of each year shall likewise obtain the registration herein provided for before commencing the same; and any person transacting, or offering to transact in the county, any of the kinds of business, trade, profession or occupation without first having so obtained said registration, shall be subject to penalties provided herein. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 12) Sec. 24-126. - Businesses not covered by this article. The following businesses are not covered by the provisions of this article, but may be assessed an occupation tax or other type of tax pursuant to the provisions of other general laws of the state or by local law: (1) Those businesses regulated by the state service commission. (2) Those electrical service businesses organized under chapter 3, title 46 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. (3) Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including agribusiness. (4) Cooperative marketing associations governed by O.C.G.A. § 2-10-105. (5) Insurance companies governed by O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8 et seq. (6) Motor common carriers governed by O.C.G.A. § 46-7-15. (7) Those businesses governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-355. (Businesses that purchase carload lots of guano, meats, meal, flour, bran, cottonseed or cottonseed meal and hulls.) (8) Agricultural products and livestock raised in the state governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-356. (9) Depository financial institutions governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. (10) Facilities operated by a charitable trust governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-55. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 13) Sec. 24-127. - License duration. Each license issued under the provisions of this article shall be valid for the calendar year in which issued. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 14) Sec. 24-128. - Transfers prohibited. No tax registration certificate issued under this article shall be transferable; and no registration certificate shall be exchanged for a registration certificate for a different type of business. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 15) Sec. 24-129. - Application. (a) Every person subject to the tax levied under this article shall, on or before January 31 of each year, or prior to engaging in said business, file with the clerk of the county commission or other designee of the county board of commissioners an application for a county business and occupational tax registration certificate. (b) Every person subject to the tax shall make application for said registration certificate on forms provided by the county, setting forth the following information: (1) Name of business/occupation. (2) Location. (3) Exact nature of business/occupation for which a registration certificate is requested. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 16) Sec. 24-130. - Veterans. Persons who can qualify for a state veterans free license under O.C.G.A. § 43-12-1, must secure such license from the state and present same to the county clerk, who will honor same and issue a county business and occupation tax registration certificate without requiring payment of the tax and mark said registration certificate "Exempt from Tax." (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 17) Sec. 24-131. - Displaying registration certificate. All persons having paid the tax required by this article shall exhibit the registration certificate, or receipt therefor, issued them by the county clerk in a conspicuous place in the office or quarters of such establishment or place of business. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 18) Sec. 24-132. - Location of business. Registration certificates granted under this article shall not authorize the holder thereof to exercise or carry on the trade, business or profession named therein at any other place than that mentioned in said registration certificate. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 19) Sec. 24-133. - Change of location. Upon removal of any taxpayer from the premises at which the trade, business or profession identified on the registration certificate was authorized to be conducted, it may and shall be lawful for the county clerk, by endorsement upon such registration certificate, to authorize the taxpayer, removing as foresaid to any other location, to carry on the trade, business or profession under such certificate. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 20) Sec. 24-134. - Refund to discontinued business. When the tax fixed by this article has been paid during the first half of the calendar year and the person paying such tax discontinues the business during the first half of the calendar year, the county clerk may refund one-half of said year's tax, provided all other license fee and other taxes owed by the taxpayer to the county have been paid, and provided application therefor is made within 30 days after discontinuing business. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 21) Sec. 24-135. - Restrictions. No person shall be issued a county business and occupation tax registration certificate as provided for in this article who is required to hold a license issued by the state to engage in the business, profession or trade which the person seeks to engage in, or is required to obtain health permits, or any other such regulatory permit or license, unless the person has a valid and current state license, or shows evidence that all regulatory requirements have been met and attaches a copy of same to the application. Any revocation or suspension of a person's state license or permit will cause an immediate termination or suspension of said person's registration certificate issued by the county. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 22) Sec. 24-136. - Enforcement. The county sheriff, the deputies, constables and all other law enforcement officers, the county clerk, or other designee of the county board of commissioners shall be authorized to issue citations to violators of any provisions of this article. Such citation shall state the time and place at which the accused is to appear for trial, shall identify the offense with which the accused is charged, shall be signed by the officer who completes and services it and the original shall be filed with magistrates court of the county or the state court of the county. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 23) Sec. 24-137. - Penalty. Any person violating any provisions hereof, upon conviction, shall be punished according to the general penalty described in section 1-13. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 24) Sec. 24-138. - Court proceedings. (a) Violations of this article shall be tried upon citation as described in section 24-136 and may be tried with or without a prosecuting attorney as well as upon accusation. (b) Violations of this article shall be tried in the magistrate court or the state court. (c) Nothing in this article shall prevent the commissioners of the county from bringing any civil action to present, correct or abate any violation of this article. No penalty or remedy prescribed herein shall be considered exclusive of any other remedy, but shall be available in addition to any other penalty or remedy by law. (d) Each violation of this article shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 25) Sec. 24-139. - Applications of provisions or prior ordinance. This article does not repeal or affect the force of any part of any ordinance heretofore passed where taxes or fees levied under such prior ordinance have not been paid in full. So much and such parts of ordinances heretofore and hereafter passed as provided for the issuing and enforcing of execution for any tax or assessment required by such ordinances, or that imposed fines or penalties for the nonpayment of such tax, or for failure to pay regulatory fees provided for in said ordinance or ordinances, or failure to comply with any other provisions thereof, shall continue and remain in force until such tax, fee or assessment shall be fully paid. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 26) Sec. 24-140. - Requirement of public hearing before tax increase. The board of commissioners shall conduct a least one public hearing before adopting any ordinance or resolution which will increase the rate of occupation tax as set forth in this article. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(02), § 27) Secs. 24-141—24-165. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - PREPAID WIRELESS[5]
Footnotes: --- (5) --- State Law reference— Georgia Emergency Telephone Number 9-1-1 Service Act of 1977, O.C.G.A. § 46-5-120 et seq.
Sec. 24-166. - 9-1-1 charge on prepaid wireless transactions. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134.2, there is hereby imposed a prepaid wireless 9-1-1 charge, as defined by O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134.2(a)(4), upon every prepaid wireless retail transaction occurring within the jurisdiction of the public service answering point in the amount of $0.75. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(01), § 1) Sec. 24-167. - Collection of 9-1-1 charge on prepaid wireless transactions. Prepaid wireless 9-1-1 charges collected by sellers shall be remitted to the commissioner of the department of revenue at the times and in the manner provided by chapter 8, title 48 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated with respect to the sales and use tax imposed on prepaid wireless calling service. (Ord. of 8-4-2011(01), § 2) Sec. 24-168. - Depositing of funds; use of funds. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134.2(j)(5), funds received by this county from charges imposed by this article shall be deposited in the emergency telephone system fund maintained by the county pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134 and kept separate from general revenue of the jurisdiction; all such funds shall be used exclusively for the purposes authorized by O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134(e). (Ord. of 8-4-2011(01), § 4)

div.head: Chapter 26 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1]
Chapter 101 - GENERAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS
div.p: Sec. 101-1. - Title. The title of this subpart shall be known as the "Land Development Code of the County of Charlton, Georgia." This subpart may also be cited as the "Land Development Code" or the "LDC." Sec. 101-2. - Applicability of subpart A, chapter 1. Unless otherwise stated or where the context of the provision clearly shows a different intent, the provisions of chapter 1 under subpart A, General Code of Ordinances, shall apply to the titles contained in this subpart. Sec. 101-3. - Fee requirements. Reasonable fees to offset the costs of administration of this subpart may be set by resolution of the board of county commissioners, from time to time, unless state law requires them to be established by ordinance.

div.head: Chapter 110 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Authority of city or county to provide codes, including building, housing, plumbing and electrical codes, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(12); adoption and continuation of state minimum standard codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-21; statewide application of minimum standard codes, codes requiring adoption by municipality or county, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25; enforcement of codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26; providing of fire escapes by building owners, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-50; access to and use of public facilities by physically handicapped persons, O.C.G.A. § 30-3-1 et seq.; authority to repair, close or demolish unfit buildings or structures, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 110-1. - Multifamily residence and multifamily dwelling defined. The terms "multifamily residence" and "multifamily dwelling" shall be used interchangeably to mean any structure constructed with the intent that there be more than one distinct habitation located therein. Characteristics which typify a multifamily residence or dwelling include, but are not limited to: (1) Separated entrances to divided living space located under a common roof; (2) Habitations sharing common load-bearing walls; (3) Separate bathrooms located under a common roof which cannot be accessed from all areas within the subject structure; (4) Separate kitchens and/or cooking facilities located under a common roof which cannot be accessed from all areas within the subject structure; (5) Separate power service for habitations sited in a common structure; and (6) Any other relevant factor. (Ord. of 10-4-2007(01), § (1)) Sec. 110-2. - Multifamily residences to be counted by the number of dwelling units for purposes of local enforcement. (a) For all purposes of calculation, definition or other purpose of regulation and enforcement, a multifamily residence or dwelling shall be deemed to consist of discrete and separate structures in a number corresponding to the actual number of residences located in the subject structure. (b) This provision shall be applied uniformly throughout the entire application of law within the county so that, by way of limited example only, a three-unit multifamily residence shall require three building permits, or, the same three-unit structure shall require the equivalent sized building lot as that required for three distinct residential structures. (Ord. of 10-4-2007(01), § (2)) Sec. 110-3. - Requirements for residential lots served by municipal water or public sewage systems. (a) Any single-family residential lot that is served by municipal water and sewage systems shall be sited on a lot no less than 10,000 square feet. (b) Any single-family residential lot that is served by municipal water or public sewage systems shall be sited on a lot no less than one-half acre. For purposes of this chapter, the term "municipal water" means a water system owned and operated by municipal corporation of the state or a system which is permitted by state and/or federal authorities, contains a treatment component, and is regularly monitored. (c) Any single-family residential lot that is not served by municipal water or public sewage systems shall be sited on a lot no less than one acre. (d) All residential structures must be situated no less than 15 feet from any property line or boundary and no less than 25 feet from any boundary of any public right-of-way. (e) No certificate of occupancy or other needed permit or like document shall be issued for any residence not in compliance herewith. (Ord. of 7-9-2009) Secs. 110-4—110-24. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PLUMBING DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 110-25—110-51. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - FLOW RESTRICTIONS ON FIXTURES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Water efficiency requirements, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-1 et seq.; flow-rate restrictions on plumbing fixtures, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-3.
Sec. 110-52. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Commercial means any type of building other than residential. Construction means the erection of a new building or the alteration of an existing building in connection with its repair or renovation or in connection with making an addition to an existing building and includes the replacement of a malfunctioning, unserviceable or obsolete faucet, showerhead, toilet, or urinal in an existing building. Residential means any building or unit of a building intended for occupancy as a dwelling, but does not include a hotel or motel. (Code 1999, § 5-36) Sec. 110-53. - Effective. The requirements of section 110-58 shall apply to any residential construction initiated after July 1, 1991, and to any commercial construction initiated after July 1, 1992, which involves the repair or renovation of, or addition to, any existing building when such repair or renovation of, or addition to, such existing building includes replacement of toilets or showers, or both. (Code 1999, § 5-37) Sec. 110-54. - Construction. This division shall be deemed cumulative and supplemental and in addition to any other act, law or ordinance shall supersede and repeal any existing ordinance, special law or county regulation which is in direct conflict with this division to the extent of such conflict. The provisions of this division shall be liberally construed in order to effectively carry out its purpose in the interest of the public health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the county and the state. (Code 1999, § 5-38) Sec. 110-55. - Enforcement. The county administrator or his authorized agent shall be authorized to issue citations to violators of any provisions of this division. Such citations shall state the time and place at which the accused is to appear for trial, shall identify the offense with which the accused is charged, shall have an identifying number by which it shall file with the court, shall indicate the identity of the accused and the date of service and shall be signed by the individual who completes and services it. (Code 1999, § 5-39; Ord. No. 12 of 2018, 5-3-2018) Sec. 110-56. - Penalty for violation. Any person violating this division or any provision hereof, upon conviction, shall be punished according to the general penalties described in sections 1-13 and 1-14. Violations of this division shall be tried upon citation as described in section 110-55 and may be tried with or without a prosecuting attorney as well as upon accusations. The county attorney shall serve as prosecuting attorney. Violations of this division shall be tried in the magistrate court or state court, and shall be tried in accordance with O.C.G.A., chapter 15-10 (O.C.G.A. § 15-10-1 et seq.). Each violation of this division shall constitute a separate offense. (Code 1999, § 5-40) Sec. 110-57. - Exemptions. (a) New construction and the repair or renovation of an existing building shall be exempt from the requirements of sections 110-53, 110-58 and 110-59 when: (1) The repair or renovation of the existing building does not include the replacement of the plumbing or sewage system servicing toilets, faucets or showerheads within such existing buildings; (2) Such plumbing or sewage system within such existing building, because of its capacity, design, or installation, would not function properly if the toilets, faucets or showerheads required by this division were installed; (3) Such system is a well or gravity flow from a spring and is owned privately by an individual for use in such individual's personal residence; or (4) Units to be installed are: a. Specifically designed for use by the handicapped; b. Specifically designed to withstand unusual abuse or installation in a penal institution; or c. Toilets for juveniles. (b) The owner, or his agent, of a building undergoing new construction or repair or renovation who is entitled to an exemption as specified in subsection (a)(2), (3) or (4) of this section shall obtain the exemption by applying at the office of the county administrator or his authorized agent. A fee, as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges, shall be charged for the inspection and issuance of such exemption. (Code 1999, § 5-41; Ord. No. 12 of 2018, 5-3-2018) Sec. 110-58. - Residential construction. No plumbing fixture shall be installed which does not meet the standards listed in this section or the state minimum plumbing code, whichever is stricter. This includes all plumbing fixtures installed in newly constructed buildings or when replacing plumbing fixtures during remodeling or renovation of existing buildings, except as noted in this division. The standards are as follows: (1) A water closet or toilet that: a. Is a dual flush water closet that meets the following standards: 1. The average flush volume of two reduced flushes and one full flush may not exceed 1.28 gallons; 2. The toilet meets the performance, testing, and labeling requirements prescribed by the following standards, as applicable: (i) American Society of Mechanical Engineers Standard A112.19.2-2008; and (ii) American Society of Mechanical Engineers Standard A112.19.14-2006, six-liter water closets equipped with a dual flushing device; and 3. Is listed to the WaterSense™ Tank-Type High Efficiency Toilet Specification; or b. Is a single flush water closet, including gravity, pressure assisted and electro-hydraulic tank types, that meets the following standards: 1. The average flush volume may not exceed 1.28 gallons; 2 The toilet must meet the performance, testing, and labeling requirements prescribed by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers Standard A112.192/CSA B45.1 or A112.19.14; and 3. The toilet must be listed to the WaterSense™ Tank-Type High Efficiency Toilet Specification; (2) A shower head that allows a flow of no more than an average of 2.5 gallons of water per minute at 60 pounds per square inch of pressure; (3) A urinal and associated flush valve that: a. Uses no more than 0.5 gallons of water per flush; b. Meets the performance, testing and labeling requirements prescribed by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers Standard A112.19.2/CSA B45.1; c. For flushing urinals, meets all WaterSense™ Specifications for flushing urinals; and d. Where nonwater urinals are employed, complies with American Society of Mechanical Engineers Standard A112.19.3/CSA B45.4 or American Society of Mechanical Engineers Standard A112.19.19/CSA B45.4. Nonwater urinals shall be cleaned and maintained in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions after installation. Where nonwater urinals are installed they shall have a water distribution line roughed-in to the urinal location at a minimum height of 56 inches (1,422 millimeters) to allow for the installation of an approved backflow prevention device in the event of a retrofit. Such water distribution lines shall be installed with shut-off valves located as close as possible to the distributing main to prevent the creation of dead ends. Where nonwater urinals are installed, a minimum of one water supplied fixture rated at a minimum of one water supply fixture unit shall be installed upstream on the same drain line to facilitate drain line flow and rinsing; (4) A lavatory faucet or lavatory replacement aerator that allows a flow of no more than 1.5 gallons of water per minute at a pressure of 60 pounds per square inch in accordance with American Society of Mechanical Engineers Standard A112.18.1/CSA B.125.1 and listed to the WaterSense™ High-Efficiency Lavatory Faucet Specification; and (5) A kitchen faucet or kitchen replacement aerator that allows a flow of no more than 2.0 gallons of water per minute. (Code 1999, § 5-42) Sec. 110-59. - Commercial construction. On or after July 1, 1992, there shall be no construction of any commercial building initiated within the county for any commercial building of any type which does not meet the requirements of section 110-58. (Code 1999, § 5-43) Secs. 110-60—110-76. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - CONSTRUCTION CODES DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 110-77. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Building official or building inspector means the qualified building official or qualified building inspector, as designated by the county. Sec. 110-78. - Interpretations. The building official is hereby authorized to render interpretations of this Code and the adopted state codes and to adopt policies and procedures in order to clarify the application of their provisions. Such interpretations, policies and procedures shall be in compliance with the intent and purpose of this article. Such policies and procedures shall not have the force and effect of law and shall not have the effect of waiving requirements specifically provided for in this Code or in the adopted state codes. Sec. 110-79. - Adoption of technical codes. (a) The following technical and building codes, as adopted and amended by the state department of community affairs, are adopted by reference and incorporated into this Code as if set out fully herein, including the administration and appendix chapters: (1) International Building Code, 2006 edition, with Georgia Amendments 2007. (2) International Residential Code, 2006 edition, with Georgia Amendments 2007 and 2008. (3) International Fire Code, 2006 edition, with Georgia Amendments 2008. (4) International Plumbing Code, 2006 edition, with Georgia Amendments 2007 and 2008. (5) International Mechanical Code, 2006 edition, with Georgia Amendments 2007 and 2008. (6) International Fuel Gas Code, 2006 edition, with Georgia Amendments 2007 and 2008. (7) National Electrical Code, 2005 edition, with Georgia Amendments 2006. (8) International Energy Conservation Code, 2006 edition, with Georgia Supplements and Amendments 2008. (9) CABO One and Two Family Dwelling Code, Appendix G, as the Standard Swimming Pool Code. (b) If any of the publications listed in subsection (a) of this section are adopted as a state minimum code pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20 et seq., then the edition adopted by the state shall control. If any of the publications listed in subsection (a) of this section are less stringent than the state minimum codes promulgated pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20 et seq., then the state minimum code shall control. (c) A copy of each of the publications listed in subsection (a) of this section, as adopted by the state, is filed in the county office and available for review by the public. The same is adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and from the date on which the ordinance from which this section is derived shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the unincorporated area of the county. (Code 1999, § 5-86; Ord. of 6-9-1998, § 1) Sec. 110-80. - Enforcement. Such codes, when reference is made to the duties of a certain official named therein, that designated official of the county who has duties corresponding to those of the named official in such code shall be deemed to be the responsible official for enforcing the provisions of such code. (Code 1999, § 5-87; Ord. of 6-9-1998, § 3) Sec. 110-81. - Certificate of occupancy. (a) A residence shall not be occupied before the building inspector issues a certificate of occupancy on the building. (b) A residence shall meet the requirements of receipt of a certificate of occupancy within one year of obtaining a building permit or a manufactured housing permit. (c) Permanent utility connections will not be issued before a certificate of occupancy is issued. (Code 1999, § 5-88; Ord. of 6-9-1998, §§ 5—7) Secs. 110-82—110-105. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - EXISTING BUILDING CODE
Sec. 110-106. - Adopted. That a certain document, three copies of which are on file with the clerk of the county in the offices of the county board of commissioners, being marked and designated as the International Existing Building Code, 2012 edition (or appropriate future edition thereof), as published by the International Code Council, be and is hereby adopted as the county existing building code, for regulating and governing the repair, alteration, change of occupancy, addition and relocation of existing buildings, including historic buildings, as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said existing building code on file in the office of the county board of commissioners are hereby referred to, adopted and made a party hereof, as if fully set out in this legislation, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 110-107. (Ord. of 3-1-2012(01), § 1) Sec. 110-107. - Revised. The following sections of the existing building code are hereby revised: (1) Section 101.1. These regulations shall be known as the Existing Building Code of Charlton County, State of Georgia. (2) Section 1401.2. Structures existing prior to the effective date of this ordinance, in which there is work involving additions, alterations or changes of occupancy shall be made to conform to the requirements of this chapter or the provisions of chapters 5 through 13. The provisions of sections 1401.2.1 through 1401.2.5 shall apply to occupancies that will continue to be, or are proposed to be, in Groups A, B, E, F, M, R, and S. These provisions shall not apply to buildings with occupancies in Group H or I. (Ord. of 3-1-2012(01), § 2) Sec. 110-108. - Future editions of the International Existing Building Code. From time to time, as future editions of the International Existing Building Code shall be published by the International Code Council, it shall be the duty of the clerk of the county to obtain a copy of the same, and upon receipt thereof, the terms of such future edition shall replace the terms of any outdated edition previously used by the county and such terms shall be hereby adopted and made of full force and effect. (Ord. of 3-1-2012(01), § 6) Sec. 110-109. - Violations. All violations per section 113 of the International Existing Building Code may be made in any court of competent jurisdiction, including the state court, as an ordinance violation and any prosecution of any such violation may be brought by summons, citation, accusation or any other legal instrument. (Ord. of 3-1-2012(01), § 8) Secs. 110-110—110-129. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE
Sec. 110-130. - Adopted. That a certain document, three copies of which are on file with the clerk of the county in the offices of the county board of commissioners, being marked and designated as the International Property Maintenance Code, 2012 edition (or appropriate future edition thereof), as published by the International Code Council, be and is hereby adopted as the county Property maintenance code, for regulating and governing the conditions maintenance of all property, buildings and structures; by providing the standards for supplied utilities and facilities and other physical things and conditions essential to ensure that structures are safe, sanitary and fit for occupation and use, and the demolition of such existing structures as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions, and terms of said property maintenance code on file in the office of the board of commissioners of the county are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this legislation, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 110-131. (Ord. of 3-1-2012(02), § 1) Sec. 110-131. - Revised. The following sections of the International Property Maintenance Code are hereby revised: (1) Section 101.1 Title. These regulations shall be known as the International Property Maintenance Code of Charlton County, hereinafter referred to as "this code." (2) Section 103.5 Fees. The fees for activities and service performed by the department in carrying out its responsibilities under this code shall be set by the Charlton County Board of Commissioners from time to time as required by resolution. (3) Section 112.4 Failure to comply. Any person who shall continue any work after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable for a fine of not less than $100.00 and no more than $500.00. (4) Section 302.4 Weeds. All premises and exterior property shall be maintained free from weeds and plant growth in excess of a reasonable height consistent with surrounding properties and the residential character, or lack thereof, of the same. All noxious weeds shall be prohibited. Weeds shall be defined as all grasses, annual plants and vegetation, other than trees or shrubs, provided; however, this term shall not cover cultivated flowers and gardens. Upon failure of the owner or agent having charge of a property to cut and destroy weeds after service of a notice of violation, they shall be subject to prosecution in accordance with section 106.3 and as prescribed by the authority having jurisdiction. Upon failure to comply with the notice of violation, any duly authorized employee of the jurisdiction or contractor hired by the jurisdiction shall be authorized to enter upon the property in violation and cut and destroy the weeds growing thereon, and the costs of such removal shall be paid by the owner or agent responsible for the property. (5) Section 304.14 Insect screens. During the period of April 1 to October 1, every door, window, and other outside opening required for ventilation of habitable rooms, food preparation areas, food service areas or any other areas where products to be included or utilized in food for human consumption are produced, manufactured, packaged, or stored shall be supplied with approved fitting screens of minimum 16 mesh per inch (16 mesh per 25 millimeters) and every screen door used for insect control shall have a self-closing device in good working condition. Exception: Screens shall not be required where other approved means, such as air curtains or insect repellent fans are employed. (6) Section 602.3 Heat supply. a. Every owner and operator of any building who rents, leases, or lets on or more dwelling units or sleeping units, on terms, either express or implied, to furnish heat to the occupants thereof shall supply heat during the period November 15 to March 15 to maintain a minimum temperature of 68 degrees (20 degrees Celsius) in all habitable rooms, bathrooms and toilet rooms. b. Exceptions: 1. When the outdoor temperature is below the winter outdoor design temperature for the locality, maintenance of the minimum room temperature shall not be required provided that the heating system is operating at its full design capacity. The winter outdoor design temperature for the locality shall be as indicated in Appendix D of this code. 2. In areas where the average monthly temperature is above 30 degrees Fahrenheit (-1 degrees Celsius) a minimum temperature of 65 degrees Fahrenheit (18 degrees Celsius) shall be maintained. (7) Section 602.4 Occupiable work spaces. a. Indoor occupiable work spaces shall be supplied with heat during the period of December 15 to February 15 to maintain a minimum temperature of 65 degrees Fahrenheit (18 degrees Celsius) during the times the space is occupied. b. Exceptions: 1. Processing, storage and operation areas that require cooling or special temperature conditions. 2. Areas in which persons are primarily engaged in vigorous physical activities. (Ord. of 3-1-2012(02), § 2) Sec. 110-132. - Future editions of the International Property Maintenance Code. From time to time, as future editions of the International Property Maintenance Code shall be published by the International Code Council, it shall be the duty of the clerk of the county to obtain a copy of the same, and upon receipt thereof, the terms of such future edition shall replace the terms of any outdated edition previously used by the county and such terms shall be hereby adopted and made in full force and effect. (Ord. of 3-1-2012(02), § 6) Sec. 110-133. - Violations. All violations per section 106 of the International Property Maintenance Code may be made in any court of competent jurisdiction, including the state court of the county, as an ordinance violation and any prosecution of any such violation may be brought by summons, citation, accusation or any other legal instrument. (Ord. of 3-1-2012(02), § 8) Secs. 110-134—110-164. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - PERMITS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 110-165—110-181. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - BUILDING PERMITS
Sec. 110-182. - Requirement of permit. (a) Any persons who intend to construct or cause to be constructed any building, facility or the like, for which the intended purpose is residential or commercial, including remodeling or new construction, shall first make application for a building permit with the county chief tax appraiser or his authorized agent. Such application shall be in a form and adopted by the tax appraiser's office and shall contain all necessary information as to size, type, use, location, etc., of the intended construction, and be signed by the owner or his authorized agent acting on his behalf. (b) All questions on the application shall be clearly answered. Failure to answer, or the giving of misleading or false answers to the questions could possibly jeopardize the issuance of a permit, if in the discretion of the issuing officer such answers so justify. (c) If, in the opinion of the issuing officer, all questions have been answered acceptably, he may proceed to issue the permit, providing the applicant has acquired a septic tank permit from the county health department. This requirement shall be waived if the intended building site is served by a public sewer and that such site can be tapped on to such system or a preexisting approved septic system. (Code 1999, § 5-146; Ord. of 9-5-1991, § 1) Sec. 110-183. - Fee schedule. (a) A fee, as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges, is hereby established for the issuance of a building permit concerning: (1) The remodeling of a residence or construction of an accessory building of 150 square feet of space or more. (2) The construction of a new residential building. (3) The construction of a new commercial building or remodeling of an existing commercial building. (b) No permit for residential or commercial construction shall be issued unless the state minimum standard codes have been met as shown in O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20(9)(B)(i)(I) through (9)(B)(i)(XI). (c) The issuing authority may refuse to issue permits for residential construction which fail to respect the health and environmental needs of the community at large. (Code 1999, § 5-147; Ord. of 9-5-1991, § 2) Sec. 110-184. - Expiration of building permits. Building permits shall be issued for an unspecified time period. However, if construction is not commenced within 90 calendar days of issuance, it shall be deemed void, necessitating the reapplication of a permit, the fee for which will be ten percent of the amount of the original permit fee if the reapplication is submitted within 360 days of the original application. If construction is commenced after 360 calendar days of issuance, the permit shall be void, necessitating a new permit with a full fee as described in section 110-183. (Code 1999, § 5-148; Ord. of 9-5-1991, § 3) Sec. 110-185. - Enforcement. The county administrator of the county or his agents, the sheriff of the county, the deputies thereof, constables and all other law enforcement officers shall be authorized to issue citations to violators of any provisions of this division. Such citation shall state the time and place at which the accused is to appear for trial, shall identify the offense with which the accused is charged, shall have an identifying number by which it shall be filed with the court, shall indicate the identity of the accused and the date of service and shall be signed by the officer who completes and services it. (Code 1999, § 5-150; Ord. of 9-5-1991, § 5; Ord. No. 12 of 2018, 5-3-2018) Secs. 110-186—110-212. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - ELECTRICAL CONNECTION PERMITS
Sec. 110-213. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Electrical connection permit means a permit, issued by the designated official authorized to issue building permits for the unincorporated area of the county, which authorizes a provider of electrical services to furnish electricity to a particular site, structure or purchaser. Provider of electric services means any public utility company or person which sells, furnishes or delivers for sale electrical service within the unincorporated area of the county. Purchaser means any person who purchases or causes to be purchased any electrical service within the unincorporated area of the county. (Code 1999, § 5-176; Ord. of 9-2-1993, § 2) Sec. 110-214. - Issuance of permit. (a) No electrical connection permit shall be issued unless and until the applicant (proposed purchaser) has been issued a valid building permit, if required under division 2 of this article, a valid development permit has been issued, if required under chapter 140, floods, that a driveway culvert off the county road to access the subject property has been properly installed in accordance with county standards, if one is deemed necessary by the county road superintendent, and a valid septic tank permit has been issued by the county board of health, if a sewage disposal system is required, or if the purpose is to reconnect or reestablish electrical service to a site that had previously been provided with electricity, then a certification from the county board of health that any on-site sewage disposal system existing or required by the site complies with health laws and regulations. (b) Any property which has been inspected by the county health department sanitation inspector and found to be in compliance with the county health code regulations shall be exempt from further inspection required by this division for a period of five years from the date of such inspection. The county health department shall maintain a list of all inspected properties, with the date of such inspection, and furnish a copy of the inspection to the county's permit officer. It shall not be a violation of this division for a permit to be issued for any property which has been so inspected within five years. (Code 1999, § 5-177; Ord. of 9-2-1993, § 3; Ord. of 9-1-1994, § 3; Ord. of 12-20-1994) Sec. 110-215. - Application. Prior to the issuance of any electrical connection permit, the applicant shall complete an application for such permit in the form as prescribed by the issuer and pay a fee for such permit in the amount as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. (Code 1999, § 5-178; Ord. of 9-2-1993, § 4) Sec. 110-216. - Proof of application; payment of fee. No provider of electrical service in the unincorporated area of the county shall furnish/connect electricity to any new purchaser or reconnect or reestablish electrical service to any purchaser until the purchaser has obtained and submitted proof of application and payment of the fee to the provider of an electrical connection permit. However, no electrical connection permit shall be required under the provisions of this division for the reconnection of electrical services when service had been disconnected due to nonpayment, and the reconnection occurs within 60 days of the date of disconnect or the reconnection is to restore electrical service which had been interrupted due to natural causes or manmade causes. (Code 1999, § 5-179; Ord. of 9-2-1993, § 5; Ord. of 10-7-1993) Sec. 110-217. - Electrical connections. No person shall connect or have connected electricity to any site or structure within the unincorporated area of the county unless and until an electrical connection permit has been issued, if one is required by this division. If any person makes or causes such an electrical connection without having in his possession or posted on the premises the electrical connection permit or a copy thereof, it shall be presumed that such person intended to violate this division. However, no electrical connection permit shall be required under the provisions of this division for the reconnection of electrical services when service had been disconnected due to nonpayment, and the reconnection occurs within 60 days of the date of disconnect or the reconnection is to restore electrical service which had been interrupted due to natural causes or manmade causes. (Code 1999, § 5-180; Ord. of 9-2-1993, § 6; Ord. of 10-7-1993) Sec. 110-218. - Penalty. (a) Any person violating this division, or any provision hereof, upon conviction, shall be punished by according to the general penalties described in sections 1-13 and 1-14. (b) No person accused of violating this division shall be arrested prior to trial, but any person who fails to appear for trial shall be arrested thereafter on the warrant of the magistrate and required to post bond for his future appearance. (c) Violation of this division shall be tried upon citations which shall be issued to an alleged violator of any provisions of this division. Such citation shall state the time and place at which the accused is to appear for trial, shall identify the offense with which the accused is charged, shall have an identifying number by which it shall be filed with the court, shall indicate the identity of the accused and the date of service and shall be signed by the representative of the county who completes and serves it. Such citation may be served by certified mail, return receipt requested. (d) Citations issued under this section may be tried without a prosecuting attorney; however, in the event a prosecuting attorney is needed the county attorney shall serve as the prosecuting attorney. (e) Violations of this division shall be tried in the magistrate court or state court of the county and shall be tried in accordance with O.C.G.A. chapter 15-10 9 (O.C.G.A. § 15-10-1 et seq.). (f) Nothing in this division shall prevent the board of commissioners from bringing any civil action for injunction, or other proceedings to present, correct or abate any violation of this division or other state or federal law. No sanction, penalty or remedy prescribed in this section shall be considered exclusive of any other remedy, but shall be available in addition to any other sanctions, penalties or remedies provided by law. (g) Each violation of this division shall constitute a separate offense. (Code 1999, § 5-181; Ord. of 9-2-1993, § 7)

div.head: Chapter 120 - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 120-1—120-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - HOUSING AUTHORITY[1] Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Housing Authorities Law, O.C.G.A. § 8-3-1 et seq.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 120-19. - Finding of need. It is hereby determined and declared to be a pressing, existing and future need for a housing authority to function in the county for the purpose of providing an adequate supply of housing in the county, thereby promoting the health and welfare of the people of such county. (Code 1999, § 8-26; Res. of 6-3-1982) Sec. 120-20. - Shortage of safe or sanitary housing. There is a shortage of safe or sanitary dwelling accommodations in the county available to persons of low income at rentals they can afford. (Code 1999, § 8-27; Res. of 6-3-1982) Sec. 120-21. - Established. There is hereby activated the public body corporate and politic known as the housing authority of the county, referred to in this article as the authority, which authority is created pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 8-3-1 et seq. (Code 1999, § 8-28; Res. of 6-3-1982) Secs. 120-22—120-45. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - COMMISSIONERS
Sec. 120-46. - Appointment of commissioners. Commissioners of the authority shall be appointed and serve such terms as provided by state law. (Code 1999, § 8-41) State Law reference— Appointment, qualifications, and tenure of commissioners, O.C.G.A. § 8-3-50. Sec. 120-47. - Powers and duties. The commissioners of the authority shall organize, carry out their duties and responsibilities and exercise their powers and prerogatives in accordance with the terms and provisions of O.C.G.A. § 8-3-1 et seq. (Code 1999, § 8-42; Res. of 6-3-1982) Sec. 120-48. - Compensation; reimbursement. No person shall receive any compensation for serving as a commissioner of the authority, but a commissioner may be reimbursed for his actual expenses incurred in the performance of his duties. (Code 1999, § 8-43; Res. of 6-3-1982) State Law reference— Reimbursement for expenses, O.C.G.A. § 8-3-50(g). Sec. 120-49. - Residency requirements. If a commissioner of the authority at any time ceases to be a resident of the county, his eligibility to serve as a commissioner shall cease and his term of office shall end. (Code 1999, § 8-44; Res. of 6-3-1982)

div.head: Chapter 130 - ENVIRONMENT
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 130-1—130-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - SOIL EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION CONTROL[1]
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Erosion and Sedimentation Act of 1975, O.C.G.A. § 12-7-1 et seq.; local land disturbing activity ordinances, O.C.G.A. § 12-7-4; local land disturbing ordinances, O.C.G.A. § 12-7-6; local erosion programs O.C.G.A. § 12-7-8
Sec. 130-19. - Title. This article will be known as "Charlton County Soil Erosion, Sedimentation and Pollution Control Ordinance." (Code 1999, § 9-26; Ord. of 8-1-1996, § I; Ord. of 7-1-2009, § I) Sec. 130-20. - Definitions. The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article, unless otherwise specifically stated: Best management practices (BMPs) includes sound conservation and engineering practices to prevent and minimize erosion and resultant sedimentation, which are consistent with, and no less stringent than, those practices contained in the Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control in Georgia published by the commission as of January 1 of the year in which the land-disturbing activity was permitted. Board means the board of natural resources. Buffer means the area of land immediately adjacent to the banks of state waters in its natural state of vegetation, which facilitates the protection of water quality and aquatic habitat. Certified personnel means a person who has successfully completed the appropriate certification course approved by the Georgia Soil and Water Conservation Commission. Certified Professional in Erosion and Sediment Control (CPESC) means a professional with current certification by Certified Profession in Erosion and Sediment Control Inc., a corporation registered in North Carolina, which is also referred to as CPESC or CPESC, Inc. Commission means the Georgia Soil and Water Conservation Commission (GSWCC). Cut means a portion of land surface or area from which earth has been removed or will be removed by excavation; the depth below original ground surface to the excavated surface. Also known as excavation. Department means the state department of natural resources (DNR). Design professional means a professional licensed by the state in the field of engineering, architecture, landscape architecture, forestry, geology or land surveying; or a person that is a Certified Professional in Erosion and Sediment Control (CPESC) with a current certification by Certified Professional in Erosion and Sediment Control Inc. Director means the director of the environmental protection division or an authorized representative. District means the Satilla Soil and Water Conservation District. Division means the environmental protection division (EPD) of the department of natural resources. Drainage structure means a device composed of a virtually nonerodible material such as concrete, steel, plastic or other such material that conveys water from one place to another by intercepting the flow and carrying it to a release point for storm water management, drainage control or flood control purposes.
